PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TEAGUE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 40 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent childen of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 12,750 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pension and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
Reintroduction of Medibank; in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 78 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 3,230 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to close the manual assistance telephone exchange at Moree will place in jeopardy the existing services to telephone subscribers in the district by:
1. The loss of a local emergency '000' service being given to non-metropolitan telephone users in emergency conditions;
2. The loss of any local knowledge of the town and district being available to telephone users if this service is moved to a distant centre;
3. The loss of a local and personalised service provided especially to elderly and handicapped people.

We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia should be instructed to seek the views of country telephone subscribers before proceeding with the closure of the manual assistance telephone exchange.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will call on the Government to halt the closure pending a full and open parliamentary inquiry into the needs and desires of affected subscribers and the full economic and social effects of the closure on this district rural telephone subscribers and Telecom Australia employees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 60 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate federal government funding to our university, which has resulted, inter alia, in the erosion of our library facilities-we note that:
1. The opening hours of our main Library have been reduced from 93 1/2 hours a week in 1975 to 72 hours a week in 1982.
2. The number of new books purchased per year has fallen from over 50,000 in 1976 to under 23,000 in 1981.
3. The number of books in storage and inaccessible to students and staff has risen from none in 1977 to over 40,000 in 1981.
4. The number of books discarded in 1976 was over 6,000-by the end of 1981 over 70,000 had been discarded.

We believe this to be educationally retrograde and economically wasteful. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government to increase funding to a level sufficient to allow the university to restore our previous library facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 49 citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights Legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax payer, and
6. evidence suggest that Plant Varietal Rights Legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 35 citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The President and Members of the Senate:
The humble petition of citizens in Victoria showeth:
That at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12th August, 1981:

We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognizing that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from seven citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction, in the provision of accommodation, and the provision of goods and services; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only Church built in Lithuania after World War II;

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we request that the Government take immediate steps to relieve the burden of increased mortgage costs resulting from increasing home loan interest rates.

We find that the resultant increases in mortgage payments have unduly caused a reduction in the standard of living, reflected in the severe difficulty experienced in meeting household budgetary commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should-
1. Maintain Government regulations of bank interest rates.
2. Amend the relevant Acts to provide for a mortgage payment subsidy scheme, based on a 'needs' requirement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of the Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef region has been declared a marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal elections on the question that: 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the Prime Minister's world plan for economic recovery, described by the Prime Minister as unexpected, bold and imaginative, has now been explained to President Reagan and to journalists in the United States? Is the world plan for economic recovery only for foreign consumption or is it just a cooked-up justification for another overseas trip by the Prime Minister? Why has the plan, if it is so important, not been explained to the Australian people and the Australian Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two things ought to be said at the outset. First, the fact is that the Prime Minister went overseas at the specific invitation of the President of the United States of America. That invitation was conveyed to the Prime Minister by the American Vice-President, Mr George Bush. The opportunity for a representative of this country to talk to the President of the United States is apparently regarded as something wrong by the Australian Labor Party. That ought to be kept very much in mind. There is no question at all of the Prime Minister initiating something for his own interest; it is a question of the Prime Minister responding to an invitation. But secondly, when looking at the quality of this plan, how can it be that the Leader of the Opposition failed to note that President Reagan's comments on this plan were that it is very interesting and very constructive? I will have more to say about this matter soon. I do not believe that in any other parliament operating under the Westminster system would any opposition do what this Opposition is seeking to do today, both in Question Time and by way of a matter of public importance. Here is an opposition seeking to denigrate and to destroy the efforts of our Prime Minister travelling abroad at the invitation of the leader of the--

—Order! I ask that interjections cease. I will not entirely stop interjections in the chamber because I accept that some interjections add to the discussions, but I will take steps to stop incessant interjections such as are taking place at present. I ask honourable senators not to interject to the extent to which they are interjecting.

—I repeat that in no other country operating under the Westminster parliamentary system would an opposition seek to do what this Opposition is doing today in an attempt to damage, destroy or denigrate the actions of a Prime Minister of Australia, speaking on behalf of the Australian people, attempting to bring about a better deal for the people of this world, a safer world in terms of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and its security and a better world in terms of living standards for the people of this world, with a better plan for trade. Let the Labor Party take it fairly and squarely: No other political party in a country operating under the Westminster system would be so mean minded, so miserable or so destructive as to attempt to destroy the efforts of that country's elected national leader to do good in this world- in this case the efforts of a leader that are supported by commerce and industry in Australia and by the President of the United States of America. All that the members of the Labor Party can do in response to this is to scream and yell. Let them take it that they stand condemned as people who are white-anted, destructive and totally un-Australian in their attitude.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the reported comments of Mr Justice Keely in the contempt of court case involving the National Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation, Mr Norm Gallagher. Mr Justice Keely said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that there can be no greater contempt than to intimidate a witness before he gives his evidence.
He went on to say:

Plainly the courts will not be able to determine those cases in accordance with the law if one party to the litigation is allowed to frighten the other in such a way that the evidence they would give, and would otherwise give, is coloured or diluted into evidence which is not unfavourable to the party engaging in the conduct.

Mr Gallagher and the Builders Labourers Federation have been found by the court to be clearly in breach of that principle. I further draw the Minister's attention to an article in today's Australian in which the branch secretary of the BLF in New South Wales, Mr Steve Black, indicated that the union will engage --

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, I suggest that you ask your question. You are giving far too much information.

—I am coming to it now, Mr President. Mr Steve Black indicated that the union will engage in a guerrilla industrial campaign against its employers at whose door the union lays the blame for Mr Gallagher's present predicament. Can the Minister indicate whether the employers are to blame for Mr Gallagher's conviction for contempt of court? If they are not, I further ask: What action does the Government intend to take to protect the employers from the proposed industrial action of the BLF? Does the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act provide immediate and adequate relief to the employers presently threatened, intimidated and adversely affected by the tactics of the BLF in retaliation for the gaoling of its National Secretary who has been found to be in contempt of the laws of this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fairly well known to honourable senators that yesterday Mr Justice Keely imposed a fine of $15,000 on the BLF for contempt and sentenced Mr Gallagher to two months' gaol. Another official of the union was found guilty and fined $500, in default 14 days' gaol. It is my understanding that at the moment there has been a stay until next Monday with respect to those matters. The matters are, therefore, potentially still before the court and I do not propose to canvass them before the Senate. It is a fact which I think would be accepted by all honourable senators that all individuals in Australia of whatever rank or station are subject to the same laws. Those laws are administered by the courts. Where there are allegations of breach, those breaches are to be dealt with by the police or other appropriate enforcement authorities. I think we would all support those proper processes of law with respect to any necessary police or court action. I understand that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations takes the view that it is not appropriate to make comments on the matter which may still receive court consideration at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator in his question, however, raised the matter of the industrial position within the building industry. I understand that at the moment the Australian Council of Trade Unions is convening a meeting of the various unions concerned with the building and construction industries and that discussions are planned between the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry in respect of those industries. At this stage I think the involvement of Mr Macphee has been invited. That is a matter to which Mr Macphee has agreed with some qualifications. He has made it clear that it is a matter for the parties to determine but that if both parties believe that a meeting chaired by him would contribute to better industrial relations in the industry, he will be prepared to convene a meeting. If the parties can agree on recommendations which might involve government action he will be pleased to receive those recommendations and act on them in the way which seems most appropriate.

The matters raised by Senator Crichton-Browne are of great interest and concern to the community. I think they are best dealt with by repeating what I said earlier in my answer, that all Australians, whether they be trade unionists, employers, members of a government or simply private citizens, are subject to the law and the jurisdiction of the courts. Illegal activity, where it occurs, should be dealt with by the proper processes of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and is asked in the light of the fact that we approach the 1982 Budget in a context of discussion and rumour about projected tax cuts. I ask the Minister: Is it true that, in framing the 1977 Budget, figures of revenue, later described by Sir Phillip Lynch as rubbery, were adopted by the Fraser Cabinet? Is it true that these rubbery figures were compiled by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and vigorously disputed by the Department of the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office? Were the figures accepted so that the Government could go to the Federal election a few months later offering income tax cuts? Were these tax cuts withdrawn five months later?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget Cabinet, as in all Budget Cabinets, has before it information from all sources. The nature of the information that is given to it, whether it is given by departments or by other sources, is of course given in a confidential fashion to guide the Government in the formation of its policies. The Government did that in the 1977 Budget, as it did in all other Budgets. There is no question that the Government set out to mislead. It did not do so. The Government presented its Budget--
—You always do. You do it every day in here. Ask the Rundle shareholders.

—If one wants to interject, one should take the 1975 Budget of Mr Hayden, repeat the statements of Mr Hayden at the beginning of his Budget Speech-I have his speech handy-and look at the results. Nothing could be more divergent than what Mr Hayden said in his Budget Speech and what in fact was the result. Mr Hayden said in his Budget Speech that his Government had to reduce a deficit which was running at about $4,000m. So that there would not be unemployment and inflation he had to get the figure down. He said that it is wrong to believe that one can spend up big and create employment and he said one must reduce a deficit in order to stop unemployment. All these things were said. They are a thesis which is rejected today by the Australian Labor Party. They were rejected by the results of the Hayden Budget. It ill becomes any Labor party to raise its head to talk about promise and performance in a Budget. The 1975 Budget stands as the then Treasurer Mr Hayden stating a correct premise and performing a completely incorrect performance which resulted in huge deficits, huge unemployment and huge inflation which ran at about 17 1/2 per cent. Therefore, the Labor Party should look to itself.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the very welcome decision of the Government which the Minister announced last Friday that theological students, in recognition of the academic merits of their courses, and the importance of their community service as graduates, will be treated no longer as exceptions to the general case for other university and college students but will now be able to receive allowances under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. How many theological students is it estimated will receive TEAS allowances this year? Will TEAS allowances be calculated from January this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Teague for the support he has given to the Government's decision to extend to one group of tertiary students the same capacity to attract benefits as is available to other tertiary students. I am not able, at this stage, to say the number of courses or the number of students who will benefit but I can advise the honourable senator that we are at the present time examining each course to see whether it will qualify for the benefits. The Government's policy will be to approve for TEAS those courses at the universities and colleges which lead to a formal qualification at the institution, which are not sponsored by some outside organisation and which qualify for Commonwealth funding under the appropriate Commonwealth-State grants legislation. A number of courses are at the margin. It is a question of carrying out an examination course by course to ensure that those who do qualify are appropriately brought in. This course of action was held up for some time because of a case before the High Court last year-one about which Senator Teague will have some knowledge-based on a challenge as to the meaning of section 116 of the Constitution. Now that that is out of the way the new policy can be put into place. Senator Teague also asked me when the benefits will apply. I will have to obtain for him an answer to that part of the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I preface my question by congratulating the Government on its appointment of Mr Macphee to the Employment and Industrial Relations portfolio. It was my privilege to join Mr Macphee on the Council of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures at the time he was appointed as director of that body. I can assure the Senate that his knowledge of the workings of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is second to none in this country. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Canberra Times this morning which indicated that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is considering a fundamental re-write of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, a task long overdue. I ask: Firstly, what input will the Parliament have to this re-write? Secondly, can we have an assurance that the Government will make clear its intentions in the wage fixing area, now that we no longer have indexation, before this re-write of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is undertaken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass on to Mr Macphee and to the Prime Minister the sentiments expressed by the honourable senator in respect of Mr Macphee and his holding of this portfolio. I have not seen the report in the Canberra Times about the desire of the present Minister fundamentally to re-write the Act. While understanding that viewpoint I have a sense of deja vu about it; he is not the first person to express that laudable ambition. I certainly wish my friend and colleague well in that exercise. I think that reflects a view which the previous Minister, Mr Viner, had and the Minister before him, Mr Peacock, had. Undoubtedly it is something which must have a great deal of merit because it has received support from a succession of Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the input of Parliament is concerned I would like to assure the Senate and the honourable senator who asked the question that we are all strict constitutionalists. Any re-write of the Act will be submitted to the Parliament before it has any effect. In other words, there will be an opportunity for full and fair debate of any proposal which the Government wishes to put forward in respect of the re-writing of this Act. Indeed there is no way that one can avoid that. The fate of the recent legislation which has gone before a Senate committee is an indication that the extent to which Parliament wishes to contribute to that process in a detailed way is in its hands. If, however, the honourable senator is concerned that there should be some pre-drafting input to the legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Senator Siddons indicates that that was the import of his question. At present I know of no formal arrangement within the Parliament which would bring together the quite diverse views existing within the Parliament as to the most appropriate form of this legislation. The difficulties faced in re- writing the legislation are exemplified by our recent debate. Even though there was an almost unanimous view within the Parliament that we should move to industry-based unions, there were sharp differences about the efficacy or otherwise of the particular means proposed in the legislation which has now been referred to a committee and which I will not canvass in this answer. I suggest that if there are individual members of Parliament who have particular views on how the legislation should be reshaped they have the opportunity to use the forms of this place, such as matters of public importance and the adjournment debate, to place those views on public record. I have little doubt that Mr Macphee would welcome constructive suggestions from any member of the Parliament if less formal approaches are desired. I think it is up to honourable senators who feel that they have something to contribute to any such re-writing of the Act to come forward and to make their views known to the Government and to the Minister concerned.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the call of the Australian Democrats in the Australian Capital Territory made to the Leader of the Opposition that if elected an Australian Labor Party government should nationalise the Belconnen Mall?
—Push that parish pump.

—The parish pump is doing very well. While I am looking after the interests of the Australian Capital Territory it will be in good hands. Is the Minister aware of the call of the local branch of the Labor Party to the Leader of the Opposition that if elected a Labor government should re-appropriate the Belconnen Mall at the purchase price? In view of the threat of both the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to nationalise a shopping centre legitimately sold to the private sector, can the Minister confirm that the Government will proceed with the decision to sell the Belconnen Mall?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party can laugh if it wants to at a stated intention of the alternative government in Australia to nationalise shopping centres and, indeed, to offer threats to would-be purchasers that they will lose the value of their purchases. The facts are as Senator Reid says. On 14 May the Minister for the Capital Territory announced that the Belconnen Mall would be offered for sale by world-wide tender. Mr Hodgman said that the Government had agreed to a strategy for marketing the Mall and that current Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines would apply to the sale. Richard Ellis (New South Wales) Pty Ltd will be engaged to assist in the arrangement for the offer for sale of the Mall. The company will also give advice on purchase proposals when they are received and provide a recommendation on the preferred purchaser, price and terms and conditions. It is expected that the invitation to tender will be released within the next few weeks. An important condition of the sale will be that the new owner should continue to provide the Belconnen Community Service with rent-free floor space and a subsidy which compares to its present level.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first part of Senator Reid's question, the Government intends to sell the Mall. The Government does not believe that it is the duty of governments to own shopping centres or to operate shopping centres as such. Therefore, it notes with considerable concern the resurrection of the nationalisation tendencies of the Opposition. It notes also the threat implicit in this-that any purchaser of the Mall will have it appropriated at the price paid for it. In other words, here is a threat, a blackmail, a duress aiming at a purchaser saying: 'Do this but you will be under threat to lose in the future'. This is an utterly discreditable performance on the part of any political party that pretends to provide an alternative government. It, in fact, shows that once again the Labor Party is continuing its nationalisation efforts as it is, of course, in the oil industry as it has quite clearly shown in recent days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Leader of the Government in the Senate be tabled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations refers to the Canberra Times article. I know that the Minister has said that he has not read it. I just read in brief what Mr Macphee has said. Referring to the Viner legislation the article stated:

QUESTION.PARA: 'The ACTU and the CAI didn't raise that legislation when I spoke to them,' he said.
'It is something they would see as, in a sense, in the past. It's a long way down the track.'
Is that legislation, so far as the Government is concerned, now in the past? What is the status of that proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the ambition of the Government to have the legislation on the statute book by now but that was not the will of the Senate which has sent the legislation to a committee. The committee is to consider the legislation and report by September which I think was the date set in the resolution. The Government has accepted in the past an obligation to respond to parliamentary committee reports. I do not intend to be contemptuous of the Senate in this regard. Clearly, we will be having a committee inquiry. It will be encumbent on the Government to look at that inquiry before declaring its further intention with respect to legislation. I do not want that to be heard as being some qualification of the Government's view with respect to the legislation. But I think that the Senate having made that decision over the objections of the Government, there is no point in pretending that it has not been made. We shall await the outcome of that inquiry to see what fresh light, if any, is cast upon the problems which the legislation purported to deal with.

ANSWER.PARA: At risk of appearing overly cautious, I ask the Senate to treat that answer as a quite neutral one. As I said, if the Government had had its way, its wish, the legislation would now be through the Parliament and, subject to the completion of the third element, namely, obtaining the approval of the Crown, the legislation would be in force. We are now in a position where the Senate, exercising its powers and responsibilities, has added another stage, and I would not seek to prejudge the outcome of that. There is nothing before the Government at this stage which would suggest that it would resile from this legislation, but we will wait to see what the Senate committee comes up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the article in last week's National Times under the heading 'Hazards of Smoking' which contained some alarming and perhaps extreme statements about the subject? The article claimed that 95 per cent of people who have the severe arterial disease which can lead to amputation of both legs are smokers, that almost three times as many Australians die prematurely from smoking as die from road accidents, that nearly half the smoking related deaths are from coronary heart disease, that only 5 per cent to 10 per cent of lung cancer sufferers survive five years of treatment and even that smokers are more wrinkled because of the effect of smoking on the blood supply. Can the Minister substantiate these statements? If so, can he reconcile with them the fact that we are giving an average of more than $20,000 a year each to tobacco growers to produce this dangerous drug-a rate of subsidy which is much higher than that for any other form of primary industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the article in the National Times of last week. It is apparent from Senator Hamer's question that what Senate committees have failed to do with their impassioned writings the National Times was able to communicate in its pages last week. It apparently has got a message through on some facts which have been known and articulated for some time. The claims are generally true. I will not go over them one by one. There is in fact a major public health risk connected with smoking and it is because of this that the Government has a national goal, which it has enunciated here, to reduce smoking. Having said that, I point out that the question of subsidies to tobacco growers does not of itself go to the level of smoking in Australia. While there is a capacity to import tobacco leaf, the subsidies go to the question of what leaf is used by those who choose to smoke. The whole question of support for the tobacco industry is at present, I believe, before the Industries Assistance Commission. Numbers of submissions have been received from interested groups, including those that are concerned about the health effects of smoking. The IAC in due course will make its report and the Government, at that time, will consider the issues, which will include issues related to the support for tobacco growers. I finish by saying that it will not be the Government's objective to try to scapegoat any person, any section of the community or any industry in pursuing its other policy goals.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. On 10 March this year I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether any signatory to the Treaty on Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is able to accumulate and enrich nuclear material to weapons grade under accepted international safeguards and then withdraw from the Treaty at any time of its choosing. In reply the Minister for Foreign Affairs pointed out that under Article X of the Treaty any state party has the right to withdraw from the Treaty if it, meaning the state party, itself decides that ' extraordinary events related to the subject matter of the Treaty have jeopardised its supreme interests' and if that country simply gives three months notice of intent. I ask: Does the Minister consider that in the light of that answer it is alarmingly obvious that the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty is little more than an elaborate source of empty rhetoric and that it is totally ineffective in preventing, or even limiting, the spread of nuclear weapons? However, since it is worth the safeguard and is regarded as the central plank in the Government's uranium export policy, will the Minister guarantee that no more Australian uranium will be exported until an effective system is discovered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, there is a total misunderstanding, which was evidenced yesterday in the debate on the matter of public importance, regarding the availability of uranium in the world and the link between nuclear power stations and nuclear weapons. Any country on earth is able to get hold of uranium without needing to buy it from any other country. Uranium is very well distributed on this earth's surface and in the oceans. As such, it is true that in some countries, such as Australia, it is in cheap, highly concentrated form; but the availability of uranium itself is not a bar in weapons making. That is the first point that needs to be made. Therefore, secondly, whether or not the world has nuclear power stations is irrelevant to the question of whether nations will seek to make atomic weapons. The knowledge of how to make atomic weapons is in people's minds, and people will strive to do so and strive to beat the system.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of that, there is an International Atomic Energy Agency, an Australian Safeguards Office and a Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. In that real world what is striven to be done is the very best that can be done to ensure the limitation of people's ability to use the ordinary processes to make arms. I do not regard the International Atomic Energy Agency as an ineffective body. It may well be that history will prove that it will need to strengthen itself. I said yesterday that I shall be having discussions with that Agency in the next week or two on many of these matters.

But let me deal with the question of the enrichment of uranium to weapons standard. That is not something that can be done overnight. I have repeated in this Senate that enriching uranium-that is, converting it to the hexafluoride and then separating the isotopes-is a chemical process capable of being inspected thoroughly, and the grade of enrichment is capable of identification from day to day. The ordinary enrichment for peacetime purposes is much lower than for weapons grade. Therefore, the inspecting agencies are competent to determine very quickly whether an enrichment plant is moving away from peacetime to wartime purposes. Of course, it can then act very quickly indeed to cut off any supplies of uranium or enriched uranium to the countries concerned.

I repeat: Nothing in the world can stop a country from getting uranium if it wants to do so, because it is distributed throughout the whole world. It does no one any good to get away from the real facts. They are that nuclear energy, the ability to produce fission in this world for peaceful or for destructive purposes, is here to stay. The fissile materials are distributed over the earth' s surface. What we need to do is to keep on strengthening our policing systems to limit the number of nuclear arms, and to this Australia is dedicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question.
—Some of the wildest theories ever heard have been heard today.

—The honourable senator will hear a few more when I ask this supplementary question. The fact that Senator Sir John Carrick now admits that the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is ineffective does not answer that part of my question in which I asked whether he would take steps to see that no more Australian uranium is exported.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite outrageous to put into my mouth that I admitted that the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty was ineffective. That is typical of the standard of debate today on the part of the Opposition. I said that it was the best that man can devise today in the policing of these things in this world. I pointed out that the restriction of the movement of Australian uranium around the world would in no way stop countries, if they so wanted, from making weapons. They can make them from the sources they have. For example, the Argentine has its own natural sources of uranium. Everybody has them. If they want access to uranium, they can get it. So stopping the movement of uranium around the world will not stop the making of weapons. The policing of uranium by the International Atomic Energy Agency and by the Australian Safeguards Office can go a very long way towards achieving that goal, and we are working towards that.

—The ratification of the River Murray scheme yesterday, on which I congratulate the Minister for National Development and Energy, has inspired this question concerning the Bradfield scheme. I ask: Is the Minister aware of this scheme, recently referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald as the old dream to water the inland, which was suggested earlier this century to divert Australia's eastern coastal rivers inland in order to supplement Australia's freshwater reserves? Has the Minister's Department ever studied this scheme in terms of engineering feasibility and cost-benefit? If it has not, will the Minister undertake to have such an evaluation carried out? Does the Minister recognise that a far-reaching program is required to assure Australia of an adequate supply of fresh water for domestic, rural and industrial usage, particularly beyond the middle of the year 2000, as by then, it has been suggested, Australia's water reserves could be almost fully committed?
—Is this a question, a speech, a statement or what?

—It is of great significance to the Opposition, I hope, and to every Australian, so I will proceed with my question. When considering this subject has the Minister's Department ever involved industry in examinations with the object of enlisting financial support for water resource projects? Does the Minister agree that industry has an obligation to assist in securing Australia's future water supplies as it is a major user of this most vital resource without which industrial development cannot continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's one resource that is severely limited, and the one that will be the most limiting if we do not take the correct steps in our development, is water. We are the most arid continent on earth. The average rainfall over the Australian continent is 16 inches a year, compared with a world average of 26 inches. We must start off with that. We have no real river systems. The Murray-Darling is our largest. Therefore, it is true that water is of pre-eminent significance to us. It is true that the Government recently arranged for an overview of water resources to be undertaken and managed by a committee in conjunction with the States. That committee is now very active in its work.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the Bradfield scheme which aimed to divert rivers of northern Queensland inland to Lake Eyre. The scheme was based on the theory that this diversion would change the rainfall pattern of inland Australia. There are a number of problems with that suggestion, of course. Some people unkindly have noticed that the great expanse of water that lies around the Great Australian Bight is alongside the driest part of the world-that is, the Nullarbor Plain-and that evaporation from a surface of water does not necessarily produce rain that will fall on nearby country; it may help, in fact, countries of Asia. Unkind people have also pointed out that if we were to divert those rivers down to Lake Eyre we would divert them first of all into a lake the water of which is highly saline. Therefore, if the water got there it would be salt water. Of course, they pointed out the obvious thing, that on the way evaporation would be great and the diversion would not necessarily result in any rain in the area. My Department has not evaluated the scheme. It was evaluated in some detail by several experts, including Dr Nimmo. These analyses showed that the proposal had overestimated the quantities of water which would be finally available for diversion to Lake Eyre and had underestimated the engineering difficulties involved and the cost of the scheme.

The New South Wales Water Resources Commission has recently completed the updating of a number of proposals formulated in 1968 for diverting water from coastal rivers into the Upper Darling. Subsequently, a consultant reviewed 40 of these proposals and identified five coastal river basin systems in respect of which a total of eight proposals warranted investigation. These figures indicated that all eight proposals were more expensive in terms of unit cost of supply on a year to year basis than proposals for storage which could be constructed west of the Divide. A considerable amount of study is still going on in that regard. As to the latter part of the question, the Commonwealth is well aware that industry itself has a conjoint responsibility in helping to provide the resource. The Government, when it has its overview in mind, will be looking towards its implementation on a Commonwealth-State basis in conjunction with industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document from which the Minister quoted be tabled.
—I table the document.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is there not an inconsistency in the two speeches made by the Prime Minister while he was in America? In his Washington speech Mr Fraser called for more free world trade and in New York he called for what appeared to be restrictions on trade with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Does this mean that Mr Fraser proposes some curtailment of the massive Australian trade, particularly of agricultural commodities, with the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no inconsistency at all in what the Prime Minister has been trying to do. Two great problems confront the world today. One is the major threat of war resulting from the enormous overarmament of the USSR and the weaker position of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. There has been a huge expansion of nuclear and conventional armament by the USSR in contrast with what has occurred in the free world. Therefore, there is a major threat of war with aggression being taken by the USSR in a number of countries around the world. That is demonstrable. The Prime Minister was directing himself , very properly, towards the need to establish and maintain world peace, to try to achieve nuclear disarmament and to try to get a balance of peace. If the imposition of sanctions is necessary to achieve peace, it will be a small price to pay.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister also noted that the world is in a major recession, that Western Europe and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development will be confronted with an unemployment level of 30 million people. Arising out of their depression of recent years there has been a tendency for countries, naturally enough, to put up defensive barriers of more protection, which have reduced the flow of trade and, therefore, reduced the capacity for employment. The Prime Minister put forward what I believe is a valid premise-that is, if the whole of the free world were to put down its barriers, trade would flow more freely and there would be more employment. I would have thought that both those goals would be fully acceptable to members of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —As good as your resources boom.

—Those who are mumbling about resources booms should talk to the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. He claimed that three quarters of the resources boom would occur in his own State. He cannot even generate enough electricity to keep the existing industries going. The Federal President of the Labor Party went to the electors and said: 'Put us in because we can create full employment in Australia. That is our election policy platform. Put us in and we will give you free employment because we have the electric power and the resources. We have $25 billion listed of the Commonwealth 's $32 billion'.
—I raise a point of order. The question concerned events on the other side of the world and we have somehow got back to Australia. I think that the Minister is off the point.

—There is no point of order, Senator. The Minister had responded to an interjection. However, I would ask that questions and answers be shortened . That would enable far more senators to ask questions. Today we are very short in regard to the number of questions asked.

—It was, of course, a question which related to profound issues-war and unemployment-and I believe deserved a detailed response. In answer to a question on the resources boom, I merely indicated the fact that the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party had claimed that three- quarters of the announced projects would happen in his State, but he cannot even finance the existing industries in that State.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. In light of the fact that the Minister went off at 180 degrees somewhere along the line, I ask him again the latter part of my question: Does this mean that Mr Fraser proposes some curtailment of Australian trade, particularly in agricultural commodities, with the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Mr Fraser is asking the free world , in those very important discussions at the summit, to look at ways to bring pressure upon the Soviet Union to reduce its force of arms. One of those ways is by the imposition of sanctions; that is one of the propositions put forward. I repeat: I would believe and hope that all Australians would want to use any measure that would compel the Soviet Union to stop its soaring arms race, both conventional and nuclear, and to bring some kind of equality and disarmament to the world and some guarantee of peace. I would have thought all Australians would be on the side of the Prime Minister in that endeavour.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I commend and draw to his attention the publication Challenge to Australia by three eminent Australians-Sir Barton Pope, Sir Frank Macfarlane Burnet and Sir Mark Oliphant. One of the themes of the booklet is the need for long term planning to meet the challenges of the future. I ask: With this in mind, does the Government envisage a need for a ministry of planning, perhaps similar to that which operates in New Zealand, or could the Minister's own department be widened to include long term planning in respect of all resources, including human resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three gentlemen in question are well known to me. They are eminent Australians and each, in his own way, has been a great achiever in Australia; each, in his particular discipline, has achieved much. Indeed, Macfarlane Burnet and Oliphant are known on the world scene. Therefore, their views are always to be read with considerable respect. Their desire to use prudently and effectively the resources of Australia, including its human resources, for the good of Australians generally is to be taken seriously. Indeed, I have had discussions with some of their numbers. The Government has clearly in mind the need for orderly planning. It has not believed it necessary to set up a department of planning. For example, at this moment the water resources sector is busy endeavouring to achieve co-ordination throughout Australia so that co-operative planning will be possible. Co-operation is being sought through the various ministerial councils. As a federation, Australia I hope will always need to work through such councils. The Cabinet itself, as a committee, is essentially a national planning committee, and all Cabinet Ministers have a responsibility in that regard. I commend all and any Australians who look in depth at the development of our resources and come forward with thoughtful proposals, all of which will be taken very seriously by the Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Although in recent years the questions of excessive surgery and the fortunes being made by doctors owning pathology services have been mentioned here time and again, can the Government produce any evidence that it is acting effectively to curb the massive financial rip-off of the community by some doctors? Did the Minister note comments in this morning's Australian by two health authorities that there was an 'epidemic of hysterectomies' in Australia and that women were 'being sold a package of desirable outcomes' by surgeons following hysterectomy? Is the Minister aware of persisting reports of annual incomes estimated to be in the millions of dollars earned by doctors engaged in pathology services? Would the Minister agree that in these respects self- regulation in the medical profession must now be regarded as a failure? Will the Government institute an inquiry into the cost of private pathology services since these are distributed throughout the community in the form of higher medical insurance costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really quite surprised by the tone of the question which implied that there is, in the provision of pathology services, a systematic and widespread rip-off. I have seen some of the reports which draw attention to excessive services and I am aware of statements made by a former Minister for Health at the time he introduced some legislative changes which are to be debated in the Senate. Because of some inadequate aspects of the system, the Government is moving in a very effective way to bring about administrative penalties for those doctors who choose to misuse the system either by fraud or by overservicing. Senator Mason knows that this legislation is at present before the Senate and that it will come up for debate within the next week or so. That legislation will impose penalties greater than any which have ever been envisaged before in this country.
—It doesn't cover Senator Mason's points.

—It goes to part of Senator Mason's points. Senator Mason has to acknowledge that the Government is moving to make it inappropriate for doctors to use fraud or overservicing in the future and that the Government system of detecting fraud and overservicing, on which parties in the Parliament have been briefed, will help us to pick up those people. I am very wary of anecdotal reports in papers about matters such as hysterectomies. I am very ready to acknowledge that if we can obtain community evidence that on a systematic basis any particular procedure is being overused, that requires the closest attention. If in fact it is out of line with experience in other parts of the world, either there has to be some local medical explanation or we have to assume that there is some element of inappropriate delivery of services.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mason has referred particularly to massive rip-offs by doctors and has linked that to pathology services. I am concerned by that. Some years ago there was a period when it was necessary to alter the structure by which payments from the public purse were made to those delivering pathology services. New procedures were instituted and as a result I think most of the inappropriate activities have been contained. The fact is that there is a wide call for pathology services to be delivered in the community. They are delivered both through the Government system-I mention to Senator Mason that the large earners of income among doctors who attract salaries plus fees for service in hospitals are the pathologists-that is, through the public hospital system and through private services. The reason that large incomes are involved is twofold. First of all, the services are in demand and are required in modern medical practice. Secondly, with a view to economies of scale, pathologists tend to work together in large units because of the capital equipment involved. The new legislation will go a long way to limiting the activities of the pathologists, as well as other doctors. I cannot say that self-regulation has failed. What I can say is that what is required is a set of co-operative actions involving the profession, the health funds and government. The Government is moving now to change the procedures in a very major way. I suggest to the Senate and to the honourable senator that what we should do now is see what effect these new legislative provisions have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was most interested in the Minister's reply. I thank him for it. It was a most important and significant answer, but it has not covered, as Senator Chipp said, the basic point which I raised about cost. The costs of things like pathology services and other medical services come back to the whole of the community in the form of higher medical insurance costs. The community is feeling this most severely. Can the Minister give me any undertaking that the Government is, in fact, considering legislation which will, in some way, look at that situation even if it were legislation which merely required or put forward the hope of some kind of self-regulation or some kind of action to limit those costs by the profession in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I say that the legislation presently before the Senate will pick up fraud and over-servicing by doctors. Among doctors are pathologists. Pathologists will not be immune from any provisions of the new legislation. It will impact upon them as it impacts upon other members of the profession. There is an emerging recognition from within the profession-I draw the honourable senator's attention to the statements by Dr Wilson, President of the Australian Medical Association, in which he has brought this to the fore-of the role which the profession has to play in controlling some of these practices . I think to that extent we would be on common ground. Again I urge Senator Mason to let the new legislation come in. It will be effective. I think doctors are very concerned not to infringe its very severe provisions.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. At the outset I say that despite my forebodings about his fate expressed before the reshuffle, I am glad to see Senator Durack back in that office as alive and as alert as ever.
—Goodbye, Senator.

—I will be around to haunt you for a long time yet, Senator Chaney . Is it the case that the Chief Censor, Mrs Janet Strickland, as has been reported in the Press recently, has demanded the submission to the Film Censorship Board of four overseas films scheduled for showing at the Melbourne Film Festival? Is it further the case that in an agreement drawn up with the Attorney-General's Department in 1975 it was accepted that every festival film would be registered, without prior showing, for festival screening except in cases of films which had been rejected previously for commercial use? Does the Government approve the Film Censorship Board's departure in the present case from what appears to be the letter, and is certainly the spirit, of that 1975 agreement-a departure, in fact, foreshadowed by a number of actions and speeches by Mrs Strickland over the last 12 months? If the Government does approve, does this signal an imminent major crackdown by the Commonwealth on the censorship front and a return to the bad old days we grew out of more than a decade ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the matters that Senator Evans has raised. An agreement in 1975 related to film festivals. It gave a number of concessions to the promoters of film festivals. Conditions were set out in that agreement. By and large those conditions do, on the face of it, provide that registration of films be made without screening. The agreement actually referred to film festivals held in 1975 although I understand that it has been accepted as current despite the fact that it does seem to be limited to the specific festivals in that year. However, the Chief Censor, Mrs Strickland, has taken the view that under the regulations and under the responsibilities imposed upon her by law that agreement is subject to the overriding requirements of the regulations and the responsibilities that she has under them. The stand she has taken does not modify, to any further extent, the benefits that film festivals have under that agreement. She requires the films to be brought in for screening only under exceptional circumstances. She has made that policy quite clear for some time. This is not the first occasion that this has occurred. Indeed, in my recollection, the first occasion on which she took that stance was at a film festival in Adelaide about a year or more ago in respect of a film that did cause a great deal of controversy in South Australia at that time. She has made that policy quite clear. I believe that she is entirely justified in taking this stand. Indeed I think she probably has a legal obligation to take this stand.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter was raised about this time last year by Senator Hamer in relation to , I think, a film festival at that time. I said that I would take up the matter for consideration by the meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for censorship with a view to seeing whether there was any concern by them about the policy being followed by the Chief Censor and also whether there ought to be in the laws some special provisions relating to film festivals. I did so, and at the meeting held in August last year the Ministers supported the view of the Chief Censor and did not feel that any special provisions ought to be made in relation to film festivals. Some reservations were expressed by the Minister representing Victoria at that meeting, but overwhelmingly that was the view of the meeting. That is how the matter stands.

Mrs Strickland has my full support and indeed the support of most of the State Ministers in Australia in regard to the stand she is taking. This does not mean that there is any crackdown in censorship. As I have said, considerable relaxations of the ordinary rules are made for film festivals. It is only in exceptional cases, in my experience, that she has taken this view. This time she has done it in respect of four films, which is more than has been the case on any other occasion. I have discussed it with her and she has expressed concern about what she has heard and read about these films and she believes that she is acting entirely within her rights, as I am sure she is, in taking this stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, I wish to raise a point of order in respect of the way Question Time has been dealt with today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). My point of order is this: It is quite obvious that Question Time was grossly abused today by honourable senators opposite giving prepared questions to the Leader of the Government in the Senate . I sought to have two documents tabled. I have now had a look at them. One relates to a question asked by Senator Reid, and the answer given by Senator Carrick is headed 'suggested response'. He then took up a long time of the Senate dealing with the Belconnen Mall. The further abuse was the question asked by Senator Jessop. The document which I had tabled begins, 'Yes, I am aware of the Bradfield scheme'. Of course neither of those documents could be typed if the questions were truly without notice. It is quite obvious that Government back benchers are giving prepared questions to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and probably to other Ministers, whilst people on this side of the chamber are being denied the opportunity to ask questions on behalf of their constituents because the Leader of the Government in the Senate goes into a long diatribe, especially when there are interjections, and it takes him nearly five minutes to answer each of these prepared questions. I ask you, Mr President, to have a look at these documents which were tabled today and to see whether a remedy can be obtained.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. Two aspects of the matter have been raised by Senator McLaren. I see no reason why Government senators should not give advance notice of a subject about which they want facts. What I object to is the lengthy answers that we sometimes get. It means that honourable senators on this side of the chamber, as well as Opposition senators, do not get the opportunity of asking questions. I do not know how many questions were asked today but I think the number would be near an all time low.
—That goes for the quality of the answers too.

—I am not talking about the quality of the answers or the questions, but we get some poor questions and poor answers from time to time. At least if we could have more succinct answers in particular we could have more questions. I have been seeking the call all day but have been unable to ask a question.
—You are not the only one.

—I am not the only one; I agree there are many others. I believe that we should be getting through more questions and answers in a day. I hope the matter will be looked at to see whether we cannot do that. I had what I thought was an important question to ask today. It will be asked tomorrow; so it will not matter.
—You hope.

—I hope it will be asked tomorrow. I want to say that I object to the idea that Ministers should necessarily not know anything about the subject matter of a question to be asked. If, in fact, an honourable senator wants some facts, those facts ought to be released in the Senate. That would still be providing an answer to a question without notice.
—Both sides do it.

—Honourable senators on both sides do it, as the honourable senator has pointed out. Of course they do. Senator Mulvihill is a notorious practitioner of that sensible course which I have mentioned. I believe that at the same time far too long-winded answers are being given and in my opinion something should be done to stop them.
—Mr President, I think some of the points of order are very long- winded, too.
—Yes, I take that on board. I hope the points of order do not continue to be as long as the last two.
—Mr President, I wish to raise a point of order.
—We have equalised the points of order from both sides of the chamber. However, I will hear Senator Colston on a point of order.
—I must say that I was on my feet trying to raise a point of order before Senator Missen received the call and at the same time as Senator McLaren.
—Yes, that is right.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Colston

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is that the Leader of the Government in the Senate asked you, Mr President, whether further questions could be placed on notice. Mr President, I ask you to consider whether you may not accede to that request today. For three consecutive days some of us in this chamber have risen trying to ask a question but have not received the call. Today the Leader of the Government in the Senate deliberately and provocatively filibustered throughout the whole of Question Time and took a great deal of the time that should have been taken by the asking of questions. In looking at the Standing Orders, I see that there is nothing which indicates that the Leader of the Government may request that further questions be placed on notice. All that the Standing Orders state in relation to questions is:

INTERJECT.PARA: After Notices have been given Questions may be put to Ministers of the Crown . . .

We have often raised in the Senate the matter of whether the Leader of the Government can, in fact, do this. It has been acknowledged that it is not in the Standing Orders but that it has been an accepted practice. That practice will not be acceptable to honourable senators on this side of the chamber if the Leader of the Government deliberately filibusters throughout Question Time so that the asking of questions can be limited. Mr President, I ask you to have a look at the possibility of extending Question Time today and not acceding to the Minister's request at this time. I am certain that the situation will be much different next week. A different person will be sitting in that chair next week and I am sure that we will have a better Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reflection on the Chair.
—I am talking about the person sitting in the chair occupied by the Leader of the Government. If it is a reflection on that chair, that reflection should stand.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now respond to the points of orders which have been raised by honourable senators today. Firstly, with regard to Senator McLaren's statement, I say that many honourable senators give notice of a question to a Minister. This is a long-established practice in this place and it has been used by honourable senators from both sides of the chamber. There are differences in the types of questions. An honourable senator who wants to play politics-if I can use that term and put some colour into it-can drop a question quickly on to the lap of a Minister. On the other hand, an honourable senator may wish to obtain information and be genuinely seeking information. This matter has been looked at by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. In the past the Standing Orders Committee has not, to my knowledge, raised any objection to this practice .

INTERJECT.PARA: With regard to the Leader of the Government asking that further questions be placed on notice, this also is a long-standing practice of this chamber. Whilst I take on board the point Senator Colston has made, I think this matter should be referred to the Standing Orders Committee if honourable senators wish to do that. It is the responsible Committee of the Senate. If honourable senators want to change practice I think this is something which should go before the Standing Orders Committee.

Other comments were passed. Criticism was expressed about the length of answers given today. I agree with honourable senators that too many answers were too long but I also say that too many questions were also too long. Some questions do require a long answer. I am asking, as I have asked in this chamber before, that all of us co-operate, and that honourable senators keep their questions short so that Ministers can respond in a much shorter time. I suggest that if honourable senators have a long question they should seriously consider putting it on the Notice Paper. Question Time today, in terms of the number of questions dealt with, was the poorest we have had for the session. I keep a record. I sincerely hope Question Time will improve tomorrow when the Senate sits again.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: Political posturing by the Prime Minister overseas which is calculated to deceive the Australian people.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of grave concern to many Australian people, even to Senator Lewis, who attempted to interject and say that the political posturing of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) overseas is typical. I illustrate the point that I seek to make in raising this matter of public importance simply by reminding the Senate that in 1974 Idi Amin offered to the British Government his services as a mediator in its attempts to solve the problems in Ireland. That was received with universal derision. The reason was that Idi Amin was black, he was fat and his own country was in a dreadful mess. The analogy is not perfect. The present Prime Minister is not black, he is not fat but Australia is in a dreadful mess at a time when he is making his third trip during which he is telling the world how to fix its problems and is ignoring problems at home.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has one good thing going for him: He believes that fantasy should be separated from reality. The fantasy is overseas; the reality is here in Australia. This is an embarrassment, I believe, to all Australians. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, sought to excuse that embarrassment at Question Time this morning by saying that the Prime Minister had been invited by President Reagan to go to the United States of America and by suggesting, in the course of answering the same question, that people who criticised this or asked questions about it were somehow disloyal Australians. He should have a look at the opinion polls. Some 58 per cent of the Australian people question the credibility of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. Are they disloyal Australians too? Is that what Senator Sir John Carrick is saying to the people of Australia? Is he saying that we can no longer criticise the stunting of a Prime Minister who struts around the world like a bird of paradise on heat while problems in this country get worse and worse? Is that the attitude of this Government to any criticisms of that situation?

Every time this Prime Minister goes overseas he develops a theme which is faithfully, some would say blindly, recorded by the media representatives who share the luxury of the Boeing 707. Each trip becomes a topic trip. A list of topics is prepared by the Prime Minister's office and is stored away for use when he goes overseas. The latest topic, the so-called world plan for economic recovery, has been greeted in the United States of America with almost a massive silence. The response is almost in theatrical terms: 'Don't call us, Mr Fraser; we'll call you-next time'. Is it any wonder that that sort of response has been given? Last year it was the North-South dialogue that the Prime Minister was proposing as a most important matter for consideration by world statesmen. Of course it is. This year it is the world economy. Earlier still-three trips ago- it was Malcolm Fraser as hero of the Third World, the saviour of Africa.

What people in Australia want to know is not so much where the world is going in respect of these issues, although, of course, that is a legitimate question; what people are increasingly wanting to know is where Australia is going. People listening to the proceedings of the Senate, be they people driving their cars, at work or doing the ironing in an inner suburb of Melbourne, want answers to some very important questions about Australia.
