Is the unemployment level, the highest since the Great Depression, to continue indefinitely or has the Prime Minister, with a world plan which he describes as bold and imaginative, some solution to that question for Australia? Has he some solution to that question for thousands upon thousands of young people who have no prospect of getting a job? Is there now any prospect around the corner, as was being offered by Prime Minister Fraser in 1976 and 1977 when elections were being held? Is there any prospect now of a reversal of the almost negative growth and the incredible increase in poverty in this country? Is there any prospect now that tax avoidance, the ultimate extreme of private enterprise which flourishes in Australia, will be dealt with by the Fraser Government? Is there any propect now of any of these questions being tackled? Is there any vision in this Government for Australia, apart from the phoney visions of the resources boom at the last election, the export led recovery at the election before and so on? Is it any wonder when the Prime Minister talked in New York last night about the weakness of willingness to resist aggression that that is happening in societies such as ours where these sorts of issues prevail?

These public relations exercises of the Prime Minister of Australia do not come on the cheap. Between them the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) have spent $1m in the last year on overseas travel. That is the official figure. It does not include all the extra bits that are added on. It is important, of course, that the Prime Minister should see that the taxpayer is getting his money's worth so there has to be a major topic for every trip. As I said, last year the topic was the North-South dialogue. The tragedy of that exercise by the Prime Minister well illustrates the words of Cardinal Newman who once said that the worst thing that can happen to a good cause is that certain people should embrace it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the phrase of Cardinal Newman was that bad people or evil people should embrace it.
—I do not think so.
—You should quote the phrase properly.
—There is no point in the interjection. Senator Carrick is making some sort of-
—Why did you use the quotation when it has no point?

—Senator Martyr, I was not using the phrase as a quotation. I said that that was what Cardinal Newman said. I am not saying that the Prime Minister is evil. I am saying he is a joke. The point I want to make is quite clear. These pedantic interjections from a Minister who turns Question Time into a sort of school of the air are really ridiculous in the context of this debate. The point I was trying to make is that the effort of the North-South dialogue trip was to project Mr Fraser as a person with genuine concern for the people of the underdeveloped world. It was a very simple invention of his advisers and promoters to soften his image and divert the attention of the Australian voters so that he could set the scene for the multi-million dollar extravaganza of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne. It is all summed up in the words of the music hall song of the 1960s. The North-South dialogue in Mr Fraser's hands could be described as:

SPEECH.PARA: Oh, what a mouth, what a north and south. Blimey what a mouth he's got.

What has happened now to the North-South dialogue in terms of Australian policy? Let us look at the position. How genuine is the Prime Minister about the plight of the Third World? When the Whitlam Government left office the proportion of our gross domestic product devoted to foreign aid was 0.56 per cent. Today it is 0.45 per cent, an increase of 0.03 per cent having been made on the eve of the CHOGM extravaganza in Melbourne to improve the figure. The real level of Australian aid to underdeveloped countries has fallen faster than the level of any other developed country in the Western world. A number of European countries -mostly with democratic socialist governments such as Sweden, the Netherlands, Denmark, France and Norway-have exceeded the figure set by the Brandt Commission and others of 0.7 per cent. Is it any wonder that the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, in talking about the Prime Minister's last extravaganza overseas in a letter to Professor Owen Harries said:

''At some stage . . . developing countries are going to be so impolite as to ask Australia to put its policies where its mouth is . . . unless we can show more 'political will' than has been evident until now (for example, in regard to the dismantling of our high-protection regime) the Australian emperor is going to appear remarkably unclothed.

They were the words of the Secretary to the Treasury about the last trip of the Prime Minister. If we look at the performance in relation to the North-South issues-the trip being over-it will be seen that in relation to the issues raised by the Brandt report Australia has an abysmal record. The record of Australia shows vitually no response and sometimes a negative response in dealing with the six main points of the Brandt report. It is a shoddy record. It demonstrates how cynically the Prime Minister has used a tragic situation in Third World countries for short term political purposes. The fact is that we need an honest, energetic promotion of North-South issues. The Australian Labor Party would support that. But that promotion does not come into this Parliament from this Government. This Parliament is a vehicle for personal aggrandisement, a funkhole for dealing with domestic issues. The North-South dialogue was dropped like a hot potato when the last head of state departed from the CHOGM conference in Melbourne.

The latest gimmick, of course, is the Prime Minister's world-plan. I hope that it goes better than the world car plan. Of course, the Prime Minister has said that his initiative is 'bold, realistic and specific' and 'unexpected, bold and imaginative'. These are the words that he has used about his plan. Nowhere else can one find words which are so favourably couched as a critique of the proposition. It is a plan which is breathtaking in its cynicism. It is a plan which involves a reduction in the levels of protection and the freezing of export incentives followed by the gradual breaking down of trade barriers. The Sydney Morning Herald has rightly called it 'economic motherhood'. Unkindly, it has said that the plan described by Mr Fraser as imaginative is:
. . . imaginative only in the sense that Mr Fraser has been the first person to feel that the obvious is worth stating.

More unkindly that same paper in the same editorial rather querulously suggested that Mr Fraser was the last person to lecture the world powers on this issue. Here is another example with this Prime Minister of conspicuous failure having gone to his head. Overseas he can trumpet about some of these magical formulas to save the world, to save the human race, designed to persuade the seven major powers to change their ways at the forthcoming Versailles conference and so on. The record at home is abysmal.

The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister and his advisers knew when he unveiled this plan in Washington that the decisions about the Versailles summit had alredy been taken. It has been confirmed that the top officials from the seven major powers have completed their final meeting. The communique has already been drafted. All that remains is for the seven heads of State to assemble for a day or two and then release the communique. There has been no undertaking, even from President Reagan, even to mention the so-called Fraser plan at Versailles. As I said before, the response is: 'Don't call us, we'll call you'.

Fraser, of course, will then come back to Australia and say: 'Look, I have tried to get tariffs freed up around the world. I introduced my world plan but they did not appreciate it. But I have no recourse back here in Australia but to cling to present tariff structures'. Any plan by Fraser for world economic development in this context is no more than a sham. The Prime Minister of Singapore has pointed out on repeated occasions as the Secretary to the Treasury has pointed out that it is time to put the money and the policies where the mouth is. Under this Prime Minister and the parade of Ministers since 1975, Australia's economic performance has been much worse than that of most other industrial countries in respect of which our Prime Minister has taken upon himself to tell them that they must put their houses in order.

Our rate of economic growth per head averaged a mere 1.3 per cent a year from 1975 to 1980. The average per capita growth rate for all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, including countries like Ireland, was 2.5 per cent-nearly twice as fast as Australia. This Prime Minister has nothing to teach other countries about economic management. The last figures placed Australia fifteenth out of 24 countries in terms of gross domestic product.

TALK.START.PARA: —And going down.

—And it is going down. In 1976, when the Fraser Government came to office, Australia was eighth on the list. It has dropped from being eighth on the list in 1976 to being fifteenth on the list in 1981 and it is going down quite steadily. It is going down the hit parade all the time. For this Prime Minister to ask for a general lowering of protection is simply to demonstrate his renowned inconsistency. He claims while he is overseas to reduce protection but he is a firm protectionist at home. We are not having a debate on the protection issue in this Parliament. It is probably about time that we did; it is an issue which is studiously avoided in debates in this place. But one cannot posture throughout the world on this issue and have a totally different position at home. One cannot go to countries such as Japan and Korea, which this Prime Minister proposes to do-the unemployment level in Japan is 2 per cent and in Korea it is about 5.2 per cent-countries which have a relatively high rate of economic growth and talk about economic management in terms of the performance we have seen in Australia since this Government came to power. The Prime Minister has said that the message should be taken to Versailles. We have only to look at some of the countries which will be attending that Versailles summit. Of course, the reason why those countries will be represented there and we will not is probably that they have had a much better economic performance in the last five years than has Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that this Prime Minister, because he is trapped in his own rhetoric about propriety, about Australia's not having a tourist for Prime Minister, about his justification for the Boeing 707, feels a need to have a justification for another stunt overseas. The justification this time was whipped up, as happened the last time in the last few days before he went. The Australian Parliament has not even been informed about his plans and is still not being informed about it. But people overseas will get the benefit of the vast wisdom of a Prime Minister of a country with an abysmal record. That is an embarrassment to all Australians. Australians do not believe in people whose conduct is totally inconsistent with their words, whose performance in relation to the problems of this country is neither bold nor imaginative, and who, when overseas,use such rhetoric to justify their own conspicuous consumption and expenditure.

We find in the Senate at Question Time, it is sad to say, a great many honourable senators who are suffering from sheep blast. They cheer on the Leader of the Government in the Senate as he gives absurd answers about the capacity of people to debate and question critically these issues. We can have no base for the restoration of a viable and vigorous economy in Australia and no base for a more equitable society under the continuation of the policies of this Government . The situation in terms of unemployment and social inequity is more and more apparent every day to every Australian who is concerned about where this country is going. While Australians confront this question in their hearts and minds, the Prime Minister is overseas stunting with a world plan, a North-South dialogue plan or a plan to save Africa-any plan but one that deals with the problems which confront him at home. Of course, he is not alone. There will be hardly any Ministers in Australia next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where will you be next week?
—I shall be right here in the Senate.
—No, you will be overseas as from Wednesday.
—Do not tell me where I shall be next week. I shall be right here in the Senate.
—You told me that you would be overseas.

—If the honourable senator would stop telling the Labor Party what it thinks and what it believes and instead mind his own business, which is looking after the Government of this country, then he and the Australian people would be much better off. That is one of the basic problems. At Question Time Senator Sir John Carrick devotes half his time to telling people about the Labor Party. Today, when he rises to make his stock speech, he will go on about the Whitlam Government, not realising that he has been in government for six years and is responsible here for this Prime Minister and for the state of this country. He is responsible for everything that is wrong with this country at present.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —First, my interjection that Senator Button would be overseas arose from information that came both from his office and from a conversation between him and me. If he has changed his mind, he has not informed me of that. Therefore, let me put the record straight for those who want to listen. That was the information that came directly from him to me. Secondly, I repeat what I said at Question Time today. I believe that nowhere in the whole of the Western world, and nowhere under the Westminster system, would occur what has occurred here today-a deliberate attempt by an Opposition to damage, to denigrate and to destroy the goals of an elected Prime Minister of a nation who is seeking to achieve good for this country and for the world at large.

SPEECH.PARA: I put that in no sense of platitude. Of course there can be honest criticism. But let the world judge the situation when the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button, has sought to form a parallel between a murderous, barbarian dictator, Idi Amin, and the Prime Minister of Australia. Does any Australian think it does any credit at all to Senator Button or to the Labor Party that the honourable senator should want to say to the world at large that the offer of ideas to the world by the Prime Minister of Australia is to be regarded in parallel with the offers of a murderous dictator, Idi Amin? That is what we are being offered today in this rhetoric.

Let me put the matter in perspective. The fact is that one would judge from the actions of the Labor Party at Question Time and now, that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), on his own spontaneous initiative has suddenly run around the world wanting to preach to the world. Of course the contrary is true. The fact is that the President of the United States of America issued an invitation to the Prime Minister to come on a specific day, and that invitation was delivered orally and in writing, and in my presence, by the Vice-President of the United States of America, George Bush. It was an invitation to come to America and to have discussions on the great issues before the two summits. Should the Prime Minister not have gone? Should he have said, 'No, I will not go'? Is it not in the interests of the Australian people that he accepted the invitation and went? Should he not have had views on the international scene, both on the question of world peace and on the question of world prosperity? Of course he accepted the invitation, quite rightly, and went.

Where, then, is this posturing? Where, then, is what the Labor Party is saying? The fact is that there are to be two summits in the immediate future, one at Versailles and one at Bonn. It is regarded by the free world that the discussions and the subjects to be raised at those summits will be of pre- eminent significance, of a degree of significance greater than issues that have been faced since World War II, and indeed, on the economic level, greater than issues faced since the 1930s Depression. The world is facing these international problems. The Prime Minister must walk on the world scene and discuss ideas. He knows that the Soviet Union is building up its nuclear weaponry enormously ahead of the United States of America. It is building up its conventional weaponry to something like four times the extent of the free world buildup. The aggression by the Soviet Union around the world is a major threat to peace. It is a threat to peace that the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation recognises, that every country of the free world recognises and one that must therefore be dealt with by the putting forward of ideas. If the Prime Minister of Australia did not put forward his ideas, if he did not represent Australia's hunger to achieve a just peace, a hunger to get disarmament in this world, there would be grave disabilities in what he is doing.

On the world scene at this moment western Europe-member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Develop- ment-is facing an unemployment rate that is double the rate that Australia knows. It is estimated that 30 million people will be unemployed. There is an absolute need for Australia to recognise, both in the true sense of altruism in that we must do something to help and in a fundamental understanding of the situation, that unless there is a restoration of employment in western Europe and the world at large there will be no trading with Australia, there will be a diminution and a recession in Australia. Under these circumstances, is it wrong for the Prime Minister of Australia to respond to the invitation of the American President? Should the Prime Minister have stayed at home? Look at all the emotive wordings used such as the suggestions that he went in a 'luxury 707' and the Press went in a 'luxury 707'. I am not allowed to mention the past activities of Mr Whitlam whose penchant, as we know, was to charter luxury 707s and to look at ancient ruins in Egypt. (Quorum formed).

I want to explain to the people of Australia the device of drawing attention to the state of the House. During Senator Button's speech there was a handful of people in this chamber. Bearing in mind the poor quality of the subject matter, I do not blame people for not attending but it did not occur to the Opposition that he should have an audience. I can understand that, but the members of the public should understand that the purpose of the use of the device of calling a quorum is to try to deny to the speaker on his feet time to put his point, particularly when a salient point is being put. Lest anyone should fail to understand the point I was putting prior to the calling of attention to the state of the House I will repeat my point. Perhaps Senator Colston would again like the embarrassment of having to do the counting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Any senator has the right to draw the attention of the Chair to the state of the House if a quorum is not present.
—There is no point of order.
—Do not waste more time.
—There are pretty sick numbers on your side.
—There are only two members of the Opposition in the chamber now .
— Order!
—I will continue with my point of order, if I may.
—What is your point of order; that there are not enough members on your side?
—When the rabble on the other side stops, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will proceed.
—If the honourable senators will allow Senator Colston to proceed the Chair will be able to judge. I call Senator Colston.
—He has to state the number of the Standing Order.
— Order!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. If a member of this chamber draws your attention to the state of the House that member is quite within his rights under the Standing Orders and he should not be pilloried by somebody on the other side complaining about his time being lost.
—There is no point of order. That is a personal explanation and that should be made at the appropriate time.

—We have now had another demonstration of the use of the device to attempt to force a wasting of time. I now repeat the point that I was making. It was all right for Senator Button to talk, without any grounds at all, of luxury 707s. Does anyone remember at the time of the 1974-75 economic crises in Australia what Mr Whitlam, the Labor leader, in a chartered 707 was doing? He was not giving to the people of the world the benefit of Australia's views; he was studying ancient ruins in Greece. This is the kind of nonsense he went in for. It was wrong grandeur of the type indulged in by the dictators that Senator Button referred to before.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button talked of the North-South dialogue and the fact that there has not been considerable progress on it. I believe the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Australia was accepted by all the nations that attended it as one of the most progressive meetings that has been held by the Commonwealth and indeed one of the most unifying meetings that has taken place in the Commonwealth of Nations. If that is not an achievement, let us hear what is. People should keep in mind when talking about the developing countries, the underprivileged countries, that if living standards in the Western world fall further and further the people who will really suffer, the people who will really be destabilised, will be those in the developing world; that is, the South, the Third World itself. So the dialogue-Senator Button acknowledges this- at the summits which are being held today is vital to the North-South dialogue, vital to the stability of the less privileged of this world.

We are asked to say that Australia itself is worse off than overseas regions. Let us have a look at what is happening in the world. The world economy is in a poor state. Economic growths in industrial countries have slowed since 1973 and have now come to a halt. The OECD projection is 0.3 per cent growth in gross domestic product in 1982. Growth in Australia is still continuing, and still continuing at a very significant rate. Indeed, the latest of the Australian Statistician's figures show that and the latest OECD figures show that. Where then is this comparison? Negative growth in industrial production in the last recorded quarter has been shown in six of the seven major countries-Germany, Japan, Canada, France et cetera. They are countries that Senator Button has said are doing better than we are. He said that we ought to look at them. They have negative growth; we have positive growth. The depth of the recession overseas is illustrated by the experience of the United States. Dwelling commencement in the United States are only 35 per cent to 40 per cent of the level a short period ago and the producing of automobiles is at an annual rate of only 7.5 million compared with 15 million previously. That is the present picture. Our GDP grew at nearly three times the OECD average rate in the last two years, 1980 and 1981 , but we cannot of course be isolated from international standards and trends.

Professor Pollard of Macquarie University, a renowned actuary, has looked at what has been happening in Australia and living standards in Australia. He has analysed the statement by the Labor Party as to whether living standards are rising or declining. He has rejected Mr Hayden's statement and has said that all the indicators are that our living standards are in fact improving while overseas they are in fact worsening.

In regard to defence, the world is in the most perilous period that it has seen since World War II. The one great potential aggressor in the world-the Opposition is never willing to tackle this-is the Soviet Union. That is the one nation against whose integrity there is no threat at all. Who offers a threat to the integrity of the USSR in this world today? Nobody offers a threat against the integrity of the USSR. Nobody is the aggressor against it. Yet the Soviet Union is increasing its nuclear arms massively above those of the United States of America. It is increasing its orthodox defences against other countries. Does the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation offer a threat to the USSR? On the contrary; what has happened is that NATO has been weakening in its defence and its will to constitute defence.

Is our Prime Minister wrong to be saying to the world at large that this poses a great danger? I do not take any comfort from the grins on the faces of members of the Australian Labor Party when we talk about these matters. They are always grinning with smug self-satisfaction in relation to this matter. The fact of the matter is that there is only one threat to the peace of the world today and that is the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union could resolve that tomorrow by putting down its arms, by bringing about an equality with the West and by implementing parallel disarmament. But it is not doing so.

If it is right for the Prime Minister on behalf of Australia to go overseas, to talk about peace and about how to achieve peace, how much more right is it to say that we believe the recession that has come to the Western world must be lifted, that we must work together to get a better psychology in this world towards creating more employment throughout the world so that we can lift up the living standards of the people of the developed and developing countries, and so that we can really have a proper North-South dialogue? How right is it for Australia, which is one of the great trading nations of the world, to put its views? Why should it not put its views? Senator Button was so selective in his editorial reading today that he failed to read the Age newspaper. The newspaper must have been thinking of him because its editorial heading stated: 'Fraser is talking sense'. The editorial went on to describe Senator Button and his party. It states:

Mr Fraser's overseas trip has already triggered the usual manifestations of our national inferiority complex that surface whenever our leaders meet with those of other countries to discuss world problems.

The editorial went on to suggest that a psychologist was needed to test the reasons for this. How is it that the Leader of the Opposition can selectively pick one newspaper editorial when right around Australia the industrialists and the leaders of commerce have praised what Malcolm Fraser is doing? The President of the United States of America has said that this represents a very constructive series of ideas. Here we are now-knock, knock, knock! It is a disgraceful situation of trying to destroy the presentation of Australia's view and of trying to denigrate Australia. The Prime Minister is going to Japan, which is our largest trading partner, essentially to free up the trade of Japan around the world so that there can be a greater flow of trade and a greater creation of jobs. Is it being said that our Prime Minister has no right to talk trade when we are one of the great trading nations on earth? We are the greatest of all in terms of bauxite, alumina, iron ore and food and farming commodities. What has been said by the Opposition constitutes one of the most dastardly presentations in an attempt to destroy a Prime Minister, who was nationally elected, when he responded to a--

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame, shame!

—It is no wonder that the honourable senator calls out: 'Shame, shame!'. A shame it is. The Prime Minister responded to an invitation of the President of the United States of America. He is trying to do something about peace, disarmament and unemployment and all he gets is denigration and an attempt to destroy him. History will show the grave misjudgment of the Australian Labor Party today. History will show that there is no credit to be gained in trying to white-ant or discredit national leaders.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —An ancient political tradition followed by incompetent or corrupt governments entailed diverting public attention. Decadent emperors staged circuses in Rome but with modern technology the circuses can be staged overseas in places such a Washington. A more recent Australian tradition combines self-indulgent ego tripping with the ancient diversion objective. In 1930 Mr Scullin went abroad to be flattered, feted and manipulated by the London money lenders. In 1956 Mr Menzies went up the Nile to deliver to Nasser the ultimatum of the British Empire which was promptly countermanded from Washington. In 1974, as Senator Button said, Idi Amin offered to arbitrate on the dispute in Northern Ireland. In reply to the claim of the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, that Senator Button had equated the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, with Idi Amin, I must say that Senator Button did no such thing. He did, however, point out that they shared common attributes such as self-aggrandisement and self-delusion . At least every year Malcolm Fraser goes abroad and stages a circus to divert Australian attention from the wretched failures of his policies in Australia and , of course, to provide a forum in which he can pose as the global statesman.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest instalment of that saga, which is soon to be terminated completely, is the blueprint for world recovery which the Prime Minister modestly described as unexpected, bold and imaginative. It has been suggested in newspaper editorials that self-praise invites ridicule-it received it-and that it is presumptuous for the Prime Minister of a minor nation to hector and harangue major economic powers. However that may be, it is certainly presumptuous for a leader with as dismal a record as an economic manager as has Malcolm Fraser to pontificate to his betters. In the class of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development Malcolm Fraser is a dunce. Well, the dunce has now promoted himself to lecturer.

If we look at the record since the Australian economy has been under the control of Malcolm Fraser, we will find that on vital economic indicators, such as unemployment rates, in the four calendar years from 1977 to 1980 inclusive unemployment in Australia averaged 6 per cent. In the OECD as a whole it averaged 5.3 per cent. Incidentally, when Malcolm Fraser gained control of the Australian economy the unemployment rate was lower in Australia than in the OECD as a whole. It was 4.7 per cent and 4.8 per cent in 1975 and 1976. In the OECD as a whole it was 5.1 per cent and 5.2 per cent. The Prime Minister took our unemployment rate from below that of the OECD average and maintained it at above the OECD average. Individual countries in the OECD, such as Japan, to which Malcolm Fraser now has the presumption to lecture, have maintained an unemployment rate through those four years-1977 to 1980-at an average of 2.1 per cent. Malcolm Fraser's Government has achieved 6 per cent, yet he is now lecturing the Japanese on economic management.

In regard to economic growth, we have precisely the same story; although the details vary, the story and the conclusions do not. I cite the comparative positions of Japan and Australia. In those five years Australia's real growth in gross domestic product averaged 2.3 per cent. In Japan it averaged 5.1 per cent, yet Malcolm Fraser has the audacity, the effrontery to lecture the Japanese on economic management. It is correct, as Senator Sir John Carrick has said- although he did not bother to add the qualification-that in the last 12 months or possibly even 18 months Australia, compared to the performance of the OECD as a whole, has done relatively well. It has still not done well compared to the leaders among OECD countries, but in the last 12 months it has done relatively well because of the passing phenomenon of a half-baked resources boom which, as even this Government now recognises, is about to lose its influence on investment and economic growth. That short term advantage, which Australia has enjoyed for reasons exogenous to it, is about to be terminated. The strident rhetoric and extravagant self-praise of Malcolm Fraser cannot disguise the fact that, as he would put it in a different context, the runs are on the board and his score is low.

We are told that this blueprint for economic recovery is only 10 days old. Those who are familiar with the Fraser style of policy making are not likely to be surprised by that. Those who looked at the contradictions in the 18 May statement were probably surprised that it spent as long as 10 days in the incubator. They would not be surprised if it had come straight off the top of the Prime Minister's head, or straight from a Channel 7 cosmetician, as have other Fraser bold and imaginative economic initiatives. Our Prime Minister has the presumption to lecture people who have managed the economies of Japan, Austria, The Netherlands, West Germany, Norway and Sweden-all of which are democratic countries-on how they should manage their economies. He has the presumption to lecture the OECD as a whole. Certainly it is presumptuous to do that. It may not be presumptuous to lecture the American President or the British Prime Minister who, arguably, are the only two non-banana republic leaders in the world who are more ignorant of economic questions than is Malcolm Fraser. It leads to some fascinating speculation. Will Mr Fraser be explaining to President Reagan that a national budget is just like a household budget; that if in one year you run a deficit it has to be paid back? Will he be telling Mr Reagan that the $100 billion deficit which the Reagan Administration plans to run up this year will have to come out of Nancy's housekeeping allowance in future? Of course, the United States Press is not as ignorant as is the incumbent of the White House on these questions. As was reported today in the Australian Financial Review, it showed excellent judgment in its response to Mr Fraser's bold, unexpected and imaginative blueprint for world economic recovery.

We are told that an Australian journalist asked Mr Reagan a question at a photography session and that that incident rated a box story on page 10 of the Washington Post, which otherwise ignored Mr Fraser's visit. Not only was it not on the front page of the Washington Post; it was not in the Washington Post at all. That newspaper ignored the visit and our Prime Minister's blueprint for economic recovery. In that regard at least, the Washington Post certainly showed good judgment.
The Prime Minister's statement raises contradictions and leaves unanswered certain questions. For example, it includes the following proposal:

. . . that there be a commitment to significant and progressively implemented reductions in all forms of protection, in accordance with a set formula to be determined through the mechanisms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade . . .

I repeat, 'reductions in all forms of protection'. How does the Prime Minister propose to reconcile that bold, imaginative initiative with the unconditional promise given to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry of Australia, that its level of protection would not be reduced for seven years? If he expects anybody to take the statement seriously-and I am not sure whether anybody does, although Senator Carrick feels obliged to purport to do so-that is one of the questions that he will be obliged to answer. If that proposal is to be taken seriously, the Government is contemplating reducing the protection for that industry, reducing the protection for the motor vehicle industry, even reducing protection for tobacco growers-I repeat, if the statement is to be taken seriously. Just what does it mean? What is the Government's policy? Is it contemplating reducing protection for those industries and repudiating yet another promise?

Of course, the Prime Minister's world overview is not restricted to economic questions. He is also a guru on international conflict, defence and foreign policy. He has denounced the 'short-sighted competitive scramble to provide one' s adversary with the means to continue investing in war', which is Fraser-speak for trading with the Russians. Does that mean that Nareen wool will no longer be shipped to the Soviet Union as it has been, as it was last year or the year before, and probably the year before that? Does it mean that Nareen wool will no longer be helping the Red Army to fight the Afghan chill? The Australian Wheat Board, in its 'Wheat Australia' publication of February of this year, proudly announced on the front page: 'The USSR buys another million tons of Australian wheat, the second million ton sale in this year'. That wheat, I might add, was for the first time ever sold on terms, on time payment, not for cash. Does the Prime Minister's denunciation of those who trade with the Russians mean that the Australian Government is about to terminate that trade or interfere with it in any meaningful way? Of course, the Government's policy towards trade with the Soviet Union has not been quite clear since January 1980. Contradictory statements by various Ministers are on the record, but what was supposed to be the definitive statement on the Government's attitude concerning trade with the Soviet Union was put to me in a letter from Mr Anthony of 23 September last year , in which he said:
. . . the Government's policy has been, and remains, that normal trade and commercial dealings between Australia and the Soviet Union may continue.

Has the Government signalled an intention in the Prime Minister's statement that that policy is about to be drastically changed? If he has not signalled such an intention, what has he signalled? What is he saying? Why is he travelling abroad and making a series of silly statements unless it is to divert public attention from the mess he has made of the Australian economy and of our social institutions?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this matter of public importance. I remind the Senate that we are discussing what is called the ' political posturing by the Prime Minister overseas which is calculated to deceive the Australian people'. In Senator Button and Senator Walsh, Opposition senators have today again continued their tirade against the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and their general denigration of the leadership which he and other leaders in this country have given in an international area. I am one who takes the view that Australia has every right to be heard, as a relatively small or middle power but one with a reasonable economic past and future and as one of the rare democracies in the world which, therefore, has every right to speak on questions of human liberty. It has every right, through its leaders, to go to the United States of America and other nations and to express its views on the economic problems which face the West, questions of disarmament and the important matters which the Prime Minister is pursuing today in the United States. It ill becomes the leaders and members of the Australian Labor Party here today to try to denigrate the actions of the Prime Minister by calling them political posturings. We know that what the Prime Minister is saying represents the feelings of the great majority of Australian people. What he is doing is not a matter of posturing but of expanding the policies which he has expressed over a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Button had the temerity to criticise the Prime Minister's policies and actions in regard to Africa and in regard to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The CHOGM conference will remain one of the most significant actions of the Prime Minister. The people who came to it as leaders of their nations expressed their considerable support and appreciation of Australia's initiatives in the world, particularly in regard to racial matters. There is no doubt that Malcolm Fraser has led in that area. There is no doubt that in recent years he has taken very considerable political risks in the world. I refer particularly to the agreement at Lusaka and the very strong high profile which he took which led ultimately to a solution, to democratic elections and to the installation of the Mugabe Government in Zimbabwe. Of course, there were critics in Australia and elsewhere. There were people who said that we should play safe and not be involved. But we were involved and it is to our credit.

As the Senate knows, in recent weeks I have been in Africa. I spent a month there. I had the opportunity to look at Nigeria, Kenya, Zimbabwe and South Africa. I came back with a number of conclusions, many of which I will explain in articles which I am presently writing. Today I want to speak particularly about this area because if there is one thing that can be said, it is that the Prime Minister was not posturing and has not been posturing in the strong views he has taken on racial matters and on matters of concern to Africa generally. His policies there have been an undoubted success; I had the opportunity to see the results in my recent visit. In Zimbabwe, the results of the compromises reached and the elections are that, after two years, the Mugabe Government is doing very well. There is a very considerable recovery in economic affairs in that country. There is a great deal more confidence in the country. The considerable outflow of some people who could not face up to black rule has now dwindled to a very small number.

While I was there I had the opportunity of talking to many of the Ministers of the Mugabe Government and to people who are friendly critics of that Government. They pointed out that there are some difficulties which will always be experienced with a government in which the Ministers may talk too much of socialism when they mean something quite different from what the Americans might think socialism means. Some people believe there is a danger that Zimbabwe will not attract back sufficient capital for the restoration of economic health in that country. But even with those criticisms, there was overwhelming support for the initiatives which the present Government in Zimbabwe is undertaking. From our point of view, what is even more important is that the initiatives which the Australian Government has expressed, not only in its support of the country at the time of independence but also in its practical assistance, are the very opposite of posturing. It is that assistance which is helping to make Zimbabwe's economy successful.

I will detail three things which were said to me time and again by people in Zimbabwe in relation to our assistance to them. In the first place, I refer to our assistance in the provision of considerable quantities of tents and other equipment when the armies were being integrated. It was very important that that help was given at the time that it was needed and it was greatly appreciated by the Zimbabwe Government. Altogether, some $20m in aid is being given by Australia to the Zimbabwe Government. The most important part of that aid is in the form of assistance by specialists and experts from Australia. For example, we have sent many teachers who were in active operation in Australia and who are now working in the education system of Zimbabwe. Not only Ministers, but also ordinary people in the street and headmasters of schools that I met, spoke glowingly of the work being done by young Australian teachers in Zimbabwe who are great ambassadors for this country. Of course, Zimbabwe would like more teachers. Our teachers are very valuable in helping to train the half-trained teachers who at the moment have to cope with the growing school population in Zimbabwe. That factor came up time and again as one of the best ways in which we can help. Likewise in the field of agriculture, we have sponsored veterinary scientists to go and work in that country. I returned with suggestions that were made to me of practical further ways in which we can assist the recovery of the economy of Zimbabwe.

I had the opportunity of being, I think, the first foreign politician to enter Harare, the new name for Salisbury, and to be at the celebrations of the second anniversary of independence and of the change of name to Harare. At the celebrations in that beautiful city I had the opportunity to meet a great number of the country's leaders, including white leaders in the community and some who have joined the Government recently as white members of parliament. In fact, the Government has been very sensible in the expansion of its ranks to include members of Mr Nkomo's party and white men who do not hold the same views as Mr Smith. Those people are collaborating very successfully with the Government. The situation in Zimbabwe results from an initiative in which the Prime Minister can take a great deal of personal pride; it is one which is continuing to this day. I hope that any Australian who visits Zimbabwe-I think many more will if Qantas Airways Ltd takes its planes to Zimbabwe later this year-will enjoy the beauty of Zimbabwe and help it on its road to recovery. As Australians, we can be proud of a real record in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —How was your time in South Africa?

—Thank you, Senator, I am turning to South Africa. I spent a fortnight in South Africa and I can detail a few things about that visit. I will be saying a lot more in the writings which I intend to do. South Africa is another area where the Prime Minister has for many years, despite criticisms- sometimes from the Government side-made absolutely clear his loathing of apartheid and all it stands for, of his objection to the terrible injustices which I was able to observe in South Africa. I can assure the Senate that I returned from South Africa reinforced in the views that I left here with and with many facts which indicate the basic inhumanity of life in South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: South Africa is a very successful, powerful country. Its success is based very largely on the backs of black, coloured and Indian labour. Even the present attempt to change the political situation slightly by giving the coloureds and Indians a form of voting right is not confusing them because they are fearful that they will be seen as the frontline fighters for white South Africa. I asked the Vice President of South Africa and other Nationalist Party members at a luncheon whether they wanted to hand on to their successors, their children, a country based upon a strong hold on defence-'us against the rest of Africa'-or whether they would become the dynamo of the economy of Africa and be seen openly to be helping the rest of Africa. They tended to agree that the latter was what they must do. But I think that, if we, with other countries, do not bring pressures to bear on South Africa, we will not see it advance along that line.

Some small advances are being made. There are advances in the labour laws which now enable black labour to be heard. But at the same time, in the last year, 22 black leaders were either imprisoned or banned, more than ever before. In other words, while they are getting greater powers and greater economic strength they are being victimised even more by the security forces. As I say, we must, I think, continue with the policies which Malcolm Fraser has expounded and espoused for years. I had the opportunity of lunching with Chief Gatsha Buthelezi and his Cabinet in Ulundi. They, of course, are the leaders of 5 1/2 million Zulus. His main advice to me was that the Australian Government should continue to put pressure on the South African Government. Chief Buthelezi is putting pressure on it. He is not prepared to sell his South African birthright. He is not prepared to set up a homeland consisting of 42 separate pieces of land around Durban and elsewhere. He and courageous white South Africans are not prepared to accept the fact that they will need passports and so forth to go to those areas. Chief Buthelezi is not prepared to abandon South African citizenship. He and many other black leaders, coloured leaders and Asian leaders are forthright critics of the Government. I hope that we will soon see him in Australia because he is a man of considerable world prestige and one to whom it will be very helpful for Australians to speak.

Australia is very well represented in South Africa, as in Zimbabwe, by our ambassadors-Jeremy Hearder the Ambassador in Zimbabwe, and Ambassador Malcolm Lyon and John Graves, the trade commissioner, in Johannesburg. I believe that they are doing an excellent job for Australia. We are making some contribution to libraries in South Africa from small funds which are available to the Ambassador. We are making it clear where our sympathies lie and what we say South Africa ought to do to recover its place in the world as a decent democracy . There are great South Africans such as Helen Suzman whom I met and the Mayor of Durban, Chief Buthelezi, Dr Motlana and many others, who are fighting a great battle. We have helped with that. The Prime Minister has been in the forthright position of standing full square to ensure that South Africa is told time and time again what it does not want to believe, that the West will not come to its rescue, that we are not entirely interested in its point of view and the preservation of the white race in South Africa. South Africans must realise the danger of their position if they are going to change.

My general thought in regard to South Africa is that the Prime Minister has therefore been a leader in this world and not, in any way, a posturer. Because we have heard such nonsense today and because we do not want the embarrassment of the Opposition going any further with it, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Inquiry into Effects of Herbicides on Vietnam Veterans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment into the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1981, the Senate referred the following matter to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment for inquiry and report:

SPEECH.PARA: The use of pesticides, particularly phenoxy chemicals and chemicals containing dioxin with reference to:
(a) their ecological effects; and
(b) their effects on human and animal health;
and that in considering this matter the Committee deal first with the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides.

Since the commencement of the inquiry, the Committee has taken more than 1,750 pages of evidence over six days of public hearings. Evidence has been taken from 27 witnesses, 10 witnesses having been heard twice. Further evidence will be taken on Tuesday, 25 May in Canberra. At the same time the Committee's secretariat and advisers have collected vast amounts of background material, largely from overseas published literature.

When moving that this matter be referred to the Committee on 16 September 1981, I noted that it was of immediate concern to Vietnam veterans. Consequently, the Committee has been concentrating its efforts on this aspect of the reference. At the time I informed the Senate that the Committee intended to report by 30 June 1982. However, due to the volume of material before the Committee that needs to be thoroughly assessed, and also because the Committee believes that the report should be tabled while the Senate is sitting, it is now intended that the report relating to the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides will be tabled early in the Budget session. After completing this aspect of the inquiry, the Committee will examine the use of pesticides in Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference to Standing Committee on Public Works

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:
Replacement of operating theatres and refurbishment of surgical wards at the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park.
I am moving this motion at the request of the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) who has provided the following statement for the information of honourable senators:

The proposal comprises the provision of 116 surgical beds to modern hospital standards, the replacement of existing sub-standard operating theatres by four new operating suites, and the demolition of some existing sub-standard timber framed buildings to facilitate siting of the theatre building as required. The facilities to be provided will be located at the existing Repatriation General Hospital complex at Daw Park, South Australia. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $6.5m at April 1982 prices.
I table plans of the proposed work as provided by the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981 [No. 2 ] (1982)
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
Second Readings
Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 [No. 2] (1982), the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill 1981 [No. 2] (1982) seek to reimpose upon a small minority of tertiary students a fee which would be a proportion of the cost of their recurrent study; that is, less than one-fifth of the recurrent cost of taking a second degree or a post-graduate degree. In no way would first degree students and first diploma students in universities and colleges be affected by this legislation but post-graduate students who do not gain a Commonwealth post-graduate award, which is awarded on the basis of academic competition and academic merit, a university research grant or an industry or other private benefaction scholarship would be required to make a part contribution towards the recurrent cost of the studies they undertake.

SPEECH.PARA: I said yesterday in this debate that the Opposition's case in opposing these three Bills was based almost entirely on the argument that they would restrict access to tertiary study in Australia. I seek to refute that argument on the basis that any matriculating student in Australia may, without any impediment, enrol in a university or a college without having to pay any fees for that academic tuition. No first degree student will be affected in any way by these Bills. Someone who wants to take on a second degree at the taxpayers' expense or who wants, after competing for the scholarships that are available in Australia, to continue with their own interests in post-graduate study, would, as proposed by these three Bills, be required to make a part contribution.
I therefore believe that the argument that these Bills will restrict students with academic ability from taking up their courses of study to be not substantial at all.

The other argument, that the Bills will restrict students from low income families from taking up their studies, also falls flat because there are Commonwealth-provided scholarships and living allowances for post-graduate study . I happen to think that the allowances have slipped away with inflation and that the Government should, in the Budget context, give very real consideration- in fact top priority consideration-to the Commonwealth post-graduate basic living allowance being raised from its present level of about $4,500 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would that be your top priority?

—It is my top priority in my own submissions to the Government and, if I may say so, as chairman of the back bench committee of Government members on education and the arts. The Commonwealth post-graduate award is intended to be an adequate living allowance to help a post-graduate student undertake a course of study, in the most part leading to a doctor of philosophy degree. The university research grants and other scholarships available are of a like nature. There is one other aspect to which I draw attention and it is that the Commonwealth post-graduate award is taxable. One third of the part time earnings of a CPGA holder is taken in tax, but holders of other scholarships- university grants, for example-are not subject to tax. I believe that that invidious difference should be resolved so that all post-graduate students are treated alike.

SPEECH.PARA: My argument at the moment is with regard to access to post-graduate study. Talented students can gain post-graduate awards and other scholarships. If we are not producing enough post-graduate students with, say, degrees in engineering, applied sciences, education or humanities, the argument should be that we increase the number of post-graduate awards. Under this Government the number of new awards a year was increased from 700 to 800. I believe the Government should consider increasing that number. In passing, I refer to the particular problem of engineering post-graduate students. At the moment only 17 of the 800 new CPGA awardees are undertaking post-graduate engineering research. Some years ago more than 100 of the 800 awardees were doing so. There is a critical need in Australia for engineers with post-graduate research experience.

Senator Macklin referred yesterday to developments in the aluminium industry in Queensland. I interjected and asked him for an example of how we are not sufficiently equipping young people in Australia with the skills we require. I think his own example is only partly relevant here. The increasing level of real grants that the Australian Government has made to technical and further education and apprenticeships, including technical engineering, indicates its resolve to make resources available to meet the need. But we have a particular problem with regard to university engineering and technology graduates going on to post-graduate study. Here the problem is that there is such a need for their skills in the work place that merely as graduates they can earn salaries of $18, 000 to $20,000 in their first year of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—Right now. That means that they are enormously tempted, even if they are academically able, to take up employment on graduation rather than, even with their first class degree, go on to post-graduate study of very real value to them and to the nation. The problem is that, while the Commonwealth post-graduate award is only $4,500 and they can gain, in any event, some research experience in their places of employment in one of the growing industries in Australia, the manpower needs of Australia are taking those graduates away. I believe that this problem will be partly met by increasing to a much more realistic and rewarding amount the living allowance to which all post-graduate students are entitled. I believe that we ought to give special consideration to areas of research need that are not being fully met at the moment. Perhaps some special provision for, say, engineering students would help to meet the need but I do not want to deny in any way the very real increases in resources being made available to apprenticeships and other areas of TAFE. In fact at the moment there are more apprentices in training than ever before in Australia's history. I think that achievement is evidence of the Government's real recognition of the need for skilled tradespersons and skilled technicians to meet our manpower requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the question of access, these fees will be applied to students of lesser academic merit than those who have gained scholarships competitively with them. To a large extent they will be applied to middle aged spouses who have every right to have an interest in some area of academic study and to help themselves, Australia and that area of discipline by the research that they do. But these programs do not have the same urgency or the same priority as those research programs which are funded by scholarships and awards. When we compare the access that all members of the Australian community have to technical and further education, we see that there is a real anomaly in the present situation.

If my wife, for example, wants to study Chinese language or Chinese studies or Japanese language or Japanese studies and she enrols in a course at a TAFE institution she will have to pay a fee. It is a requirement of the State Government-based TAFE institutions, even though they receive very substantial Commonwealth support, that fees are payable with regard to not only elective study but also serious study at a TAFE institution. But if my wife, for example, wants to take those same studies but in more full time capacity she can presently enrol at a university as a graduate and she does not have to pay any fees at all. Sometimes she will have a better language laboratory made available to her. She will have an array of staff made available to her. Of course, according to the enrolments, there is an expectation of the university applying staff to an area. Without any cost, useful but somewhat elective research studies and second degree studies can be undertaken by Australians. They will not have to pay any fees if they are enrolled in a university or a college but if they are enrolled in a TAFE institution a fee is payable.

The burden of the Government's argument in response to the findings of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which is embodied in these three Bills, is that it is appropriate that persons who already have a degree which the taxpayer has funded, who are going on to do a second degree or who already have a degree and who have competed for a research post-graduate award and failed, but go on with that study, should make some contribution to the recurrent cost of the course they are undertaking. The contribution is up to $1,000 a year for a full time, enrolled, second degree or post-graduate student. The recurrent cost of a course of study in a university or college these days is between $5,000 and $6,000 a year. A person would be required to pay less than a fifth of the recurrent cost. That is not taking into account the part value of the capital that has been put into the universities and colleges over the last century or so.

So the question is not one of access. It is not a matter of denying access to students of talent nor is it denying members of families at any income level, including those at low income level, access to tertiary education. If it were it would be thrown out entirely at a very early stage in the Government's formulations. That is to say: What should the taxpayer bear? Should the taxpayer entirely fund these more marginal and lesser priority activities of adult Australians in taking second degrees and some research studies largely part time and largely not leading to a Ph.D. or a serious research degree? The question of access, which is the whole thrust of the Opposition's attack on these Bills, I believe, falls flat.

In any event, when fees in universities and colleges were abolished in 1973 it was the expectation of many in this chamber-certainly it was my expectation and my hope-that in the years following 1973 there would be a much broader spectrum of Australians entering tertiary study. It was certainly my hope that increasing numbers of students from low income families would enrol in our universities and colleges. But what is the evidence? What is the finding? The finding by Dr Anderson of the Australian National University and also by a direct study of this matter done by the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee is that there has not been any significant change in the profile of students enrolling in our universities and colleges. I do not like that finding. I do not like the conclusion.

But that conclusion will not be addressed by opposing these Bills. It will be met by looking at 14 year-old, 15 year-old and 16 year-old students in high schools and making sure that they have put before them encouragements to consider going on to do tertiary study and that they are not dissuaded by family , peer group or their own lack of full momentum from considering the option of a professional course of study for a degree or the awards given in our colleges of advanced education. The matter of access will not be met by trumpetings against these Bills from the Opposition which fall flat in this debate. The question of access which should be addressed by honourable senators on all sides concerns students in their teens being given encouragement to be prepared to go on to complete their matriculation and other requisites for a course of tertiary study . It is my hope that by these sorts of encouragement being given in our high schools we may see a change in the profile of enrolments and the giving of much broader access to students.

I reiterate that nothing in these Bills applies a fee to any first course of study. In essence the question raised in these Bills is this: Should the taxpayers of Australia not only pay the $2 billion for tertiary study that the Commonwealth provides and the $1 billion which is provided through the Schools Commission supplementing the billions of dollars applied from the States, but also in addition bear the full cost of recurrent study by, in the main, adult Australians who are taking on a second course of study or after missing out on a post-graduate degree, going on with some area of post-graduate study anyway? The finding of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee prior to April last year was that in the light of restraint on government spending and on liberally spending taxpayers' money this is an area of attention in which the user pays principle has some bearing and in which about a fifth of the recurrent cost could be borne by the students involved.

The legislation as it applies to universities generally in the States or to the ANU and the Canberra College of Advanced Education seeks to apply fees to that small proportion of students. There is a limit on the fees of $1,000 in any one year. There is a limit in that the fees can never be applied to a first degree student and the fees cannot be applied to overseas students who are already required to make a contribution by way of a visa fee. There are also indications in the Bills that the Minister for Education will prescribe approved combined courses for which students will not be liable to pay fees. It is well known that some Bachelor of Arts students take on a second degree in law and that this is a combined course of study. Arts students and science students may also take a diploma in education and this is an approved combined course. There is no way in which this legislation will levy fees on that second aspect of the combined degree.

With regard to a number of specialised courses in which I have had a special interest, I have been very glad to see, from the Minister's circulated indication of the approved combined courses for these purposes, that there are such things as special education diplomas. Teachers who already have a degree and a diploma in education will be able to take on a course of study in special education, for which there is a real community need, without any such penalty to themselves. I believe there is not sufficient awareness in the Opposition that the Government's intention of serving the taxpayers of Australia is at the crux of these Bills. Whenever governments are reviewing programs, such as in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, they ought to have foremost in mind that the money that is being applied to programs is not their own money; it is money being used on behalf of taxpayers. That is the matter that is at issue in these Bills. Senator Macklin at one stage in his speech implied that some Government senators might argue that this part payment of fees would give some moral uplift to the payers of the fees. That is not an argument I have ever entertained. It is not an argument that the Government puts forward. It is a hypothesis that perhaps Senator Macklin has raised. It has no home on the Government benches. No Government senator would be so patronising as to argue that these Bills have anything to do with moral uplift.

I conclude by saying that the fuller account of the arguments in favour of this legislation was very clearly put forward by Ministers and other Government senators during the October debate on these issues. I hope that the brief summary of them that I have been able to give in this debate will commend the Bills to honourable senators and that after this second consideration of the Bills they will be approved by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague first for his clarity and care and the comprehensive way in which he has discussed the three Bills before the Senate.
—Stop back-scratching and get on with it.

—I suggest to Senator Georges that he does not want me to go through the entire argument again. The three Bills have been discussed in this place and the other place on three previous occasions. This is the fourth time the debate has occurred. The arguments have been well rehearsed, are well understood and are well known. It is not necessary for me to review the arguments in detail. I thank Senator Teague for the way he has set out the Government's position with the clarity which he brought to his contribution. Anyone listening to the debate might have been excused for thinking that the Government is about to bring in some draconian measure. It has been made quite clear that this is not the case. It is not true that this is the first step towards the introduction of fees for all tertiary students. The Government has no such intention. We have no intention that there should be fees for students who are taking first degrees.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the Senate makes it clear that what is proposed excludes undergraduates or first degree students. I regret that the Australian Labor Party, in particular, has chosen to muddy the waters rather than concentrate on the effects of the Bills, which have been set out by my colleague. The Bills are a result of the considerations of the Committee on Review of Commonwealth Functions. They do provide for a very limited reintroduction of fees for the kinds of students mentioned and elucidated by Senator Teague. The Bills will have no retrospective effect. They will not pick up people who are already enrolled. It would be the intention of the Government to introduce additional legislation to exempt students already enrolled for courses in 1982 from paying fees. Therefore there is no question of those who are already enrolled being picked up. The fees proposed are not large. They are modest and they are modest as a proportion of the cost actually incurred on behalf of the students.

The effect of these Bills will not be to deny students access to education. Those who are undertaking subsequent degrees or studies will be asked to make some small contribution to the costs which are involved in the study they are doing. The Government is committed to increasing and improving access to education for all people, not just the wealthy. We are also committed to a belief that education is the key to our future national prosperity. Our programs are designed to these ends. We are committed to quality of education and we are committed to good educational outcomes. It is the question of educational outcomes which particularly attracts me. These principles are not at stake in the legislation and it is wrong for anyone to suggest that they are or to paint the legislation in those terms. We intend to monitor the effects of the legislation and to correct any negative consequences which might emerge.

There has been much made of possible effects upon research as a result of this legislation. That is based upon a most unusual reading of the place of research or the structure of research in our tertiary institutions, or the contribution to that research made by way of students not having to pay tuition fees. It is a very tortuous argument. It does not apply to most students doing research. It does not apply to those in receipt of Commonwealth post-graduate awards. It does not apply to those who are in receipt of university research grants or private industry awards of any significant amount. Those who do receive those awards would not be denied access to an opportunity to do their research. Nor would the capacity of those who are presently tenured in universities, colleges or other institutions be affected because they are already able to do research as part of their normal daily activities.

The Government is committed to furthering research generally in tertiary institutions. We believe the money spent on research-I pick up a point which, I think, Senator Macklin made in his contribution last night-will be returned to us many times over. It will be returned to a wider community in a large number of benefits as a result of that research. We understand that and we do support it. I make the point that in the last nine or 10 years-most of it during the term of this Government-the number of identified research workers in universities has increased from about 14,500 to about 18,500. The amount of research support has been significant. It has been increasing and it has been possible to increase the number of people undertaking this activity.

The debate throughout on these Bills has tended to range widely. Many people have concentrated on matters which are not at issue in the legislation proposed today. There have been attempts to exaggerate the supposed negative aspects of this package of Bills. However those contributions which have addressed themselves to issues of access, quality and outcomes-wherever those contributions have come from-have been extremely welcome. I mention again my two colleagues, Senator Teague and Senator Macklin. The extent to which their contributions have addressed themselves to issues in education will be examined. I will do my best to determine whether it is possible to respond on merit to those proposals because I believe they were put forward in good faith.

Having said that, the issue before the Senate is quite clear. The Bills have been discussed many times. The Senate is quite clear on what the issues are. I understand the intentions which have been indicated by the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independent as to how they will vote. I understand the reality of numbers. I think it will be a pity if this legislation is rejected but at this stage I think it proper to put it to the test. Therefore I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan Bill currently before the Senate authorises the Government to borrow moneys technically for defence purposes. Normally all expenditure is funded from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or from Loan Council Funds. The additional avenue of funding government expenditure available-that is, the Loan Bill before the Senate-is the third source of government funding. If revenue available from the general loan fund and from the Consolidated Revenue Fund is inadequate the Government may resort to a loan Bill of this type, borrowing moneys, as I said, to fund expenditure technically for defence purposes. I think it is fair to say that the reason the Government is introducing this Bill now is that the Budget deficit will be substantially greater-I do not know whether I should say than was anticipated or was admitted to-than when the Budget was brought down in August last year. This is so because revenue is lower than had been projected and expenditure is higher and as a result the likely total overall budget deficit is likely to rise from the projected $146m to something over $1,000m.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that that has happened is indicative either of unforeseen or unforeseeable circumstances or perhaps, I suppose, given the precedent of 1977, some people may say it is due to rubbery figures-to a falsification such as we witnessed in 1977-of estimates for political purposes. Whether or not that is so , there is nothing sinister about the procedure itself being adopted by the Government of the passage of loan Bills through the Parliament to fund government expenditure if the conventional sources-that is, the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the general loan fund-are inadequate for government needs. That was not the view expressed by Senator Carrick on behalf of the then Opposition in 1975 when he spoke on an identical Bill. This speech is found on page 879 of the Hansard of 1 October 1975. Senator Carrick said:

. . . the Senate is debating the Loan Bill 1975. It is not, as the Government would like to have us believe, a minor machinery matter. It is a vital part of the overall strategy of the Federal Budget, and the testing of this Bill is a primary testing of the authenticity or the validity of the Budget itself.

That, of course, is palpable nonsense. It was palpable nonsense at the time it was stated. It still would be palpable nonsense to state it. The Opposition, of course, takes a rational view of the reason for this Bill being introduced. Given that it is required to fund inaccurate projections of revenue and expenditure in the Budget, the procedure itself is neither sinister nor improper . The Government will ultimately be called to account for its overall fiscal and monetary management, but there is no reason to oppose this legislation. The Opposition will not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Loan Bills are a technical device which Treasurers of governments of political parties represented on both sides of the House have used to perform a pea and shell trick designed to bypass the Australian Loan Council. By presenting a loan Bill, allegedly for defence purposes, the Government can circumvent the Loan Council since the money is for a specific purpose and that does not fall within the ambit of the Loan Council. By paying for defence expenditure with moneys from the Loan Bill other revenue can be diverted for non-defence purposes. Basically, the Bill is a short term measure to stop the Government going broke at a time when tax revenue is not coming in at a sufficiently fast rate. Since we are not in the business of bringing down governments we will not oppose this Bill.
