The Bill is, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) noted in another place, a loan Bill requesting an unusually small amount-a ceiling of $300m. As the honourable member noted, it is brought forward unusually late in the financial year. I can only speculate on the reasons for both, but taken together they suggest that the Government is not as strapped for cash as it has been pretending it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take the opportunity to make a few remarks about this Government's financial management. The first and most salutary lesson for the Government was that its provisions in the Budget for salary increases were clearly inadequate. The Government has claimed that salaries and wages rose faster than it predicted . If this is true the predicators of the Budget must be severely castigated. We believe that it was quite obvious, even on Budget night, that the provision of only $100m for salary increases for members of the defence forces was inadequate and that the figure should have been $240m based on the consumer price index and the work value rises related to trade awards.

The Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) again blamed the revenue shortfall on two things-a drop in crude oil excise caused by industrial disputes and the rejection of the proposed sales tax legislation. Interestingly, the Minister ascribed this rejection to 'another place'. I do not know whether this was a Freudian slip and whether she would, in fact, prefer to be in another place but it is the Senate that she now graces and it was the Senate that rejected the outrageous proposed imposition of sales tax on the necessities of life. I remind the Minister that if the Government had agreed to split the sales tax Bills, as we proposed, the cost of the Senate's action would have been only $37m and not the $53m that the Minister herself is on record as saying was involved-a difference of $16m. We nevertheless sympathise with the Government to some degree, even though much of the dilemma that it now finds itself in is of its own making. In recent months the Government has, in fact, had to make a number of tough decisions on expensive defence equipment. Although we do not necessarily agree with some of these decisions, we recognise that the Government has had to face very difficult choices.

Most of all, we call on the Government to bite the bullet in devising some new method of wage fixation. It could well be that with a little imagination the Government could come up with a proposal for wage fixation which would be a very considerable advance on anything that we have seen before. Whatever comes up, there has to be recognition of direct bargaining since there is no way that the unions will forgo this right. This surely has to be related to some sort of written agreement with the unions for industrial peace for a fixed period. This will require varying the role of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission so that some sort of social compact can be arrived at. Such a compact should include effective price control. It should include also some degree of wage indexation and flexibility for productivity-related increases. But the unions must agree to play ball. At the present time the unions get the benefit of advocacy before the Commission and irrespective of whether they are successful, they can immediately seek over-award payments on a plant by plant basis or a company by company basis. The unions cannot continue to have it both ways. If they are given a fair deal, in return surely they should be prepared to accept some restrictions on their bargaining power. The sooner the Government addresses itself to these very difficult but basic issues in economic management the sooner this country will pull out of its tail-spin as far as the economy is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators who have spoken for their support of the Loan Bill. Both Senator Walsh and Senator Siddons described the technical requirements for the Bill. It was introduced rather late because it was thought that such a Bill would not be necessary, but the sorts of factors which were mentioned by Senator Siddons-the additional expenditure which has been incurred unexpectedly, the shortfall of revenue occasioned in part by industrial action reducing oil revenue receipts and the rejection of certain legislation in this place by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats-have given rise to the need for the buffer which this Bill provides. As was pointed out in the second reading speech of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), funding from the Loan Fund to the maximum extent could, if there were no untoward developments, avoid the prospect of a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. In other words, there may be no need to utilise the provisions of this legislation. But the Government, of course, cannot be certain that contingencies will not arise. The unexpected can always be upon us. We have already seen this year the loss of revenue due to union action. For that reason the buffer is seen as being necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing that I would say with respect to the debate which has occurred on this Bill is that I acknowledge the interest which Senator Siddons has shown in terms of a better wage fixing method. I think his comments may be taken as encouraging in respect of the greater dependence upon negotiation which was evident, I think, in the Government's approach over the last year. Indeed, some recent agreements have contained provisions for no strike action, for further review and for no further claims over a defined period. The Government's own moves in the wage fixation area indicate a desire to see that aspect of the economic system functioning in a more satisfactory way. I doubt that the Government would wish to embrace some of the additions which Senator Siddons suggested. The idea of some form of price control with all of the bureaucratic inefficiencies which are inherent in such systems is unlikely to appeal to the Government. I would therefore not wish to sound in my response as though I am encouraging the whole of the package which Senator Siddons has suggested we should consider. As I said, there is no opposition to the passage of this Bill. I commend it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I present Supply Bill (No. 1) 1982-83. This Bill, together with its companion Bill, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1982-83, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1982 to 30 November 1982, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 1 and 2) and the Appropriation Bill for Parliament, forming part of the Budget for 1982-83, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $4,827m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $464m, or about 10 per cent greater than the amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1981-82.
The Bill includes $125m for the advance to the Minister for Finance, which is the same amount as has been included in Appropriation Act (No. 1) for the past several years.
I wish to emphasise that the Supply Bills do not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1982-83 Budget context.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that the Senate deal cognately with Supply Bill (No. 1) 1982-83, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1982-83, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1981-82.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that that action be taken? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four Bills before the Senate. Supply Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 authorises current expenditure in the next financial year up to about the end of November, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 authorises capital expenditure for the same period and Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1981-82 appropriate additional items of expenditure required for this financial year, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) covering current expenditure and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) covering capital expenditure. On behalf of the Opposition I give notice of my intention to move, to the motion that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) be now read a second time, the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) Current economic policies have utterly failed to achieve the Government's stated objectives;

(b) This Bill maintains these disastrous policies, which have depressed economic activity and living standards, increased unemployment, inflation, taxation and interest rates, and accentuated inequity and division in society; and
(c) A completely new economic strategy is required to prevent the Australian economy sliding into deeper recession, and to provide any hope of sustained economic recovery'.

There are, of course, especially in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), many points regarding specific items of government expenditure which justify some comment and questions, but I will not comment on them now. That will be reserved for the Committee stage of the debate on that Bill. Indeed, I do not intend to speak at great length in this cognate debate because we have already today had a debate essentially about the state of the Australian economy and the overseas visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in which debate I participated. To speak at great length in this debate would entail repeating much of what I said this morning. I do not intend to do that, and anyway half a dozen other senators want to speak in the second reading debate.

It is, however, inescapably true that the effects of the Government's economic management in the last seven years are accurately stated in the foreshadowed amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3). Economic activity is depressed. In only one calendar year since the Fraser Government came to office over six years ago has that Government recorded a growth rate sufficiently high to reduce unemployment. In all other years the real non-farm gross domestic product growth rate has been inadequate to sustain the prevailing rate of unemployment. In only one year has it been high enough to reduce the rate of unemployment, given that we require to reduce unemployment a real non-farm GDP growth rate around or in excess of 4 per cent a year. Inflation has been on a rising trend ever since 1978. That, again, is unarguable.

Taxation is at record levels. That is unarguable. It was at record levels even before the present Budget, which increased income taxes for wage and salary earners by an astonishing 22 per cent. Not only is the aggregate level of taxation as a proportion of GDP higher than it has ever been before but also the burden of taxation has been shifted during the lifetime of this Government, unjustly and inequitably, on to wage and salary earners, in particular those at the lower end of the employment spectrum. This has, as the foreshadowed amendment states, 'accentuated inequity and division in society'. In addition, interest rates, as everyone knows, are not just at record levels but are above any level previously recorded by the order of 3 per cent, 4 per cent or, in some cases, 5 per cent or 6 per cent, depending on what type of interest we are talking about. Interest rates are higher by up to 6 per cent than they have ever been. Everyone who is paying off a housing loan, for example, is well aware of the consequences of that.

The third clause of the amendment which I shall be moving states that a completely new economic strategy is required. That strategy, if it is to succeed , must incorporate a social consensus, an agreement, about prices and incomes. Senator Siddons said recently that the unions will not forgo their right to bargain collectively as individual unions. I do not believe that that is entirely true. Certainly they will not forgo that right under the present Government; and, given the record of this Government, there is no reason that they should. But there are, to say the least, encouraging signs that Australia's largest union, and one of its strongest unions, the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, is willing to accept a prices and incomes policy which entails forgoing the right to bargaining on an individual union basis provided that it is part of the sort of package which will be offered by a Labor government. Such a package, of course, will not be offered by the Fraser Government, for purely doctrinal reasons and, even if it were offered, it would not be accepted by the union movement or by the public in general for the very good reason that the Fraser Government is not trusted-and nor should it be trusted.

In those countries of the world which have performed very well since the mid- 1970s, in contrast with Australia-those countries which have maintained consistently lower rates of inflation, consistently higher rates of economic growth and consistently lower rates of unemployment-the common denominator is an effective prices and incomes policy, whether it is called that or not. Those countries-and there are not just one or two of them-include, among others, Japan , West Germany, major industrial powers, and smaller countries, comparable roughly with Australia, such as Austria, Sweden, the Netherlands and Norway. All of those countries have out-performed Australia since the mid-1970s, and of course the other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole, on average, have out-performed Australia since the mid- 1970s.

The leaders, the bright pupils in the OECD class, as opposed to the class dunce who has now promoted himself to lecturer, all have effective prices and incomes policies. It would be surprising, to say the least, if there were not a lesson in that empirical fact which is worth heeding. I do not believe, and the Labor Party does not believe, that Australia can emulate and match the performance of those bright pupils in the OECD class such as Austria, West Germany, the northern European democracies and Japan unless we have an effective prices and incomes policy. Given the very limited coercive power in this area of a national government, apart from anything else, it is unlikely, to say the least, that a consensus will be achieved about a prices and incomes policy unless the Government has a considerable amount of moral authority-and of moral authority this Government is bereft, and justifiably so.

I make one other rather more technical point. It is correct that for reasons that are quite beyond the control of an Australian government-the major reason in question being the geological fact that in Australia there are large and accessible deposits of high grade coal and of many other minerals-Australia has been very well placed in the last couple of years to supply what was the then growing demand from overseas, particularly for an energy alternative to oil. For that reason, Australia's rate of economic growth in 1981 appears to have been higher than the OECD average for the first time since 1975, for the first time since the Fraser Government came to office and for the first time since the last Labor Government went out of office.

The point there is that, when the Labor Government was last in office in 1975, Australia's real gross domestic product growth rate was above the OECD average. It appears again to have been above the OECD average in 1981-althought the figures are tentative. I think that it was also above that average in 1979, but I do not have all the figures before me. Because of this, the Fraser Government, with its customary modesty-exhibited again by the Prime Minister when he describes his blueprint for economic recovery as unexpected, bold and imaginative-sticking to that sort of modesty for which it has become noted, has been claiming kudos for what was, by its standards, an apparent high rate of growth in 1981.

I should like to refer to figures that came out in the quarterly estimates of national income and expenditure for the December quarter of 1981. In case anyone wants to look them up, the Australian Bureau of Statistics catalogue number is 52060. They came out last week or the week before. As the document itself states : Some care should be taken in interpreting the recorded non-farm gross domestic product growth rate in calendar year 1981, firstly because all such measurements are subject to sometimes quite large statistical revisions, but, more importantly in this case, because, conventionally, the estimates of growth are derived from income-based data. National income may be measured by summing income or by summing expenditure, or by summing expenditure plus savings. Conceptually those two things are identical; but, because of inadequacies in the data which is available, those two conceptually identical measurements are in fact never quite identical. The convention is that the difference between the two, which statisticians' jargon dubs the statistical discrepancy, is recorded on the expenditure side of those conceptually identical totals rather than on the income side.

The importance of all this to the interpretation of these quarterly estimates of national income and expenditure is that the growth rate shown on the income- based data, which is the one that is usually looked at-I stress that that is for purely arbitrary reasons, and that is not intended as a criticism, because one must make a choice whether to use one or the other-shows a non-farm growth rate of 4 per cent, whereas on the expenditure-based data the growth rate is only 2.5 per cent. It is probable that the actual figure, as ultimately revised, will fall somewhere between those two figures but at this stage it would be reckless, to say the least, to assert unequivocally, dogmatically, that the 4 per cent figure shown for non-farm gross domestic product in the income based figures is accurate. It would be almost as reckless to assert that as it was for Senator Carrick to assert in the run-up to the 1980 Federal election that Rundle would be producing 200,000 barrels of oil a day by 1990, which everyone now knows to be arrant nonsense. I guess that nobody would be more aware of the fact that it was arrant nonsense than those people who bought all those Rundle shares at prices four times their current value.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance as to whether I should now move my foreshadowed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should move it later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately, at the request of the Government, Appropriation Bills (Nos 3 and 4) and Supply Bills ( Nos 1 and 2). Although these Bills are routine pieces of legislation they are very important. Like the Opposition, the Australian Democrats, in accordance with our pledge not to prevent a government which retains a majority in, and the confidence of, the House of Representatives from governing, will not oppose these Bills. These Bills are essential to that happening. But clearly, as my colleague Senator Evans has recently stated, these Bills are survival Bills. Their passage is undeniably crucial to the Government continuing to govern and thus, like the Loan Bill which prevents Consolidated Revenue from going into the red, they must be passed without delay.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Labor Party proposes to move an amendment to the motion relating to one Bill. The Democrats will be supporting the proposed amendment, as circulated. I seek your guidance, Mr Acting Deputy President, as to whether I should move at this stage the amendment which the Democrats will be seeking to have accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —You may move it at a later stage. At the moment we are dealing with Supply Bill (No. 1). You can speak to your foreshadowed amendment, of course, as it is a cognate debate.

—Our foreshadowed amendment seeks to point out the deficiencies in the Government's economic management and underlines our attitudes as to what should happen if the economy is to be revived. We believe that there are four key areas of economic management which the Government urgently needs to address. They are: Firstly, that the economy should be selectively stimulated; secondly, that a fair and just prices and incomes policy has to be introduced; thirdly, that we must institute a process of national indicative planning; and fourthly, that we need to encourage industrial democracy so that our industries can be built on a sound foundation and industrial relations can become an economic tool rather than the blunt instrument it is at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Before turning to this theme and our foreshadowed amendment, I would like to make a few observations about the contents of the Bills and their purposes. Appropriation Bills (Nos 3 and 4) are parallel Bills to Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) which were passed last year and implemented with the Budget. Essentially, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) appropriates money for the ordinary annual services of the Government and thus, under the terms of the 1965 compact, can only be rejected or passed by the Senate but not amended. Appropriation Bill (No. 4) could be amended but under section 53 of the Constitution it may not be amended to increase the burden on the people. Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) are similarly arranged. The Appropriation Bills are needed, in the words of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, 'to meet essential and unavoidable expenditure for which provision was not made in the earlier Appropriation Acts'.

The proposed additional expenditure in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) totals $740. 4m. It includes $409m for wage and salary costs, money for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, initial payments on the Invincible and the funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Appropriation Bill (No. 4) includes funds payable to former lessees of two Northern Territory pastoral leases which were compulsorily acquired by the Government, money for several capital works projects and a $25m increase in the subscribed capital of Qantas Airways Ltd. Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) seek interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1982 to 30 November 1982, by which date it is expected that Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83 and the Appropriation Bill for the Parliament, forming part of the 1982-83 Budget, will have been enacted.

One of the most significant elements in the appropriations sought under these Bills is that for the wage and salary increases which the Government claims were not foreseen. As I have said previously when I have spoken on this matter, the Government, at the time the Budget was framed, could reasonably be expected to have foreseen these sorts of increases. The Democrats are alarmed by aspects of the Coldham report into Defence Force pay and particularly the lack of a formula by which future rises can be calculated. The members of the Defence Force deserve to be appropriately paid for their services and, most importantly, they also deserve better living conditions. But the Parliament must have some idea of what personnel costs are likely to be in the future. The Democrats do not have any confidence at this stage that the Government is able to foresee those costs.

I would now like to make a few brief remarks about the state of the economy which this Government quite obviously has failed to manage properly for the last six years. The Australian economy is in the worst state it has been in since the Great Depression. To be charitable, international circumstances have not made economic management easy and the slide towards a depression in the United States has not helped. Despite this the Government has not seen fit to change its policies. Even Professor Milton Friedman, the father of monetarism and a modern advocator of small government and generally conservative economic management, only recently stated that deficits, so long as they are not excessive, are okay. They are satisfactory and are a reasonable approach to economic management. In spite of Professor Friedman's making this recent claim, this Government has persisted with an ultraconservative approach to monetary control and monetary management. Sadly, the results of the Government's exessses are very obvious.

For the first time in a generation we have a government which is not committed to full employment and which has repeatedly shown itself to be uninterested and unconcerned at hardships that the lack of full employment are causing in the community. A great British economist more than 50 years ago said that conservatives are to be condemned by their ideology to inflict misery on people. This Government and its ideological brethren in the United States, Great Britain and other countries have shown the truth of this. Recently Senator Button referred to the fact that the standard of living of Australians has fallen in the last few years in comparison with most other advanced countries and that we are now only fifteenth on the list and are well behind other countries such as Sweden, Switzerland, West Germany and the United States.

As I said earlier, the Australian Democrats believe that there are four basic key areas to economic renewal. Let me briefly outline the sorts of policies that we would like to see the Government adopt. Firstly, we believe that the Government must selectively stimulate the economy. There are so many unused resources, both human and material, but particularly human, that unless we change our approach and utilise the unused resources we will never solve the problem of inflation. At the moment the economy is operating very inefficiently. Unemployment ensures that. The fact that our industries are operating in many cases at half their planned capacity again adds a great cost burden to the economy as a whole. Unemployment must be eliminated if the economy is to operate efficiently and if that cost factor is to be eliminated from the cost push inflation which is the case at the moment. If we did have full employment the multiplier effect would have a most positive reaction on the community. This selective stimulation of the economy, as we see it, would be the first priority of government economic management. Housing-to name just one area-cries out for stimulation. Recently the Treasurer said that Australians are overhoused. We believe that Australians are entitled to housing and the assurances that they have reasonable dignity and comfort. During the life of this Government expenditure on housing has fallen from 3.9 per cent of the Budget to less than one per cent. Real expenditure fell 70 per cent between 1974-75 and 1981-82.

The second key area, as we see it, is national indicative planning. I have spoken in this chamber many times on the importance of this. I am delighted to see that the Australian Jaycees, which is a totally non-political organisation, has recently sponsored a book entitled Challenge to Australia which looks to the need for planning. Three of Australia's most distinguished sons, Sir Barton Pope , Sir Macfarlane Burnet and Sir Mark Oliphant, agree with me and with the Democrats on the vital need for long term planning. This is very heartwarming to us. I hope that the Government will take note of what the community and the Democrats are saying and have repeatedly said. I was most disappointed, nevertheless, that the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, made clear recently that the Government does not see the necessity for the establishment of any basic long term planning agency. Apparently the Minister is content to continue with the laissez faire approach to economic management which, I am afraid, has been symptomatic of the Government's approach since it came to power six years ago.

The third basic key area to economic recovery is the need for an effective and just prices and incomes policy. I did comment on that to some degree earlier so I will not elaborate except to make the point that Bob Hawke, some two years ago , I think at the Australian Labor Party's national convention, made it clear that he considered the Government and the Labor Party should again attempt to change our Constitution, by way of a referendum, which would allow the Government to fix prices and incomes for a period. That would allow the Federal Government to move into this area. As we see it this is still vitally important. The problems of changing the constitution are not minimised as far as the Democrats are concerned. But that is no excuse for not trying. I believe that there has to be a concerted effort to get the States and all political parties to agree that the Federal Government does need this vital power if it is to effectively control the economy. In the meantime, urgent steps should be taken to get a social compact-call it what you will-or some agreement that, for a short period at least, will place a freeze on prices and incomes. We need a circuit breaker to stop this great spiral of inflation and the expectation of ever increasing prices and costs.

Lastly, and I believe most importantly, the fourth key area to economic management would be the introduction of industrial democracy in this country. It is vital that we use industrial relations as a tool to economic management. We will not solve unemployment until we can see a revitalisation of our manufacturing industries. It is vital that this rebuilding of our manufacturing industries be based on a firm foundation. That foundation has to be based on a partnership, a genuine collaboration, between the interests of labour and capital. This can only be done by embracing the principles of industrial democracy. This Senate has already debated and passed an industrial democracy Bill which clearly sets out how this can be done. We put it to the Government that the passing of this Bill in the lower House is now urgent if we are to build our industries on a firm foundation.

I wish to say what I said earlier-that is, how welcome it is that Mr Macphee has entered the troubled area of the industrial relations portfolio. We are hopeful that he will recognise that industrial relations can be used as a tool to economic management and that he will prevail upon the Government to adopt this approach. Just as the marriage laws cannot force spouses to sleep together, our industrial relations laws cannot force people to work together. That is basic and fundamental. In this country we must develop an environment in which people will work happily together, in which there is a partnership between the essential factors of production, labour and capital.This happens in other countries. For the Government to smile and to suggest that what we propose is pie in the sky, or mere dreaming, is to ignore the reality in so many enlightened countries. The sooner that the Government realises that people are free agents, that their co-operation must be sought, the sooner we will have a better Australia, the sooner we will have made a start towards solving our critical problems in economic management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment my friend and Australian Democrat colleague, Senator Siddons, on his thoughtful contribution to the debate. The Senate is debating a series of measures-Supply Bill (No. 1), Supply Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). These Bills, which the Parliament is asked to pass, provide funds as a part of the Government's economic strategy. Therefore, at this stage it is proper to examine the Government's appalling economic results. Of course, these Bills will be passed because the Democrats are pledged never to block Supply Bills, which these are, as distinct from Bills which raise revenue or impose taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to comment briefly on one or two aspects of the economy that will be affected by the additional money that today this Senate will vote to the Government. Unemployment presents a worrying scene. It is now admitted as representing 6.3 per cent of the work force, or some 435,000 people, but according to the latest reports of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, another 619,000 unemployed are hidden, or not registered as such. This pushes the total number of people who are available and willing to work, but who do not have a job, close to 15 per cent of the notional work force. Thus, one in every six who are prepared to work are not, for one reason or another, working. One could well say that that is the severest indictment of the Government's economic policies and, as Senator Siddons has said, an appalling waste of our human resources. Sometimes I find it difficult to realise I have been in this Parliament, in one House or another, for some 22 years. When I first came to it, an unbreakable rule, one accepted by members of all political parties, was that if unemployment ever exceeded 1.5 per cent or 2 per cent it would mean the immediate destruction of the government. That was a sort of rule of law, such as that night follows day. If unemployment ever exceeded 2 per cent the government of the day, whether Labor or Liberal, was doomed. Now unemployment is officially admitted to stand at 6.3 per cent and, as I have said, it is really 15 per cent, yet out there in the electorate it hardly seems to be a political question.

The Australian Labor Party conducted at least one of the last two election campaigns on the basis that unemployment was a big issue. It did so following very expert, and no doubt very expensive, research by the expensive consultants that it, in common with all political parties except the Democrats who cannot afford it, hires to obtain such valuable information. Those surveys that the Labor Party, and I believe also the Liberal Party, conducted indicated that unemployment was the biggest issue in the electorate. The Labor Party quite properly, and if I might say so quite humanely, followed a policy directed at curing unemployment. In the event, unemployment was not the big issue that the pollsters, the expensive consultants, had predicted it was. They were told by people on whose doors they knocked that the biggest issue was unemployment, but quite often people who answer the questions of pollsters at their front doors tell fibs. The sooner political parties and others-whether they are selling a political doctrine, toothpaste or anything else-realise that the fewer will be the mistakes that are made. Clearly a person answering the question 'What do you think is the most important issue in the country's economy today?' being human, will want to impress the pollster. If the pollster presents to that person a series of options-unemployment, interest rates, social service benefits, housing loans and so on-he or she is bound to say 'unemployment' because he or she wants to appear unselfish, caring, altruistic, Christian and so on; but in the secrecy of the ballot box the real self comes out.

It is an unhappy comment to make of Australians, but I believe that a great number will say to a pollster at the door, 'I care for the unemployed', but in the secrecy of the ballot box will register the view: 'I do not give a damn about people who are unemployed as long as I have a job. If the present Government'-which happened at the time of the survey to be a Liberal Government- 'is pursuing policies whereby I can get a wage, whereby I can get provision to feed and clothe my family, that will do me. I might say an odd prayer for the unemployed next Sunday if I go to church, but my personal vote will go to the Government that is presently giving me a job'. That illustrates how political feeling has changed in this country since I first came to the Parliament.

I remember that Les Haylen, a much loved and revered Labor politician, said that anything up to 5 per cent unemployment was inevitable in a capitalistic society. That virtually destroyed for six to nine years the Labor Party's chances of being elected. It was used ruthlessly and very successfully by the Liberal Party of the time under Sir Robert Menzies. People were terrified of unemployment. It was not just unemployment that was a political factor, it was the fear of unemployment. It proved to be a very effective political weapon. Unhappily, today it no longer remains a weapon. Why it does not I leave to people wiser than I am to answer. The fact is that today in this country one in six of those who are prepared, able and willing to work are not working, yet it is not the political dynamite or death knell for the Liberal-National Country Party that it would have been to any party 10 years ago.

The same can be said of interest rates, which now are at an all-time high, with most moving rapidly towards 20 per cent. Again, if five years ago any government had presided over an economy in which interest rates were approaching 20 per cent it would have suffered instant dismissal at the ballot box.

TALK.START.PARA: —They refused Supply here in those days. You can't do that, under the new rule, any more.
—I acknowledge the interjection of my friend, Senator Button, but he is missing the point that I am making, doubtless because I am making it badly .
—Too cleverly.

—His quick mind normally grasps points in a flash. My point is that even if Supply were refused and this Government were forced now to the people, the present 15 per cent unemployment rate and 20 per cent interest rates would not necessarily sound the death knell of the Fraser Government. Ten years ago no government, be it Labor or Liberal, could possibly have survived in such circumstances. In speaking on these Supply Bills I am posing the queston of what has happened to our society. Have we got used to a situation in which we do not care about the other chap? Do we not care about the one in six people who does not have a job and who wants a job? Do we not fear any more? Have we become so fatalistic about the future that we believe that all political parties are the same, that things will not be any better under Labor or whatever? Have the people given politicians away? I do not know the answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just pointing to what I believe to be two rather extraordinary political phenomena. As a direct result of high interest rates, the number of people able to commit themselves to the major undertaking of buying a home is diminishing rapidly. Ten years ago the one common denominator in all young Australians, which was pumped into them by their parents, was 'you will have your own precious piece of dirt and you will put your own precious brick veneer dwelling on it'. That was the Australian dream. Every young Australian accepted and embraced that as an ideal. We have seen a change. I do not know that it is necessarily a bad change but a change it is. That dream is now becoming an impossible dream as interest rates continue to soar. This year housing commencements are expected to be no higher than 130,000. That does not mean anything in itself but when I say that that figure is 30,000 short of the level needed to maintain Australia's housing stock, it does mean something. The queues for welfare housing are growing. More than 100,000 families are on the waiting lists nation-wide for welfare housing while the housing industry is underutilised by as much as 20 per cent, in some areas adding significantly to those people unemployed and losing valuable trade skills.

I have never boasted of being a very bright or very intelligent person. I have an economics and commerce degree but I still cannot understand a situation in which a politician or a group of politicians tells me, as I am being told today, that Australia-wide there are 100,000 families who desperately want cheap homes, that unemployment in the housing industry is something like 20 per cent and that the two cannot be matched and brought together. In other words, we are to have 20 per cent undercapacity in the housing industry and 100,000 families living God knows where under God knows what sorts of conditions. That is another thing that continues to bewilder me. An indication of the worsening situation for self -employed tradesmen and small business people is provided by the 24.7 per cent increase in personal bankruptcies in 1980-81 compared with the previous year. I have heard Government Ministers dispute those figures. I am not a politician who normally cites a lot of figures. An old Jewish friend of mine, a very wise man, used to say to me: 'Chippy, do not quote too many figures because although figures do not lie, liars can figure and everybody realises that'. I very seldom cite figures. But the stark figures are there; among small businesses bankruptcies increased by 25 per cent last year compared with the previous year. I hope I do not malign the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, but he is or was an accountant, a man used to this sort of subject, and I would be obliged if he could explain to me why that phenomenon is taking place and why the Government-allegedly a government that champions free and private enterprise -is not concerned about it.

The Government has identified rapidly rising wages as one of the factors fuelling cost push inflation, and with some justification. I agree with the Government that a few greedy trade unions sometimes unnecessarily push for abnormal and unfair wage hikes at the expense of the community. There is a saying, which has some truth, that a wage increase for one worker costs the job of another. But, while we concede that increases in wages above productivity do add to inflation-and the Government always seems to blame wage increases for inflation, which sometimes is justified-I never hear a Government Minister or the head of the Treasury, John Stone, a man of remarkable intellect, make a point about interest rates and what they do to inflation. What are interest rates? They are not just something that appears in a savings bank account in June of every year showing how much interest one has earned on one's savings. Interest rates represent the cost of money at any particular time. I ask those people listening to me-I am not talking about honourable senators in the chamber because one could hardly describe the Senate chamber as overflowing at the moment--

TALK.START.PARA: —There's a lot of quality here though.

—The quality is here though, Senator; I will admit to that in a flash. I ask those people listening at home-some 300,000 Australians listen to us at any given time-to look at an object in front of them. I do not mean for them to look at a husband or a wife; I mean some inanimate object like a table or a chair. I ask those people to ask themselves what is the real cost of that table, or this desk in front of me that I have just thumped. The real cost of an item can be measured in several components. Of course, wages are a component of the cost of that item. I do not go to the Marxian extreme and say that wages are the only real cost in that article. If Senator Button, a non-cricketer, will forgive me for a moment and let me pad that away to slips, let us forget the Marxian argument for the moment. While wages do represent part of the cost of the desk, the table or the chair in front of us at the moment, in this day of automation, wages represent only a fraction of the cost of that object, whether it be a desk, a table, a can of beans in the refrigerator or whatever. If I understand my reading correctly, wages represent something like 22 per cent of a product on a national average. So an increase of 10 per cent in wages does not mean that inflation rises automatically by 10 per cent. It means that inflation rises by 10 per cent of 22 per cent. I would have thought that was fairly simple economics. But when we look at the object in front of us, the table or the chair , it has to be financed. The money has to be obtained from a bank or from some other source in order to pay the wages to make it, to buy the raw materials for it, to pay for the power to produce it, the packing to pack it, the transport to take it from the factory to the shop, et cetera. Money is needed to finance the manufacture, distribution and exchange of the object. This is a difficult economic exercise to conclude.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been told by a very distinguished civil servant, an expert in economics, who naturally must remain nameless, this rather startling fact: Every one per cent increase in the rate of interest equals a 25 per cent increase in the level of wages across the board. I repeat that: A one per cent increase in interest rates contributes to inflation in the same way as does a 25 per cent increase in wage rates. What would have happened in this Parliament if this week the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, instead of awarding no increase in wages, had said: 'We will award a 25 per cent increase in wages across the board to all the workers involved'? There would have been a near riot in this Parliament. I suspect that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) would have been sorely tempted to cancel his trip overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would have resisted the temptation, though.

—In my judgment he would have resisted the temptation, but only after a severe internal battle with his conscience. A 25 per cent increase in wages awarded by a commission would be regarded by a government as a near catastrophe. How many times have we heard from government sources announcements of an increase of one per cent in interest rates? That is the same thing. Those increases are announced with an air of gay nonchalance and reckless abandon. I ask: Where is the consistency, where is the logic?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not hold to that figure. I was told that figure by a senior civil servant of international standing. I asked the Parliamentary Library to check on the figure. I got a rather disappointing reply. The Library advised that such a comparison was near impossible to calculate because of the massive presumptions one would have to make. It said that, in any case, if it were calculated, because of the presumptions it would be a worthless figure. That was written by a true librarian, I suppose, or a true economist. The Government has great resources at its command. I am not trying to make a political point, but it would be very interesting for those of us who are interested in the economic debate taking place in this country to find out what a one per cent increase in the interest rate represents in terms of the inflation rate and in particular what it represents in terms of an increase in wages. I ask the Minister, if he believes that there is some substance in what I am saying-that is, that an increase in interest rates does contribute to inflation-whether it would be a useful exercise for him to ask Mr John Stone and the Department of the Treasury to provide the Parliament with that figure.

I, and the Democrats, acknowledge that some trade unions use their muscle to obtain what are euphemistically called 'pace-setting pay increases'. A disgusting exhibition appears on the front pages of this morning's newspapers, about which I cannot comment because of court proceedings. But I say on behalf of the Democrats, people who have respect for law and order in this country, that we all were disgusted by statements made by certain leading union officials today about 'letting gorillas out of cages'. I make no more comment about that.

The Democrats have enormous sympathy for the vast majority of workers who are asking for wage increases and who are simply struggling to catch up with the diminishing real value of their wages. The Government, in its recent industrial relations legislation, did not choose to attack this problem by attempting to reduce living costs. It decided instead to attempt to push through some of the most draconian, unintelligent, stupid industrial relations measures we have ever seen in this country. It seemed to want to contain by brute force what it is could not achieve by economic policy. In doing so it is misusing the industrial relations option. I believe that Senator John Siddons made a significant contribution to economic debate in this country. I join with him in saying that we are thankful that a man of the integrity, compassion, tolerance, intelligence and understanding of Ian Macphee is now Minister for Industrial Relations. He had not been in the job for five minutes before he declared that he wanted to talk with unions and with employers before introducing new measures. He will do that instead of coming into the Parliament with draconian measures to score cheap, nasty political points.

I was taken with the phrase used by Senator Siddons when he said that industrial relations in this country should be used by Governments as a tool of economic policy rather than as a brutal political weapon. I thought that was a well-chosen phrase. Let us face it, that is one of the few shots left in the Government's locker to try to bring this economy to some sort of order. That is not necessarily a criticism of the Fraser Government because governments throughout the Western world are facing problems. They have tried monetarism, that insane, obsessive product of Freidman and others. It has failed and has been seen to fail. There are few weapons left. One of the weapons which we have not tried is the industrial relations one of consensus, which the Democrats have talked about since we were first elected to this Senate five years ago. The only way to achieve industrial peace and to have some breakthrough in this area is through consultation between the workers, management and the Government.

I conclude by giving just one example. I pose this because I think it is good to have it on record for listeners to this debate to determine the bona fides of this Government in these difficult times. The recent industrial relations legislation did, among other things, two things: It had regard to what are known as stand-downs and to giving preference to trade unions. I will deal very briefly with each in turn. The Australian Democrats support private enterprise, particularly the small business person. I have been one myself. We know the difficulties that a small business person, whom we admire intensely, suffers when that person employs, say, ten people and, for reasons totally out of his or her control, cannot employ those 10 people usefully because industrial action or a strike somewhere has meant that he or she cannot get raw materials into the factory, shop, or whatever. It is unthinkable that that person who has risked his or her capital, health and family to start a business of his or her own should be forced to keep those workers on if that person cannot get them to do anything useful. So, a stand-down provision is essential. That has been admitted by the Australian Labor Party and by all the trade unions. After many years a solution appeared; namely that unions could apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for stand-down provisions to be put into their awards. Many unions have done that. It has worked like a charm. There were some instances of applicants for stand-downs not being heard as expeditiously as possible, so the word 'expeditiously' was written into the legislation in 1977.

I defy any Government Minister-we have already done this-to produce the name of one employer who can say: 'These stand-down provisions are not working. I, a small business person, cannot stand down my people and have not been able to stand down my people'. There has not been one such employer. Yet into this Parliament, without any explanation, comes a Bill to allow employees to be stood down automatically. It is a return to the infamous days when workers were stood down capriciously by unscrupulous employers. Why did such a provision get through the intelligent people of Cabinet? Why did the Government go against the advice of the Department of Industrial Relations? One wonders sometimes why, with an intelligent Prime Minister such as Mr Fraser and intelligent people in the Cabinet, such stupid legislation gets through. Is it merely for the purposes of provocation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that we have discussed separately today, firstly, Supply Bill (No. 1 ) 1982-83 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 and, secondly, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1981-82, I wonder whether it would be agreeable to all sides if I addressed my remarks to the points raised during the debate on the Supply Bills, which I intended to do on the Appropriation Bills at the end of the debate, and to deal with the Supply Bills as quickly as possible.
—There is no objection, Senator Messner.
—In that case I wish the Supply Bills a speedy passage.

Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.
