Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, two amendments are to be moved. The first has been circulated in the name of the Opposition. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) current economic policies have utterly failed to achieve the Government's stated objectives;

(b) this Bill maintains these disastrous policies, which have depressed economic activity and living standards, increased unemployment, inflation, taxation and interest rates, and accentuated inequity and division in society; and
(c) a completely new economic strategy is required to prevent the Australian economy sliding into deeper recession, and to provide any hope of sustained economic recovery'.

I wish to speak very briefly to the amendment. I say 'briefly' because the issues it covers have been debated in the Senate quite frequently-indeed they were debated this morning. I suppose I have been stimulated to say anything at all only by Senator Chipp's simple speech this afternoon. I hasten to qualify the use of the word 'simple'. I do not mean simple minded, conceptually simple or anything like that. His speech was a very simple statement of some of the issues, which I think is welcome in this place.

I shall refer to the terms of the amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3). I do not think there is any point in reiterating the clear view of the majority of honourable senators that the Government's current economic policies have failed to achieve the Government's stated objectives. It is very difficult to discern what this Government's stated objectives are in regard to the future of this country. It is pretty clear to see what they are when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is overseas fixing other problems, but in Australia, the stated objectives are sometimes difficult to achieve. One can divine a thread in the last three elections which ran through the stated objectives prior to each one. Prior to each election the stated objectives were put in terms of reducing inflation. In the last three elections which the Fraser Government has fought the reduction of inflation has always been put as the top priority. The objective of reducing unemployment, after the election policies were followed, involved putting inflation first, we agree, but the consequence of those policies has been higher unemployment. Policies relating to improving the growth rate and the economic situation of the average Australian were also enunciated in the last three elections. It is in relation to those sorts of matters that one can, by an exercise of the imagination, put together a grab bag of what one thinks are this Government's stated objectives.

We say that the stated objectives, insofar as they can be divined, have not been achieved and that the present Bill maintains disastrous policies which have depressed economic activity and living standards and increased unemployment, inflation, taxation and interest rates. I again remind the Senate that Australian living standards have been declining steadily in terms of per capita income sine 1976. Australia has moved from No. 8 to No. 15 in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development hit parade of per capita income since this Government came to power. There has been an enormous increase in the taxation burden on lower paid people in Australia, that is those who have jobs. That increase in taxation on lower paid people has been accompanied by a significant growth in real poverty in Australia stemming from unemployment and a variety of other factors which affect the wellbeing of the average member of this community.

There has been a very real depression of living standards under this Government . From time to time one has been led to believe that that is all necessary in order to deal with inflation. The fact of the matter is that the level of inflation is now higher than it has ever been since this Government came to power; it is, of course, in double figures yet again. Similarly, at the same time there has been increased unemployment. The rate of unemployment in Australia is now higher than it has ever been since the Great Depression. Probably, if the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures of last week are to be believed, nearly one million people in Australia are looking for work or are anxious to have work if it becomes available.

Interest rates are the highest that they have ever been. Of course, it has been a Government-stated objective to reduce interest rates. I think it was in the 1977 election campaign when the Prime Minister said that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent. One is able to guess that the lowering of interest rates has been a stated objective of the present Government. Those policies have failed. As I indicated before in connection with taxation, there was a 22 per cent increase in the last Budget on the level of taxation paid by pay-as-you-earn income earners. Those various factors have all accentuated inequity and division in society. Of course, the greatest inequity in the taxation system is this Government's continuing tolerance of tax avoidance. I will digress in a Chipp- like manner. Last week in Melbourne I had lunch with the president of a professional association who told me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid?

—I am not sure how to answer that. Whatever I say I might be in difficulty. He was the president of a professional association and he told me quite seriously: 'I do not know anybody who pays tax'. He would be earning about $100,000 a year. That is the circle of friends he keeps and he said: 'I do not know anybody who pays tax'. I will tell Senator Messner, who is trying to interject, afterwards if he likes, who it was and what his profession is. That is the sort of inequity which exists in Australian society where professional people can make remarks like that with some degree of pride although, in his case, with disapproval about that sort of thing. We can have a situation in which only last week the Australian Taxpayers Association said that $7,000m a year is being lost to revenue by having that sort of person in the community.
—Is that $7,000m legal evasion or illegal evasion, or both?

—I do not know. I do not think that would have been dissected. ' Avoision' is the expression being used now. It is a dreadful word. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, a royal commission set up to crack a few nuts in the trade union movement , has ended up revealing an enormous industry in this area with billions of dollars flowing through bodgie companies as a result of efforts being made to avoid taxation. That is the sort of society in which we live and that is why we refer to these policies as disastrous. We make the comment that a completely new economic strategy is required to prevent deeper recession and to bring about sustained economic recovery. That is what most Australians, of course, are concerned about now. They are concerned about where this society is going in terms of all those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: People want to know whether unemployment, which we were told five years ago would disappear as a result of this Government's policies, will disappear or whether it will be here until the year 2000 and beyond. They want to know whether tax avoidance will go on until the end of this century. They want to know whether it will be impossible for Australians to buy houses in the remaining 20 years of this century. They want to know what will happen to interest rates. That, of course, is an associated matter. They want to know about the levels of taxation which this society can expect in the next 10 years or 20 years. They do not want to be promised, as they were promised in 1977, bribes at the next Budget. These are the fundamental issues which concern people and which suggest that this Government has no strategy for sustained economic recovery and no strategy related to the fundamental questions which concern the majority of the Australian people.

The Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment to the amendment which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition relating to many of these issues. If I might indulge in commentary on the proposed amendment, I say that I think it is very rarely that the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party agree. Senator Chipp and his Party are always attacking us in this chamber. But on this issue I am moved to observe that the fine minds of the Australian Democrats or the fine mind of the Australian Democrats-I do not want to make people think that they are all like that-and the fine mind of the Opposition, not mine but Senator Walsh's, are in fundamental agreement about some of the issues about which we ought to be concerned. The Democrats' amendment refers again to the importance of having policies for long term economic recovery. Those policies involve an effective and just prices and incomes policy, national indicative planning, selective stimulation of the economy, the encouragement of industrial relations and a recognition that industrial relations is an essential creature of a healthy, viable democracy and an improving economy. All these concepts are, in a sense, wrapped up in the Democrats' proposal. We will be happy to accept and support their amendment because these are the sorts of issues to which this Parliament should be addressing its mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear that the Australian Labor Party is supporting our proposed amendment. I thank Senator Button for his kind words. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After paragraph (c) of the words proposed to be added, add the following paragraph:
'and (d) long term economic recovery in this country depends on
(i) an effective and just prices and incomes policy,
(ii) national indicative planning,
(iii) selective stimulation of the economy, and
(iv) the encouragement of industrial democracy and a recognition that industrial relations should be used as a valuable tool of economic management, rather than a blunt political weapon.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on a few of the points that have been raised in the debate.
—You could say we believe in motherhood too.
—One could almost say that in relation to that last amendment in several respects. However, a number of specifics would need to be addressed in relation to them.
—Clearly you didn't understand it if you make that comment.
—Perhaps we will come to it in a moment.
—Can you justify that remark in view of your industrial relations legislation?

—I think we will turn to these events in the course of my remarks. Firstly, we heard from Senator Walsh, at a very early stage in this debate, who referred to other countries doing much better than Australia in terms of economic performance since 1975. I think he specified countries such as West Germany, Austria, some northern European countries and also Japan. It is fairly clear that some of those countries indeed have done surprisingly well over the last six or eight years. There are also many other countries that have done extremely worse than Australia has in the job creation area in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Senator Walsh failed to mention countries such as France , the United States of America, the United Kingdom and many other countries of Europe whose affairs have fallen into great states of disrepair over that same period. Why were those countries not mentioned? They were not mentioned because they indulged in the kinds of policies that led to high rates of inflation and to high rates of unemployment. It is clear that Senator Walsh refuses to acknowledge the basic premise which is the essential element of this Government' s policy and which, through the control of inflation, has brought about a turn- around in growth factors in the Australian economy in the last six years. In particular I refer to an item which, I think, is very close to Senator Chipp's heart and that is the job creation role of the Australian economy. I think he would acknowledge that since 1978 there has been an annual rate of growth in jobs in this economy in the order of 2 per cent. I think that during 1979 it hit over 200,000. That kind of growth rate has been produced by the kinds of policies which have been employed by this Government.

I come now to some of the specifics which were raised by Senator Siddons in his proposed amendment to the motion for the second reading. He spoke, firstly, of an effective and just prices and incomes policy. Ever since I have been a member of this Parliament and taken an interest in economic affairs people have been talking about prices and incomes policies. No one has come up with any policy that seems capable of working. I was sorry that Senator Siddons was unable to present us today with a formula. The results of the so-called 1974 social compact in the United Kingdom certainly did not demonstrate a great deal of faith on the part of the trade unions in any kind of prices and incomes policy that was employed in that country. I do not know whether Senator Siddons is suggesting that we apply the same kinds of policies that were employed with such disastrous results by the then Labour Government in the United Kingdom or whether he is suggesting some alternative. However that alternative was not forthcoming today. I would appreciate it if, in future, we could deal with some more specific points about that matter.

National indicative planning was the second item mentioned by Senator Siddons. He assumes it is possible to be able to predict with great certainty the future trends of events not only in this country but also internationally. We know that those kinds of trends are virtually impossible to predict when it comes to assessing long term plans over periods of, I suggest, five to 10 years. Again I presume that Senator Siddons was referring to that kind of time frame. Obviously this is an area of great concern. It is an area in which all nations, all economies, would be seeking to do the best they can in determining the best use of the resources that are at hand, whether they be land, mineral resources, or how people work within an economy to produce goods and services. Those things are all factors associated with production in an economy. It is impossible to plan with any great certainty how those things may be achieved.

I turn to the third point in Senator Siddons's proposed amendment, selective stimulation of the economy. Again we heard a number of general propositions in this regard but nothing very much in the way of specifics. We heard of one suggestion, stimulation of the housing industry. I think that the Government can take credit for the recent package of housing support announced by it some six or eight weeks ago. Those policies are designed to provide the Australian housing industry with another $400m towards the development and improvement of housing in this country. I think it is also very important to note that currently some 72 per cent of home ownership in this country is in private hands . That is a very significant factor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it increasing or decreasing?

—It has dropped, I believe, very slightly but compared with the longer run figures it is still very significant compared with, say, the 45 per cent rate in the early 1940s. Clearly, the development of private ownership of housing is one of this Government's prime objectives and it will continue to be so.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth point mentioned by Senator Siddons was 'encouragement of industrial democracy and a recognition that industrial relations should be used as a valuable tool of economic management, rather than a blunt political weapon.' I think all of us would acknowledge that as a very clear statement of the sort of relationship that we all believe should exist between unions and management. It is the kind of relationship which this Government is seeking to foster. I note in particular the Australian Democrats laudatory remarks about the current Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) in this area. However the words 'industrial democracy' do stand out. Again this is one of those expressions which can mean anything to anybody who so--

TALK.START.PARA: —As defined in the Bill.

—I am going to acknowledge the honourable senator's point. It is one of those expressions that mean anything to anyone who claims a particular meaning. Senator Siddons has given us the benefit of seeing his Industrial Democracy Bill which is before the Senate. We have a clear idea of what he means by that phrase. However the general proposition in relation to unions and management and the general question of leadership within the industrial economy in this country certainly is one which this Government not only supports but also does, in its own way, employ on a day-to-day basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp was very concerned with unemployment. He was particularly concerned about the lack of job growth in this economy and made the point that there could be as many as 15 per cent of the community unemployed. He made the point that people somehow had become switched off to the unemployment issue. I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is certainly not the position of this Government. This Government is not switched off to the concerns of the unemployed, nor to the essential job of creating more employment in this country. Our commitment to the development of this nation's resources, both human and mineral, is well known to all Australians. For that reason we can believe that people will continue to support the Government in the way that they have in the last six years. They perceive this job making and creating capacity as one of the first intentions and first policies and priorities of this Government.

Senator Chipp also referred to high interest rates. He sought explanations as to how higher interest rates would lead to beneficial effects in the economy. I think that sums up the honourable senator's expression. It is difficult to debate issues of money supply and rates of growth in the economy in a very short period because the subjects are fairly complex. However, I think I can make one or two points. Although interest does feed into the overall cost structure of business, and consequently in due course, given time lags, reflects itself in the rate of inflation in any economy, the point is that more direct control over inflation can be exercised by a government through control of the money supply. One of the factors that do flow from that kind of control, which has been very tightly exercised by this Government since 1976, is problems with interest rates . By controlling the supply of money, by ensuring that that rate is kept to a minimum, we can ensure that the rate of inflation is kept at the lowest level possible within the circumstances applicable. This subject would demand a longer argument than we can devote at this time but that essentially is the point in relation to inflation.

I believe that the next point of equal importance and certainly very significant, was not mentioned by any speaker during this debate. That point concerns the external effect upon our interest rate structure in this country over the last few years. We have a situation where if we pay no regard to the competitive international money market scene and allow our interest rates to be significantly below those of overseas countries we will find ourselves in a situation of capital outflow to other countries in such a way as to lead to a depletion of the availability of capital for housing, small business, resource development, or whatever, within the Australian economy.

Of course, that has significant ramifications for the value of the dollar. Such a situation would be detrimental in the longer term effects on the fundamental issue of inflation. Of course, the point is that if a currency decreases in value the effects of that in due course are inflationary. That has been well understood by economists for a great number of years. For those reasons the maintenance of a healthy balance of payments situation overseas depends on the kind of interest rate structure that we have in this country being competitive with those of other nations. I will turn quickly to the Opposition's amendment in relation to the second reading of the Bills. Firstly, the Opposition seeks to add to the motion the statement that:
Current economic policies have utterly failed to achieve the Government's stated objectives.

It is clear to me-I hope that in their most objective moments it would be clear to Senator Button and to Senator Walsh-that during the last six years there has been a significant growth in the number of jobs in this country. Employment has grown very substantially over that time and in general terms inflation has been significantly reduced since 1975. There has been an overall approach which has determined, and is still continuing to contribute to, the development of this nation in the longer run. The kinds of conditions being set by this Government in relation to the inflation rate of this country and in relation to employment growth are setting the climate for future development. It is that which we seek to do. The second point raised in the amendment is that the Bill in some way maintains the disastrous policies-as the Opposition calls them-and claims that these have depressed economic activity and living standards, increased unemployment, inflation, taxation and interest rates, and so on. Of course, the point is that the very reverse is true in many cases. In fact economic activity has grown over the last six years. In fact more jobs have been created in that period. Even in this last financial year there has been a growth rate in gross domestic product of over 5 per cent in real terms. That demonstrates a fairly clear commitment on the part of this Government to improvement of the living standards of Australians. It would be appreciated, even by members of the Opposition, that in fact the growth in economic rates in this country are the only ways by which living standards of all Australians will be improved. It is that productivity which will lead to a wealthier and more prosperous Australia.

The third point raised by the Opposition touched on the need for a new economic strategy to prevent the Australian economy sliding into deeper recession. It was quite clear that neither Senator Walsh nor Senator Button was able to produce evidence that demonstrated that in fact this economy was sliding into deeper recession. In fact they have been unable to do so in the light of the most recently published statistics. Clearly, the statistic I just cited of 5 per cent growth rate for the year ended December 1981 demonstrates that. In fact we are still seeing a rate of job creation in this country as well. As to the forlorn and hopeless statement included in the last part of the amendment in which the Opposition stated that we will never have any hope of sustained economic recovery unless we have a new economic strategy that, of course, is totally unsupported by any arguments it has put forward during the debate. For all those reasons the Government rejects the amendments put forward by the Opposition and by the Democrats. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly in response to a couple of things which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Senator Messner) said and did not say in responding to the second reading debate. I will speak briefly to the amendments to which I have not spoken before and to the Minister's statement on the amendments. The Minister rather deprecated the advocacy of Senator Siddons on an effective and just prices and incomes policy. That was the first prong of a four-pronged amendment moved by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Minister said that since he became a member of parliament he had heard this idea bandied about. In fact, in response to an interjection by Senator Peter Rae that was not worthy of Senator Rae or worthy of the Minister- incidentially, I thank the Minister for his thoughtful response-Senator Peter Rae said that a prices and incomes policy was like motherhood. The Minister was not deprecating motherhood but was using a cynical expression that politicians use to denigrate something that is so obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: We are quite serious that without a prices and incomes policy in this country we are just going down the tube in economic terms. I am not saying it is necessarily the Government's fault but it now has no wages policy whatsoever. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last week virtually demonstrated that with devastating clarity. The Minister said: 'Okay, a prices and incomes policy might well be a good thing in theory but it does not work.' I just remind the Minister of something that embittered me in the House of Representatives in 1977. I did not know that the Minister was a member of parliament then. In that year Prime Minister Fraser had very cleverly conceived the idea of a prices and incomes policy, if the Minister remembers. He had persuaded the employers to accept a prices policy. That was an incredibly difficult task in itself. I do not know how the Prime Minister did it but he did. He got the employers to agree on restraining prices. Prime Minister Fraser achieved an even greater miracle in 1977. He got every one of the six State Governments to agree to a prices and wages policy. These governments were both Labor and Liberal. Knowing how they regarded their precious State rights they said: 'We will co-operate.' I was sitting on the cross benches at the time. I had resigned from the Liberal Party. I was looking at Prime Minister Fraser with some sense of approbation. I do not do that too often as the Minister would appreciate in a flash. That is what the Prime Minister achieved. All he had to do to wrap up the package was to get the unions into the deal. He had the employers, the States and the Commonwealth. All he needed to do was to get the employees, the trade unions.

At that time Mr Bob Hawke, then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, had come to Canberra especially for the big conference which was to be held on a certain afternoon. Mr Hawke had been making conciliatory, helpful, hopeful noises about the conference and about the concept of an incomes and prices policy and a wages policy. Unless I am mistaken Mr Hawke still holds very strongly the view that this is the only way in which we can get a sensible economic policy in this country. That day in the House of Representatives when Mr Hawke was sitting in the gallery Prime Minister Fraser engineered a Dorothy Dixer. I will never forget it as long as I live. By denigration, by personal abuse-which included saying that Mr Hawke was not a man to be trusted, that his word could not be relied upon, that he was a coward-Mr Fraser in answer to a Dorothy Dixer in the Parliament there and then on the floor of the House totally destroyed any chance of a rapprochement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a reprehensible act.

—My friend Senator Mulvihill remembers the occasion. I think anyone with any sensitivity who talks about prices and incomes will remember that. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, might well say that this is pie in the sky. But it is not. In 1977 we were so close to achieving a prices and incomes policy and a wages policy in this country. It was devastating to see the chance just flushed down the plughole for cheap political purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentioned the matter of industrial relations. I do not want to tread unnecessarily on a matter that I know the Australian Labor Party finds delicate. Senator Crichton-Browne asked the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney), who represents the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question this morning about the Builders Labourers Federation. Senator Chaney's answer-a most responsible answer in difficult, delicate circumstances-I believe cleverly yet clearly spelt out the disgust that the Government felt about certain statements of union officials which were printed in the newspaper this morning. We have not heard a statement from the Country Party. I, as Leader of the Australian Democrats, made a statement in my speech a few moments ago.

We may come to a stage-you will have to watch me here, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I know that there is an appeal before a court; I will steer well clear of that-where a court of this land brings down a duly considered decision on a certain matter and in response to that union officials outside that court action, so I am safe in my remarks not being sub judice at the moment , but of the same union say: 'That is it. We will bring chaos to this country now. We will employ the guerrilla tactics that we are very good at using. We will let a gorilla out of the cage that can cause absolute havoc throughout this country'. If that sort of attitude at these crossroads that we are facing now is allowed to persevere the decent people in the trade union movement, some of whom we heard on AM this morning-people like Cliff Dolan of the ACTU-will be submerged into oblivion and anarchy and chaos will take over in this country. Representatives of two political parties made that sort of statement. I know the difficulties in which the Labor Party finds itself now. I would have thought that if the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, could find his way clear to make a careful statement setting out the attitude of the Labor Party to this disgraceful episode reported in this morning's Press for once we could have a bipartisan attitude towards a certain situation in this country which could only help the forces of moderation to prevail. This could only help to assist the legitimate trade union movement in Australia.

Finally, the Minister mentioned that the Government is interested in the control of inflation through the money supply. Some say that if we want to control inflation we should control the money supply according to Friedman and his colleague Paul Samuelson-probably two of the most overrated economists ever to have been mentioned in any sort of history book. Their policies, I would have thought, are now totally discredited. But this Government, together with the Thatcher Government and the Reagan Government, continues to espouse and embrace their policies. I remind the Minister that even those economists are now abrogating their stand. According to both Milton Friedman and Paul Samuelson deficit funding is losing its dirty tag. We find them moving away from their purist line. In all seriousness I asked the Minister to consult his advisers and to inform the Senate of ways to equate a one per cent rise in interest rates with a rise in wages. I would not have thought that that is an impossible--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, could you come back to discussing the amendment and not go back to the second reading debate or your previous speech?
—I am speaking to the matter that the Minister raised in his reply , Mr Acting Deputy President.
—He has not replied as yet; he spoke to the amendments, I hope.

—Well, he spoke in some detail on the matter. I will respect your ruling in any event, Mr Acting Deputy President. I just make a plea to the Minister: If he does not have that information at the moment-I do not blame him or his advisers-I suggest that it might be a very useful exercise for the Department to look into the matter and to inform the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Siddons's to Senator Button's amendment) agreed to.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Button's amendment, as amended) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the date for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Banking Amendment Bill 1981 be extended and that the Committee report to the Senate on or before 23 September 1982.

When this matter was referred to the Committee the time for reporting was the end of this month. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I present the Committee's report on the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 together with the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

I speak very briefly to outline the report. The history is that last year the Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions decided, amongst a great number of other things, that there should be a 50 per cent recovery of inspection charges for a variety of export industries where those inspection charges were to be made to recover the estimate of the cost of provision of those services. The areas to be covered-it was decided earlier to include the meat industry and others-were to include dairy products, edible oils, eggs and honey. Considerable concern was expressed in the honey industry, which is a very small export industry, which led to the Senate referring this Bill, which would have put the charges into effect, to the Senate Standing Committee. It was a very interesting example of the way in which a Senate Committee can operate.

We found as we received submissions from the industry the unanimous view that it would very seriously and detrimentally affect the profitability and future viability of that industry. We also found as we examined the matter further that in fact the export inspection service was not required; that whereas there had been a period when it was necessary for the purposes of international trade to provide a certification of the unadulterated, true to label nature of the Australian honey, this was no longer required within the existing trade. Some countries had required special certificates and we found as we investigated further that that was no longer required either. It boiled down to the fact that a whole inspection service has been providing a certification at a substantial cost to the taxpayer. It was proposed that half of that cost be paid by the industry itself. It was found that certification was not required by the industry nor by the importers in other countries.

It is for that reason that, having discussed the matter with a wide cross- section of the industry and with the Department of Primary Industry, the Committee has now recommended to the Senate, in the report that I have just tabled, that this inspection scheme should be abandoned, that the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill should not be proceeded with and that in substitution there be a system whereby a would-be exporter, for the purposes of developing or expanding his trade with any country that requires certification by the Australian Government of an analysis of an export having been made, can have a sample of the exports inspected by a registered laboratory in Australia. The Department of Primary Industry, on receiving the analysis from that registered laboratory, would then issue the export certificate in the event that it was needed. That would mean that the exporter would pay the cost that resulted directly from that inspection, that no overall apparatus and system would be necessary to provide an unnecessary service-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why had the Department not found this out?

—That is a matter which honourable senators may wish to pursue , but we are reporting on the Committee's findings. The further points we make are that if it is desired to have some random sampling system to ensure that Australia's reputation as an exporter is preserved, it would be possible to do that by an occasional random sampling from the small number of exporters involved. I emphasise that only a very small number of exporters in Australia are involved in the industry anyway. This is an industry which ought to be able to be controlled reasonably effectively. Honey is not really like meat. It is a bit hard to use kangaroos instead of bees for honey, as it were. We believe that the whole system does not need to be as it is at present, that this will suit the industry, that it will save the industry money, that it will suit the taxpayer because it will save him a considerable amount of money and that it will ensure that Australia's overseas trade is not adversely affected in any way . We therefore make the recommendation that the Bill be not proceeded with.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also the Committee's suggestion that when the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 is restored to the Notice Paper for the convenience of the Senate, the second reading debate on the Bill and the motion for the adoption of the Committee's report should take place at the same time. While the debate would be a cognate debate, the questions for the adoption of the Committee's report and the second reading of the Bill would, of course, be put separately. The report has been presented at the time that it had to be presented, which is today. It is for the Government to determine when it wishes, in the conduct of Government business, to restore the Bill to the Notice Paper. My suggestion and the Committee's suggestion is that that be not before tomorrow, so that honourable senators will have a chance to read the Committee's report before the matters are debated in this chamber. To enable that procedure to take place, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report that has just been presented and the comments of Senator Peter Rae illustrate the extraordinary effectiveness of a Senate committee. I congratulate the Chairman and his Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, on the work they have done. What is incomprehensible, however, is that the Government could have introduced into this chamber a Bill to increase a levy when in fact, in a short period, a Senate committee was able to discover not only that the increase was not necessary but also that the entire Bill was not necessary. I think that when we again debate this issue, the Government must report to the Senate on how such an extraordinary situation could ever have occurred; that this chamber could have been presented with a Bill to impose on an industry a charge that was not even needed. The Government has an enormous amount to answer for in terms of the departmental advice that it has been given on this issue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

Department of Business and Consumer Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of matters to which I want to direct attention. The first relates to the former Department of Business and Consumer Affairs which, as I interpret the situation, was responsible for controlling imports and exports of wildlife. I refer to a recent and pending prosecution in Sydney of people who endeavoured to export Australian birds. Following the publication of an article in one major Sydney newspaper the presiding judge decided that the article might prejudice the defendants being given a fair trial. I do not quarrel with his decision which was almost on a parallel with the Harry Miller trial but on a different basis. I would like some assurance from the responsible Minister that the prosecutions involving Messrs Volkman, Stein, Opperman and Lowe, who were charged with illegally seeking to export Australian birds, will be restarted so that these people will not get off the hook.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I want to deal with relates to Australian Government policy on the legitimate export of Australian wildlife. In respect of this matter I am indebted to Marjorie Wilson of the Kangaroo Protection Co-operative Ltd for her advice. The Committee will be aware that a number of overseas zoos are permitted to import our wildlife. I have received a list of the zoos to which we have permitted wildlife exports. I do not object to the domicile countries but there is a contradiction to which the Kangaroo Protection Co-operative has drawn my attention. I refer to an article in the World Wildlife Fund Australia ' Newsletter' stating that a grant of $23,000 had been made for a project known as 'Yellow-footed rock wallaby-a population survey in South Australia'. I wonder how we can reconcile the need to protect a rare species with a letter by the previous Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, which stated that we had permitted the export of some rock wallabies. I have not previously objected when the species involved has been in abundance but there does seem to be some contradiction in terms of policy. China has always been conservative in its decisions when it comes to foreign governments which seek to import some of that country's pandas. I would like information on this matter.

I would also like to deal with another matter in anticipation of a response from the responsible Minister. This matter was dealt with at the Estimates committee level. A sharp distinction was drawn on the responsibility for the certificate issued by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service as to the condition of an animal or bird that is being exported. I feel that the question of the chain of command merits specific answers on the matters that I have raised. Mr Chairman, I am in your hands as to whether you want me to confine my remarks to that section of the Estimates relating to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs or whether you are quite happy for me to raise matter relating to the Department of Industrial Relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Chair is that all the votes in Group A be now passed without request. If Senator Mulvihill confines his remarks to matters relating to the Parliament, the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Department of Industrial Relations he will be in order.

—Well, the latter reference gives me the green light to proceed. I again refer the Committee to a discussion at the Estimates committee level in relation to the Department of Industrial Relations. I raised the issue of the role of the Commonwealth Government, through the Industrial Relations portfolio, on crane operations safety. I raised this matter previously when Mr Street and Mr Viner occupied this portfolio. I want to make my position perfectly clear on the matter of industrial safety. I know that all the various State governments have their basic responsibilities in this area. The position is further complicated on the waterfront because with the advent of larger container equipment the Ministry of Transport plays a role. Notwithstanding that , the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia in its journal Engine Driver raised well over 12 months ago the question of some initiative being taken by the Commonwealth Government through its Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to a letter to me from the Assistant General Secretary of the Association, Mr Vic Fitzgerald. He quoted the comment of Mr Maher of the Department of Industrial Relations who said that the Department ' aimed at co-ordinating those activities for the Commonwealth and encouraging the development and improvement of safety health and welfare at the workplace'. They are very laudable objectives. But they are somewhat blunted by the words in a further paragraph of Mr Fitzgerald's letter which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully Senator, the new Ministry will heed your pursuance on the question of industrial safe working practices . . .
. . . although I have received numerous letters from your office keeping this Association informed . . . I have yet to receive one item of correspondence from any Government Minister.

I simply say this: I have always had a high regard for the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Honourable Ian Macphee. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter from the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen' s Association of Australasia because I think it will be a valuable prompter although I am confident that Mr Macphee will initiate some action in regard to Federal direction on safe working practices for crane operations generally.
Leave granted.

The letter read as follows- E.D.F.A. or other Trade Unions that cover crane drivers, or do you intend having them'? Mr Maher's reply again in part. 'It is something we would certainly take notice of and bring to attention.'

Hopefully Senator, the reconstructed Ministry will heed your pursuance on the question of industrial safe working practices and have the National Labour Consultative Council take up expeditiously this important issue.

Incidentally, although I have received numerous letters from your office keeping this Association informed of all happenings I have yet to receive one item of correspondence from any Government Minister.
Best wishes,
Yours fraternally,
V. FITZGERALD, Assistant General Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —I will rest on those matters.

—It was not my intention to speak on the votes in Group A this afternoon until I saw what I considered to be an extraordinary procedure in that about two minutes before we got on to a consideration of the votes in this Schedule the chairmen of Estimates committees were still introducing information in this place. Answers to questions that were raised in different Estimates committees were brought in only one or two minutes before people had to be prepared to get up and speak to particular sections. I do not think it is good enough. I think it is a matter which the Committee should consider. We will have to look seriously at how we can improve the procedures in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I would like to discuss quite briefly is part of the report of Estimates Committee A, a Committee of which I was a member. I refer specifically to page 3 of that report. The matter comes under the Attorney-General's Department and relates to the services for retired judges. In the course of the conduct of the Committee hearings, we, as a Committee, managed to drag out of the Government a number of rather important and interesting facts in respect of the matter. The Committee, in its report, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee noted with some concern an amount of $32,000 to cover the cost of hire car charges incurred in respect of the former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia for the 12 months ending 30 June 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I take issue with the words 'drag out of the Government'. I believe it demeans the Senate and the Government to have a procedure described whereby a lawful question is asked in a Senate Estimates Committee hearing and the Government gives an answer. I believe that to suggest that there is some reticence in this important parliamentary procedure of Senate Estimates committees is an inappropriate use of language. I ask that the honourable senator give some consideration to being more factual and less demeaning of the Senate and its procedures in the language which he uses.
—There is no substance in the point of order.

—Without responding to the point of order, I am sure that, as I go on to describe the situation that evolved, the honourable senator will understand why I used that term. In this instance, the Committee found that the Government had, by a secret measure, given an unprecedented benefit to a former member of the Government who had for some time held the highest judicial office in this country, a person to whom, quite coincidentally, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government owe a great political debt. Of course, that person is former Chief Justice Barwick.

SPEECH.PARA: I say 'secret' because I think that was precisely the situation. In saying that , I refer to page 218 of the Hansard report of the hearings this session by Estimates Committee A. I asked the question:
Was there no provision made for this in the initial estimates?
In that respect I referred to the allocation made for the car charges. Mr Glare, from the Attorney-General's Department, replied:

At the time we made the original estimate we thought that the car hire would probably be occasional access to the car pool. As it transpired, it has been considerably more than that. When we were part of the way through the year we realised that expenditure was much higher than we anticipated. If it had been a matter of a few thousand dollars we would have absorbed it within the general vote . . .

That to me is evidence that initially the Government's intention was to conceal the allocation and the benefit given to Sir Garfield Barwick. It was a decision made which was not publicised. It was not announced in any way. The decision was not subject to public scrutiny and it was not gazetted. It is a decision made at that time, we are told, by the Prime Minister.

Subsequent to that, we have been formally advised by the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, that the decision made was transmitted to Sir Garfield Barwick by the Prime Minister on 6 March 1981, but it was a decision made by Cabinet on 10 February 1981. However, that does not satisfy me at this stage because, to date, only a portion of the facts has been revealed. A letter from the Attorney- General dated 5 May 1982 lists the benefits to which Sir Garfield Barwick would be entitled pursuant to the decision of Cabinet. The benefits are as follows: The use of a car and driver in the home city with access to car pools elsewhere; an office and a telephone; the services of a secretary on a part time basis; and the retention of the services of his tipstaff for a period of six months. That was the decision made by Cabinet.

What is curious from the Attorney-General's correspondence is that he went on to say that, subsequent to that decision, Sir Garfield Barwick had been allocated further entitlements. He had been provided with a full time secretary in lieu of a part time secretary for the period immediately following his retirement until 30 June 1981. He was allocated his former tipstaff for a further period of eight days to assist with the relocation of his office. So, what we had initially was a decision of Cabinet which was transmitted to the former Chief Justice. We now have a series of further decisions made with or without the knowledge of Cabinet but definitely without the knowledge of the Australian public to the date of the Estimates Committee hearing and to date. So , there has been a continuing allocation of benefits. As I mentioned earlier, they are benefits of an unprecedented nature.
In the same correspondence, the Attorney-General quite apologetically went on to say:
It has also now been ascertained that Sir Owen Dixon was provided with a car with driver on retirement.
A previous Chief Justice, on retirement, was provided with a car with a driver but ex-Chief Justice Barwick has had this massive list of public benefits allocated to him.

As I said earlier, ex-Chief Justice Barwick is not a person who is not well known in this place. Not for the least of reasons, his notoriety relates to his activities on 11 November 1975. We can remember that the day preceding 11 November 1975-the day preceding the sacking of the Whitlam Government-it was the advice of Chief Justice Barwick which was quite instrumental towards the sacking of that Government. He saw Sir John Kerr, the then Governor-General, at nine o' clock that morning. He saw him again at lunch time. At four o'clock that afternoon, he advised him what he should do; not what he was able to do, but what he should do. Once again the approach taken by the Chief Justice at the time was of an unprecedented nature and was contrary to the principles of operation of the High Court of Australia and its justices. A former Liberal Minister, who was appointed to the High Court, advised the Governor-General of this country how to sack a government of another political colour. For that, he receives the continuation of an allocation of benefits.

I will not speak for much longer but, in summing up, I refer to page 4 of our report and the principles that Estimates Committee A has sought to uphold. We maintain that the financial arrangements between the Government and the judiciary of the country should be sanctioned by the Parliament and be totally known and made known within that country to avoid the possibility of a government influencing a judiciary by offering private terms and benefits. What I am saying is that in this instance there was an intention to conceal. One could say that the ex-Chief Justice was caught with his fingers in the till. As a consequence this matter has come out because the Attorney-General's Department had to reveal the facts. It had not intended to do so in the first place.

The other matter to which I shall refer quite briefly concerns the supply of information from the Attorney-General's Department but is related to another part of the hearings of Estimates Commitee A. Since being elected as a member of the Senate I have had a running correspondence with the Attorney-General with respect to the provision of information pursuant to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and pursuant to the power of the Attorney-General under that Act to make the payment of legal aid to persons involved in proceedings under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Initially I wrote to the Attorney-General on 24 August 1981 in respect of one set of procedures. In that correspondence, I asked the Attorney-General to advise me whether any person concerned with a particular proceeding had obtained financial assistance pursuant to section 141A and section 141B of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

On 3 September 1981, I received a very short one paragraph acknowledgement promising a reply in due course. On 1 October, I telegraphed the Attorney- General asking for the information. There was no answer. On 4 December, I did the same thing again and there was no reply. Some time later-in fact, on 22 January this year, almost six months after my request-I received a letter from the Attorney-General. He raised the aspect of confidentiality. He went on to say :
I am disposed to refuse your request for information-
this was in relation to a particular case.

He then went on, quite curiously, to suggest that I would be aware that last year-that is, 1981-for parliamentary purposes he provided an answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 255A, Senate Hansard, 12 June 1981, containing details of successful applications for assistance under the Act.

Being quite new in this place and not wanting to break precedent, I looked for that question. I noted that it was asked by Senator Evans. I rephrased the question to accommodate the period with which I was concerned. As a consequence of the hearings, we have received a chart which details the number of applications made for financial assistance and those which were authorised. Since then, even though the chart is purported to represent an interim reply, I have had advice to the effect that it is expected that I should be happy with the extent of it. I am concerned about this. There is a major difference between legal aid that is provided as a matter of course under aid schemes in respect of which publicly known guidelines are implemented and legal aid which the Minister has absolute discretion to provide, or not provide, under section 141A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. An amount of more than $150,000 was spent, at the will of the Attorney-General, during the period with which I am concerned. The situation becomes much more sinister when one considers the activities of the Government in the industrial relations field, in which it has a dismal record. In the last full financial year, as is proven by its own statistics, those of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, it has not settled one industrial dispute. I believe sincerely that the Government is involved in dividing the trade union movement and festering sores within it. I suspect that its payment of legal aid in this way-payment which it seeks to keep hidden from the public- is one example of its activity in this area. I would like to know why we cannot have this information. Why has there been a change of policy? What has the Government to hide here as well? What concerns me in respect of the two items that I have raised this afternoon is that the Minister involved in both is also responsible for the implementation of the Freedom of Information legislation. No wonder the implementation of that legislation has been deferred time and time again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.
