SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague Senator Bolkus in lodging a complaint about the way in which this Government has seen fit to make certain services avialable to the ex-Chief Justice at a cost of $32,000, a sum which, as he pointed out, could well be regarded as a pay-out for services rendered, quite apart from those rendered in his job on the High Court. I refer to services rendered in conjunction with those rendered by the former Governor- General in the course of sacking the Whitlam Government. Senator Bolkus was able to indicate from the report of Estimates Committee A that during the Committee's hearings on the Attorney-General's Department it was revealed that it was costing Australian taxpayers an additional $32,000 a year to provide for the ex- Chief Justice-I do not use titles, so I will merely refer to him as 'Mr Barwick' -over and above what he would receive by way of superannuation. What is not in the report but was revealed in an answer given to me only yesterday is that the ex-Chief Justice's partner in the sacking of the Whitlam Government is also receiving a very great amount of money from the Government. The question concerning this matter was on notice for quite some time. If it had been answered sooner and I had had it when the Estimates Committee was inquiring into another department we might have had a similiar report being presented to the Parliament later. The provision of car transport, telephone, office accommodation and clerical staff to keep the ex-Governor-General in London, cost $32,909 in 1978-79, $55,379 in 1979-80 and $51,670 in 1980-81. If we add that sum to what the ex-Chief Justice is being given we find that the Government has been prepared to pay those two main people involved in the downfall, the sacking , of the Whitlam Government of the order of $87,000 in one year, $65,000 in another and $83,000 in yet another. It is a very costly exercise for the Australian taxpayers. They have to find the money that the Fraser Government pays for services rendered by these people in 1975 to bring about the sacking of the Whitlam Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been pursuing this matter in the Parliament for quite a long time and am very pleased that Estimates Committee A was able to incorporate in its report the figure to which reference has been made. I am also pleased to be able to report to the Senate the figure that was given to me yesterday concerning what this Government is paying to keep the ex-Governor-General in London. Of course, we do not know what other costs the Government has incurred in keeping him in other places. It is a very costly exercise and the taxpayers will be very unhappy to learn, in these times of Government-imposed financial restrictions- down to the lowest paid in the community, the pensioners and the unskilled work force, with the result that many have to live on a mere pittance-that the two men to whom I have referred are receiving, in addition to their superannuation, between $80,000 and $90,000 a year to keep them in a measure of luxury which, in my view, neither deserves. I compliment Senator Bolkus on the speech that he made this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will take two other matters on board. One concerns industrial relations and relates to Question on Notice No. 2126 of which I gave notice on 25 March. It refers to what may be correctly deemed sexual harassment in the work force at Roth Industries, at Liverpool, New South Wales. The female work force of the firm is mainly of Spanish origin. I am concerned that in this supposedly modern age of 1982, with the Industrial Relations Bureau apparatus available, although we are two-thirds of the way through May I have not yet been given a full decision. I use the word full, advisedly because I recollect that an acknowledgment was given that the matter was being probed. However I am a little suspicious because last year I had a very unsettling experience when I brought up a similar case of harassment of women, in that instance in the New South Wales transport industry. Perhaps at the time I was a little harsh on Commissioner Walker. I found out later that the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, did not pass on messages to me because I had the stigma of being an Opposition senator. I know all that has gone with the advent of the new Minister, the Honourable Ian Macphee, but be that as it may I want it recorded that I believe that it is time that I had a full report from the Industrial Relations Bureau about the victimisation of Spanish women in our work force at Roth Industries at Liverpool.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter is a smaller one. I have referred already to the role of the Business and Consumer Affairs ministry in the checking of illegal import or export of wildlife. Apart from what I asked earlier about whether there would be a deferment of the matter in regard to the four people I named, I ask simply whether I could have a score card giving me the names of the people and the fines involved in this nefarious traffic in the last 12 months and whether all the fines have been paid. If not, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first matter raised by Senator Mulvihill relating to the Industrial Relations Bureau and his Question on Notice No. 2126, I will see what can be done to provide that final report which he has been seeking. On the other matter with regard to illegal import or export of wildlife and his request for information of the names and the fines paid by people in the last 12 months, I will refer that to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) for an early report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department and to legal aid. I am sure that honourable senators will agree that this Parliament, in conjunction with other Australian parliaments, not only has responsibility to make laws which are just and fair but also needs to ensure access to the courts for all those who seek the aid of the courts, whatever their financial situation may be. In order to help discharge that responsibility, the Australian Legal Aid Office was established with flair and with sufficient financial backing by the Whitlam Government in order to ensure that that terrible slogan 'guilty until proved wealthy' should have no place in our Australian society. It is very important that all those who need to appear before a court should be able to have access to our legal system without regard to their disposable income. I am not making a second reading speech although it may sound as though I am trespassing that way.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am concerned about is a matter raised for discussion by the Tasmanian Pensioners' Union. It was pointed out that in recent times-this is what I want the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to confirm for me, if she will be so kind-restrictive criteria have been introduced into the guidelines put into operation by the Australian Legal Aid Office in such a way that with divorce proceedings where no property settlement is involved, there seems to be an absolute rule that no legal aid is available. What I want to have confirmed or rebutted by the Minister is whether indeed there is such an absolute rule rather than some discretionary or rule of thumb system so that those people seeking the aid of the Family Court of Australia and seeking to appear before it can be aided by the legal aid system having proper regard to their actual disposable income.

In the case of pensioners this is particularly important because, in cases where no property settlement is involved, those seeking a divorce nevertheless have to incur certain expenses relating to the lodging of the necessary documents. Perhaps they have to put in an appearance either personally, by counsel or with the aid of counsel which involves an expenditure of money which for pensioners is beyond their meagre means-certainly beyond the small savings which they may be able to put away from time to time. My question is whether for pensioners either some reduction in the fees charged by the Family Court could be negotiated for the lodging of documents and so on or, whether legal aid could be made available to these people, having regard to their actual disposable income, rather than some absolute rule which prevents their access to the legal aid system in such instances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to help Senator Tate with precise details of the legal aid requirements in divorce proceedings; nor am I able to make any comment at this time on the suggestion of a reduction in the fees that might be charged in the Family Court of Australia for those who are in the pensioner category. I will take those questions on notice for the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and seek an early response so that Senator Tate is able to resond to the Tasmanian Pensioners' Union and to any other people who are interested in the matters that he has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter on the parliamentary appropriations. I am led to understand that the Presiding Officers are currently in the process of ordering parliamentary badges for honourable members and senators. No item appears in the supplementary appropriations but I understand that the order is imminent. I wish to speak very briefly to the Committee today to raise a matter of concern that I have in relation to those badges. Some honourable senators may recall that this issue goes back some years. On 2 May 1978 Senator Young, then a senator and not the President, asked the then President whether it would be possible to have honourable members and senators issued with parliamentary lapel badges as a method of recognition, as is the practice in some parliaments overseas. Any member of parliament who has been to Japan is well aware that the badges worn by members of the Diet as they go about their business identify them as members of the Diet wherever they go in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: That idea has been raised by other honourable senators from time to time. The matter has been discussed by the Joint House Committee for quite some period; for most of that time I have been a serving member on the Joint House Committee. My very clear recollection of early discussion on this subject in 1978 was that the Committee was to strive to achieve a design for the badges which could be used as a symbol of the Parliament. Quite a lot of time elapsed in consideration of different designs and of what would be appropriate for those badges. In 1981 the Committee was informed, following debate with various people, discussions with Whips and having shown the design to honourable senators and members, that an order was imminent. That was in February 1981. In a casual conversation with an honourable senator on this matter, I showed him the design and gave to a group of honourable senators who were then present the reason for the great delay in getting these badges as being that the Committee was attempting to get a design which would represent the Parliament and which might be of use for other reasons. When I showed one of the honourable senators the design, he pointed out that it could never be used as a symbol of the Australian Parliament . The design was simply a small circular badge with a duco background. It was intended that the background colour be red to symbolise the Senate and green to symbolise the House of Representatives, but with a common design on it which was to be a background of the Southern Cross in gold with the Black Rod and the Mace crossed in front of the Southern Cross. That was to symbolise the two Houses of Parliament, taking the Southern Cross as symbolising Australia. The honourable senator with whom I had this conversation and who said that this could not be used as a symbol of the Australian Parliament, pointed out to me that under the Constitution the law of the land is the business of the House of Representatives , the Senate and the Crown and that we could not have something symbolising the authority of the Parliament if the Crown were not included. I passed on this opinion to the President and, as I understand it, as a result of that the ordering process was halted. An attempt was then made to see whether it was possible to have an alternative design which would achieve the original purpose of the Committee-a purpose that I think had been accepted by honourable members, and certainly by honourable senators with whom I discussed the matter.

It is therefore, with some dismay that I learn that it is possible that two quite different badges are about to be ordered-one with the Crown on it, which will be the badge with the red background and one without the Crown on it, which will be the badge with the green background. Some actions have been taken--
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not passing any value judgment on that. People can giggle and laugh but the point is that this Parliament does not have a symbol. There is no design or symbol that represents this Parliament. A large number of other parliaments do have symbols representing them. The badge of the Japanese Diet I referred to is a stylised chrysanthemum which is also the symbol of the Japanese Diet. It is worn with great pride by members of the Diet as a symbol of the institution in which they serve.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst individual members might have a view on the value of a constitutional monarchy versus a republic, the fact is the constitutional monarchy is our system of government. A design that does not include that fact and has only symbols of the Senate and the House of Representatives does not represent this Parliament. I do not think for one minute that there is any overwhelming republican sentiment in the House of Representatives. Indeed, I strongly suspect that members of the House of Representatives are sweetly oblivious to the whole thing, that they are unaware that there will be two different badges, so the badges cannot symbolise the Houses of Parliament, and for some reason the House of Representatives does not recognise the Crown as part of the parliamentary process. It disturbs me even more that it could come to this point and that the Houses of Parliament would choose symbols that are so different in their intent as well as in their design.

I raise this matter because, as I said, I understand that orders are about to be placed for these badges. I suspect that in the long run, particularly when many members of the House of Representatives realise what the design on their badge means, there would be a demand for the same design as the design that is to be on the Senate badge. The sad thing is that there is a Senate design and a House of Representatives design. I would have thought that it would be possible for adult men and women to agree on the purposes of the design and to get a common design for both Houses of Parliament. As I have said, I believe the order is about to go in. The badges are to be in 9 carat gold. They will not be inexpensive items. I make a plea that no money be spent on these items-expensive as they will be-until it is quite clear that there is no chance that there will be a demand from members of the House of Representatives for a different badge, one that symbolises what the badges were meant for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into the chamber principally to speak on items in Group B when the time arises. But I have been listening carefully to the comments that have been made on many matters in relation to Group A. I note that some very important comments have been made in relation to the Attorney- General's Department. I notice that in Group A we are dealing with the Parliament, the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Department of Industrial Relations. I well understand that the Minister responsible for the former Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Minister responsible for the former Department of Industrial Relations could not be present in the chamber. But I notice that the President has been present for matters relating to the Parliament. It seems that it would have been relevant for us to have the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) here to make comments on questions relating to the Attorney-General's Department raised in the chamber. It seems to me that the Committee deserves to have his presence. I ask, through you, Mr Chairman, whether we can be informed why the Attorney- General was not able to be present for the discussion of items in Group A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that arose out of Estimates Committee C that is relevant to the Attorney-General's Department. On two occasions I asked why the Queen's Counsel appointed in charge of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union received the salary that he did. We were informed last September that the salary was in the order of $289,200. I questioned, at the time, why it was so high. I was informed that the Department of Administrative Services merely agreed to a suggestion from the Attorney-General's Department. So, probing in that Committee , it was impossible to find out why Mr Costigan was paid that salary. So it is obvious that at this stage of the Estimates debate one has to probe the Attorney -General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Not content with being paid $289,200, this year Mr Costigan has received an $87 ,900 pay increase for the year, bringing his total salary to $377,100. I think anyone would agree that that is a rather monumental sum for any individual to receive, especially when the Attorney-General's Department recommends it whilst the Government's case to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was to deny to workers who have had no rise in the last eight months a $25 a week or $1,250 a year increase in income. Yet the Government can give a royal commissioner 50 times that amount.

I understand that Mr Costigan is doing a job that requires a deal of physical courage. I have known him, inside the Australian Labor Party, for many years as a person of integrity. I realise also that one of the reasons that he would seek a pay increase, unlike many of his other legal brethren, is that he uses no tax dodges whatsoever. He pays his full income tax without using any scheme to minimise his tax. One would think that that would be obvious given his comments about tax avoidance in the last report that came out. I want to know from the Attorney-General's Department on what basis one individual was paid $87,000 over and above a salary of $289,000 a year. We could not get that information in Estimates Committee C because the Department of Administrative Services just acts on recommendations of the Attorney-General's Department. Several other QCs have been paid in the vicinity of $240,000 a year for assisting in various inquiries-the meat inquiry and others. I find it amazing that that amount of money is paid to one individual for a year's work. I hope that the Minister can give some indication of on what basis the Attorney-General's Department made that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened this afternoon with interest to what Senator Martin said about badges which are apparently to be ordered for members of this Parliament. I had come to the happy conclusion that his whole business of badges had died a natural death. I have, at all stages, been opposed to the idea that we go around labelled like members of the Japanese Diet. I have seen them and I realise that they do that and apparently require identification. I think that we are easily identified in this building. Generally speaking, I do not care much for the idea of the carrying of labels and badges and so forth, particularly if they are divisive in any way. It appears that this proposal is divisive. That is the second point that I will come to.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place I want to assure the Committee that there are members of this chamber-I am one of them-who do not think that it is necessary or desirable for us to waste money on these badges so that we can identify ourselves here and perhaps in the community. Apparently these badges will give us some special privileges. I do not see why we should receive those special privileges. Frankly , I do not think the badges will be identifiable by the Australian people. I do not think that they are given to recognising these sorts of things anyway. They recognise the Returned Services League badge because it is very commonly known, but I do not think that other things that people wear are recognisable by people .

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone recognises the ALP badge.

—I do not know about the ALP badge. I think it would be rather unfortunate to be wearing that in many places. I do not want to become party political, despite Senator McLaren's provocation on this matter. Apparently one of these badges will have a crown on it. Presumably, the monarchists, of whom I am one, will want to wear that badge. Apparently the monarchists in the House of Representatives will have to put up with the Southern Cross on their badge instead. I think that there will probably have to be four badges so that we can identify ourselves as monarchists and republicans-and be more divisive than ever . I urge that this matter be taken back to the drawing board to be looked at again. I think that this is a silly notion which has gone some considerable distance and now looks like causing more divisiveness in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief. One of the points I wish to raise was mentioned by Senator Colston who drew the attention of the Committee to the fact that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) was not in the chamber. In some ways that is disappointing to honourable senators, particularly when we are discussing the additional appropriation of the Attorney-General's Department. I felt it was only fair that the Attorney-General should be present in the chamber. The question I wish to raise is one I would have liked to address to the Attorney-General to try to obtain some answer. It concerns Kenneth Derley, the drug trafficker, who was gaoled for 8 1/2 years and was recently released by the Attorney-General after serving 3 1/2 years in gaol. That seems to me to be rather unfortunate, particularly when we consider that currently we have the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and certainly a great deal of discussion about a crime commission being set up. People in Australia certainly want to know what is happening, particularly in relation to drug activities. Derley was released after 3 1/2 years. A question about this was posed to the Attorney-General by a newspaper. He reportedly said that he could not give any reason why he was released or why his parole came about at this stage of his gaol sentence because it was a private matter. Whilst I will accept the privacy of the matter, I believe that it is unfortunate for the people of Australia and for this chamber that more detail has not been given .

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the point I raised before concerning the Stewart Royal Commission. Is it aware that he was to be released? Was it notified by the Attorney-General? If so, were his whereabouts given to the Commission? Is it possible for the Commission to have Derley appear before it so that he can talk about his association with Murray Riley and the importation of drugs into Australia? I make an important point which was also made be Senator Colston. It is unreal to discuss these matters when the Minister is not in the chamber. I would be pleased if the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), acting on behalf of the Attorney-General, could give a reasonable explanation as to why he is not here and provide some answer to the questions I raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the presence in the chamber of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has been raised. At present, the Attorney-General is involved in a telephone hook-up with State ministerial colleagues. There is, as honourable senators know , a National Companies and Securities Commission Ministerial Council, and at present its members are having pre-arranged discussions on the telephone. I think it would be rather difficult for the Attorney-General to leave that discussion at this time. That is the explanation as to why he is not here to deal with questions on this occasion. If the matter raised by Senator Jones is one on which he seeks information, there are other opportunities for him to raise it with the Attorney-General. Perhaps he could seek one of those opportunities at an appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter raised by Senator Colston, I think, related to the attendance of the Attorney-General. I hope that the explanation I have given is a satisfactory one because whilst we have a program for dealing with this legislation on this day I do not think it is easy to assume that at a certain hour we will deal with the Attorney-General's Department. His pre-arranged discussion with the other Ministers is the reason why he is not able to be here.

The only other question that was raised concerns the payment made to Mr Costigan, the Royal Commissioner. I am advised that the Crown Solicitor determines the fees paid. I understand that this matter was not raised during the Estimates Committee hearing in respect of the Attorney-General's Department but in respect of the Department of Administrative Services. I have sought information from officers with regard to the $87,000 in question and as soon as there is some information on that matter I will see that the honourable senator is advised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters. The first is the matter raised by Senator Martin in respect of the parliamentary badges. She said in the course of her remarks that quite a few members of the House of Representatives may not be aware of what is taking place. I say again that a lot of members of parliament are not aware of what takes place in regard to decisions taken by the Joint House Committee because no records of the proceedings of that Committee are distributed to members of parliament. Many of them are in the dark. That is why there are many complaints about the Joint House Committee. I have suggested many times in this Parliament that the record of the meetings of the Joint House Committee should be circulated to all honourable senators and honourable members after every meeting.
—But they are distributed to members of the Committee.

—They are distributed to members of the Committee but I am more concerned about all the other people in this Parliament who are not members of the Committee. As I was saying, I have made this plea on many occasions. Every member of parliament should be provided with a transcript of the proceedings of the Joint House Committee so that they are aware of what is taking place. I will not enter into any argument about the wearing of badges. I have no room on my lapel to wear a parliamentary badge because I proudly wear my Australian Labor Party badge wherever I go. I cannot wear two badges but I am happy to wear this one at all times.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter to which the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) referred concerns the absence of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack ). My comments are prompted by my colleagues who posed this question. I see no reason why consideration of the Attorney-General's Department could not be postponed until a later hour this day when the Attorney can be present in the chamber to answer those questions which have been posed to him. Although the Minister for Finance said that other means are available to the two honourable senators who posed these questions, there are no means for them to put a follow- up question arising out of the answer the Attorney-General may give, such as happens in Committee of the Whole.

Often when an honourable senator asks a question of a Minister or of the departmental officers the answer is not satisfactory and opens the way to many more questions. We saw that happen when we were dealing with the appropriations for the cheap housing loans. We had to pursue and pursue and have the matter postponed until after dinner one night when we got the answer we were seeking. I make the suggestion that if the Attorney is held up-of course we know that all Ministers have other duties-the vote to be taken shortly on the Attorney-General 's Department, which involves the amount of $7,179,000, should be postponed until the Attorney is able to attend in the chamber and answer the questions asked by Senator Robert Ray and Senator Jones. I put that question to you, Mr Temporary Chairman, and hope that it can be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question about procedures which I hope can be explained. The Advance to the Minister for Finance dated March 1982 had, among other things, a special appropriation for Parliament of $ 557,000 which was listed under Appropriation Act (No. 2). I expected to find in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) provision for the appropriation of that amount but it is not there. I have not yet been able-I did not realise this matter would come up so quickly-to look at Appropriation Act (No. 2). The specific item may be in Appropriation Act (No. 2) which of course was passed six months ago. If that is so, my question is: If the appropriation was provided in Appropriation Act (No. 2) passed six months ago, why is the item recorded as an Advance to the Minister for Finance for March 1982?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanation is that it appears as it does because we are waiting for the warrant of the Governor-General. It does not appear in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). It appears in the Advance to the Minister for Finance simply because we are waiting for the Governor-General's warrant for the release of the funds.
—I presume that the money has already been paid. In those circumstances would it not be normal practice to have an item appearing in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) to appropriate the $557,000?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it would not be usual. It is a special appropriation and it does not appear in the way that is suggested by Senator Walsh. I repeat: It is a special appropriation.
—When, if ever, will the item appear in an Appropriation Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not. It appears in the manner in which it does. It does not appear in any other way. It is a special appropriation.

—I am still a bit puzzled by that but I will not pursue that point at this time. I am more interested in what the item is for. It is appropriated for payments under the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act. As far as I know, the only payment which would have been made pursuant to that Act in the relevant time would have been a payment to the former member for Lowe. A question was put on the Notice Paper-it was answered today-about whether Sir William McMahon had commuted his pension entitlement. The answer was that it is not the custom to make this information public. Therefore, no answer was provided. As far as I can discover, the only payment which would have been made under that item at that time would have been a lump sum payment to Sir William McMahon. That being the case, I note that the sum is $557,200.

—I now wish to raise with the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) the matter I raised earlier. It relates to the release of Kenneth Derley, who was serving an 8 1/2-year sentence and was released on parole. I refer to the Attorney-General's statement to the Press that it was a private matter and he could not discuss it. Whilst I accept that statement to some degree because of the matter of privacy, I think it is a pity that some information was not made available in relation to the release of this person, particularly because it is a fairly well known fact that he is an associate of Murray Riley and has had some association with the importation into Australia of a large amount of drugs. The other fact is that we have the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. The questions I pose are: Was the Commission notified that this person was going to be released; is it aware of where he is; and can he be called as a witness because of his known association with drug pedlars throughout Australia?

—The matter of releasing a Federal offender from prison is determined by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Attorney-General. The reasons for releasing or not releasing prisoners are many and varied. In an ordinary case no reasons are made public. It is being done all the time. There is never any mention made of it. I regard it as a matter of the privacy of the person concerned. I would not wish to depart from that in the case of the gentleman whom Senator Jones mentioned.

—Whilst I accept the decision of the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) not to make available to anyone the facts in relation to this person's release, the other points that come into it are the known facts in relation to the person and his association with Riley, who was mixed up with drug importation into Australia. I think the Anoa might have been the name of the vessel on which they brought in drugs. What sort of attempts have been made, or has any advice come from the Attorney-General's office, to notify those people concerned with the investigation into drugs and drug trafficking in Australia to make them aware that this person was released, his whereabouts et cetera, so that if he is required he may be called as a witness? Has the Attorney-General's Department taken any action?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot specifically answer the question. Of course, the fact that he has been released has now been publicised. I would not have thought that that sort of information would have been passed on as a routine matter. All I can do is take note of the concern the honourable senator has expressed and make some inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the votes contained in Group B be now passed without requests.
Department of Home Affairs and Environment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to an issue raised in the report of Estimates Committee B and to point out to the Senate that there is a recommendation from the Committee that it send a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations relative to the adequacy of the present legislation, administrative authority and procedures as they relate to the territories of Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The Committee also recommended that the Finance and Government Operations Committee be asked to report to the Senate on action necessary to bring financial accountability for Commonwealth funds into conformity with the practices in other Commonwealth departments and semi-government authorities. I am aware that I have to move a motion. When I receive the wording of that motion I shall move it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to canvass all the issues on this subject that arose during the hearings of Estimates Committee B. They are outlined on pages 2, 3, 4 and 5 of the report of Estimates Committee B under the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I would like to give briefly to the Senate the background of the issue. The Estimates Committee had before it the March 1982 report of the Auditor-General which said a number of very critical things relating to the administration of Christmas Island and to certain weaknesses in internal controls on the accounts and records of the postal and philatelic service for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The criticisms were very lengthy and detailed. The Estimates Committee B report lists the more significant matters referred to by the Auditor-General. The words 'more significant matters' relate to the matters referred to by the Auditor-General in his report on Christmas Island. The Estimates Committee B report also makes a brief summary of criticisms in relation to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I think it would be accepted that when witnesses come to Estimates committees they are aware that senators take a lively interest in what the Auditor-General has had to say about their departments, particularly if he has been critical.

I asked questions in the Committee relative to the Auditor-General's criticisms to attempt to ascertain what action, if any, had been taken on those criticisms. I will give a very brief, but I hope, fair summary of what we were told. We were effectively told by witnesses that the administration of these territories was the responsibility of the Minister and that the Department of Home Affairs and Environment could not provide us with information regarding what action might have been taken on the Auditor-General's recommendations because it was not the responsibility of officers of that Department. That seemed to us not terribly satisfactory. It certainly seemed unsatisfactory for the purposes of Estimates committees in attempting to determine what is happening with public funds and how public officials are keeping records of certain matters.

The Committee was concerned at its inability to examine properly the administration of Commonwealth responsibility in these territories. Of particular concern to the Committee was the lack of clear responsibility and authority within the Department of Home Affairs and Environment to supervise effectively the administration of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Since the Committee reported there have been a number of conversations, some of which I have been involved in, relating to this matter which indicate that it is possible that information in the Hansard record of Estimates Committee B may not be the most reliable basis for the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to proceed on but undoubtedly that will be brought to the attention of the Committee at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would be grateful for any further assistance you may care to give us.

—Senator Rae, as Chairman of the Committee, would always I am sure be looking for assistance to attempt to make the load of the Finance and Government Operations Committee a little easier, a little lighter and a little more straightforward. We appreciate that that Committee carries a very heavy load. However, we thought some important issues of principle relating to accountability, public funds and the administration of those funds and the territories arose. We also concluded that the Finance and Government Operations Committee was the proper method of operation to attempt to investigate this matter and to get to the Parliament some recommendations on how this very unsatisfactory situation might be tidied up. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee, having considered the Report of Estimates Committee B, recommends that the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations:

The adequacy of present legislation, administrative authority and procedures as they relate to the territories of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and that the Committee report to the Senate on action necessary to bring financial accountability for Commonwealth funds into conformity with practice in other Commonwealth departments and semi-government authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be an appropriate moment to comment on some of the matters raised by Senator Martin . I was present during that Estimates examination and was aware of some of the concerns that she had. I am advised by officers of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment that they accept some of the criticisms and are concerned that the situation should not happen again. Some of the comments made by the Auditor-General were on matters on which they would wish to have had more information. However, there is a history of some subsequent events which the Committee may wish to hear when it comes to consider whether this is a matter which properly should be sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I am perfectly easy about how the Committee determines the matter. Following that Estimates examination, the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment put the matter under study to determine the significance of the issues which were raised. Officers had answered questions to the best of their ability but it was quite clear that more action would be needed. Letters were subsequently sent by the Minister to the administrators of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands advising them of their responsibilities for the management of financial and administrative operations and trying to set out the proper relationship for the passage of information.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General has subsequently decided to send a team to the Islands to carry out some further investigations. I understand that the team is either in transit or has arrived today. At this moment something is under way in that area . I am suggesting that this is a considerable advance on the situation that existed at the time the Estimates were considered. It was intended that the Department would send part of its internal audit team-I think along the lines that the Committee may have expected-to carry out similar investigations. But it now seems that that action would be better delayed until the Auditor-General's team has made its investigation and study and has given an appropriate response.

The Committee has a capacity to refer this matter as and when it wishes. The Department will not stand in its way and it will not resist such action. However , the question is whether the matter is of sufficient importance, in view of subsequent events and the fact that the Department has taken the Committee criticisms-both at the time of questioning and in the Committee's report- sufficiently seriously to put action in train. It is a question of whether the Committee wishes to proceed to make the reference and whether the Committee on Finance and Government Operations would want to take the reference now. As I say , it is a matter about which we are quite relaxed. We want to see the issues dealt with properly; the Department wants to see the issues dealt with properly. It has taken on board the points made by the Committee and we believe it is now responding in an appropriate fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has far more to do than it is likely to cope with without a great work load on the senators involved and whilst it is in no way seeking any further references, I think I had better indicate that, pending any restructuring of the Senate committee system and to overcome one of the shortcomings in the procedure of the Estimates committees which, because of their periodic nature, do not have a follow-up capacity, the arrangement has been that they should have been able to recommend to the Senate that there be some follow-up procedure. Therefore matters arising which are appropriate to be referred to the Finance and Government Operations Committee are referred for follow-up. It would therefore seem appropriate for the Senate to pass this motion this afternoon bearing in mind what the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has said. Certainly, the Committee will be only too glad if it turns out that the audit procedures which have been undertaken by the Auditor- General and the departmental steps which have been taken make it unnecessary for the Committee to do more than eventually report to the Senate that steps have been taken with certain results. But if the motion were carried it would seem to me to be not inappropriate, bearing in mind the follow-up system which has been adopted. I hope it will not involve the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in any great amount of work. Certainly I hope it will not involve members of the Committee in a visit to Cocos (Keeling) Islands. One of the things that I think I can do without is that, only because of the time factor that would be involved.

—I respond briefly to the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). I believe I can say, on behalf of Estimates Committee B, that it would nevertheless want to proceed with the reference. I certainly appreciate the information that the Minister has given. My view is that it would not matter if the investigation did not start immediately, to enable reasonable things to happen. Nevertheless, our concern was about not only the issues raised in the Auditor-General's report but also the question of whether the legislation relating to these territories is adequate and whether it might not be appropriate for the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to look at recommended amendments to the legislation, if it thinks that the present legislation is deficient for the purpose of proper accountability.

—I will bring this matter to a conclusion. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment is not resisting the reference. I understand the points that have been taken. Some discussions are going on at the moment between departments in relation to the legislation. Those discussions necessarily take some time as they involve the seeking of a number of opinions. As I said, we will not resist the reference and I think the course that has been outlined is quite reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish to say a few words on the motion. Whatever action is taken, whether the matter goes to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations or whether the action that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has said is to be taken is taken, I think there should be some analysis of the method of appointing the administrators. There has been quite a lot of Press publicity recently concerning one of the administrators appointed, I think, to Christmas Island. He is an ex-Government member from the other place who lost his seat at the last election.
—He took his bees with him.

—I do not know whether he took his bees, but I think, as I read the situation, those appointed to be administrators need to have a bit more expertise if, as it appears, since 1977 these administrators allowed both of these islands to get into such a financial mess. I say to the Minister that some very serious thought ought to be given to the type of people appointed in future to administer the affairs of these islands.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (Senator Martin's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I raise concerns the Department of Education and in particular the Curriculum Development Centre. In April 1981, the Lynch Review of Commonwealth Functions committee recommended that, if State governments were not willing to meet half of CDC's operation costs, the Centre would be abolished. Obviously, the Government undertook consultations with the States during 1981 and the State governments either refused to or were unable to meet the additional costs. On 30 November 1981, the then Federal Minister for Education (Mr Fife) announced that CDC would be replaced by a unit of the Commonwealth Department of Education. In the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 11 March 1982, one finds in the 'Orders in Council, Positions created and abolished' section under the heading 'Department of Education, Central Office' a whole range of positions is created from 'Deputy Director' to 'Third Division- Assistant Director' down to 'Typists Grade 1' and 'Attendant (one)'. The offices abolished in the Curriculum Development Centre were almost identical.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the difficulty which arises is in relation to the precise nature of what is happening with the amount of money which may or may not be held by the Curriculum Development Centre in relationship to the Commonwealth of Australia Estimates 1981-82. Here we discover that, as a consequence of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and preparatory to the final determination of the future of the Centre, the CDC estimates for 1981-82 were framed on existing commitments. There seems to be a variation of some $441,000 which represents the difference between the actual expenditure of $2,477,000 and a proposed expenditure of $2,036,000. Of course, at the time the Government maintained that this amount was part of the savings the Centre had managed to acquire. I refer now to the Hansard report of Estimates Committees B, C and D of Monday, 19 April in which a very interesting exchange is reported taking place which, rather than clarifying what actually happened, seeems to make the matter even more confusing . I presume that, when Senator Martin speaks of an amount of $33,000 and everyone else talks about an amount of $333,000, a mistake has been made in the printing. Accounts of money seem to have been bandied around. My concern is with what is precisely the situation. On page 29 of the Hansard report, Mr Morrison said:
Technically the money is under the control of the council of the Centre and its director.

That would seem to be correct. In looking at the Curriculum Development Centre Act of 1975, the particular point made in section 37 (1) (a) and (b) would seem to be that it is set down how moneys for that Centre shall be applied. The section states it shall 'only' be:
(a) in payment or discharge of costs, expenses and other obligations of the Centre under this Act; and
(b) in payment of any remuneration and allowances payable under this Act.

The point is that the Government, obviously in pursuit of a particular policy decision, has dismantled internally the Curriculum Development Centre. I do not think there is anything to the contrary contained anywhere else. In other words, the Executive has constructed a shell called the Curriculum Development Centre which remains. Of course, the reason why there is a shell left is that the Government knows full well that it would be unable to repeal the Curriculum Development Centre Act of 1975 and presumably, unlike the exercise in relation to fees, has chosen not to waste the Committee's time in debating that matter.

It seems to me to be an extraordinary situation when this Parliament creates in a separate Act a particular statutory authority to carry out a range of tasks as set out in that Act and the Executive, by means of operating perfectly legally administratively, is able to circumvent the desires of the Parliament in relation to that. To my way of thinking, it would have been a much more correct and honourable course for the Government to seek to bring before the Parliament a repeal of the Curriculum Development Centre Act. The Parliament would then have pronounced upon that and the Curriculum Development Centre would have continued because the Parliament would not have decreed otherwise.

We now have an extraordinary situation whereby presumably we will have some shell of an operation called a Curriculum Development Centre which in terms of finances will still receive some considerable finances from its extremely successful publications. Of course, this adds irony to the whole rather sorry business because the Curriculum Development Centre has been extraordinarily successful in a whole range of activities for which it has become internationally well known. But now the Curriculum Development Centre has been pronounced by the Government as disfunctional in some way, without any excuse or by-your-leave. That matter apart, the irony of the situation for the Government is that the Curriculum Development Centre in terms of its development and propagation of various curriculum materials throughout Australia and other parts of the world is that it has been able to generate an income for itself. Presumably this income will go into the Curriculum Development Centre which, according to the Act, must be used for the purposes of the Curriculum Development Centre.

I am seeking information on two things from the Minister. On Tuesday in Question Time, I sought an answer-I am sure the Minister would have the material -as to the precise legal situation in relation to the finances of the Curriculum Development Centre and what the Government proposes to do in terms of these finances going into the Curriculum Development Centre. Is it the intention of the Government to continue with the Curriculum Development Centre Council? Under the terms of the Act there will at least have to be a director and a Curriculum Development Centre because the Act states there 'shall' be. Presumably, according to the Act, that Council will expend the moneys in some way. If that is not the case I would be very interested to hear what precisely the whole setup will turn out to be in this rather sorry exercise of dismantling a very worthwhile innovation of a previous government which, indeed, in educational terms has been lauded internationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the Curriculum Development Centre is to be wound down but the decision arose out of the refusal of the States to have any financial role in its support . Because the significance of curriculum development extends into the State systems the Commonwealth asked the States to contribute on a 50 per cent basis to the operations of the Centre. They declined any interest in doing this.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Macklin's analysis, as he set things out, is fairly correct. I will not bore the Committee by going over these things again. Senator Macklin's question really concerns how the shell which he describes will continue to use finances. The Centre has a continuing function, as I advised in Question Time the other day. Materials which it has developed, which it is producing and which are being sold will continue to generate some income. That income can be used to reprint and regenerate that material. That material has a continuing attraction to purchasers. There will be a continuing revolving function for that amount of the money. The Curriculum Development Centre Council can continue to perform that function. I expect that it will continue to produce and sell materials as it is doing now. I think Senator Macklin referred to that activity.

I think we can divide the money that is to be disposed of: First of all, there is that money which is part of that revolving activity-I have already explained how that will be used-and secondly, I think it is fair to say that once money is appropriated under an appropriation Bill it has to go to the Council and can be used for the purposes of the CDC. I think Senator Macklin is quite correct in drawing that conclusion. No attempt will be made to withdraw that money or to take it back. There may be an argument as to how it is applied. There will have to be an examination at the time the Budget is constructed. That examination, of course, is proceeding. It has not been completed. How the Commonwealth will move to provide moneys for curriculum development activities will be announced on Budget night. The honourable senator is correct that if the CDC remains then it is necessary that it have a legal entity. That would involve having a structure and having a council. I think the honourable senator is quite correct in asserting that. Appropriate steps are being taken to secure that position, to ensure that the Centre does not go by default. During the Budget process the question of the appropriate use of its remaining finances will be considered in the kind of context that Senator Macklin has set out. The decisions will be taken then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of which I was unaware when the Estimates committees were sitting. If I had been aware of it I would have raised it at that time. I think it is of sufficient importance to raise it in the chamber. It concerns the telephone link between Weipa and the Aboriginal community of Aurukun and how the privacy of telephone conversations on that link is being breached. Most honourable senators would be aware that Weipa and Aurukun are on the western side of Cape York Peninsula. They look westwards to the Gulf of Carpentaria. Weipa is a fairly large town. It has an effective telephone system for intratown communication and for communication with the world beyond. From Weipa to Aurukun there is a radio telephone link. I understand that there is one line only so delays are inevitable. Still, the situation is far better than it was a few years ago when no telephone link was available between those two centres.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now been advised that no scrambling device was incorporated in the Weipa to Aurukun link. I do not fully understand the technical reasons for incorporating a scrambler but I have been advised that without it conversation on this link may be received by commercially available frequency modulation radios. It may be that with a scrambling device a signal may still be received on an FM radio but the signal will be unintelligible. My advice is that extensive eavesdropping of telephone conversations between these two centres is occurring by persons using FM radios. This means that no person conversing with any person at Aurukun can be confident that he or she is having a private conversation; nor can any caller at Aurukun assume that a confidential conversation is taking place. In fact, the reverse is the case. It seems it is most likely that conversations will be listened to by some people with nothing better to do or alternatively by some people who have a vested interest in monitoring conversations on this link.

There are quite a few subscribers at Aurukun. There is a public telephone. The subscribers include the shire office, the police station, the school, the hospital, the Queensland Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement Department and the federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs. No conversation between any of these locations and places beyond Aurukun can be considered secure. I do not know whether the link lends itself to a scrambling device but in the interests of security of conversations every effort should be made to rectify the situation. I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to have this matter investigated with some urgency and to advise what will be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in a slight difficulty here. The matter does not involve the Department of Communications; it involves Telecom Australia, one of the commissions. The matter which Senator Colston has raised is both serious and technical. We will have to refer the matter for advice. We will do that. If I understand the honourable senator correctly he is saying that eavesdropping is occurring by people using frequency modulation radios. I am advised that on technical grounds that probably means the equipment involves radio concentrators which are being used in rural Queensland to open up communications systems. It operates in the very high frequency bands. I am advised that for this kind of interception to occur a deliberate effort to tune in would be required. Because the system is a directional system tuning in would involve placing a receiving system somewhere within the beam in a quite deliberate fashion. Since Senator Colston is concerned and is asserting, I think, that eavesdropping is occurring on the link between Aurukun and Weipa-I would regard it as a very serious matter if people cannot have any privacy in the communications that they are trying to make-I think the most appropriate action for us now to take would be to ask Telecom to look at the matter, to get a report and to try to make a response to Senator Colston on the outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise three matters. First of all I refer to Question No. 2119 that I asked the former Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, on 24 March. In that question I sought financial analysis of the operations of the Black Mountain Tower, with particular reference to the restaurant. I did so because about seven years ago my illustrious Queensland colleague Senator Keeffe and I disputed the idea of the restaurant being imposed on the tower column. We did not object to better television reception for the residents of the Australian Capital Territory but we knew-we were proven right- that the expanded foundation would encroach on dedicated park land. Leaving that aside, I have been seeking, like a sort of environmental Diogenes, to find out the relativity between the operating costs of the restaurant and the security service and what rent the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Department of the Capital Territory get. I mention in this instance the two Ministries. This project developed originally through those two Ministries. What annoys me is that I asked for these figures on 24 March. Here we are in May and there has been no response. I am sure that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will take note of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I am correct in saying that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) is responsible for sports grants. Prior to Senator Baume coming into the chamber I showed the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) correspondence from the Australian Clay Target Association in which the Association expressed concern about the future Budget and the Association's rating in the sports firmament. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard this letter addressed to me from the Executive Director of this organisation. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has approved this incorporation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CLAY TARGET ASSOCIATION
Please address all correspondence to EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR P.O. Box 198, Blackburn, Vic. 3130 Australia Telephone (03) 878 2533 (2 lines)
10 May 1982 Senator J. A. Mulvihill,
Commonwealth Parliament Offices,
Chifley Square,
Sydney, N.S.W. 2000
Dear Senator Mulvihill,
The Australian Sporting Community requires an increased allocation from the 1982-83 Federal Budget.

It is a matter of real concern that the needs of this country's six million registered sports participants are not being provided for in the current Federal Government allocations, particularly in respect to the Sports Development Programme.

Under this heading, financial assistance is provided to national sporting associations for such essential activities as international competition (either in Australia or overseas), the appointment of full time Executive Directors and Coaching Directors, research projects, general administration projects and improved coaching and communications techniques.

It is obvious that all of these activities are vital to the growth of sport at a time when sport is making a continually increasing contribution to the health, fitness and morale of our nation and is becoming more and more effective as an avenue towards greater international understanding and co-operation.

Allocations for the Sports Development Programme has remained stagnant at $2. 885m for the past two years despite inflation, soaring costs of travel and the fact that this only represents a sum of less than 20c per head of population.
In each of the past three years, the Commonwealth Government has had a financial commitment to the 1982 Commonwealth Games project.

As this does not recur in the 1982-83 Budget, sport strongly urges you to support the proposition that $2.5m of the money previously directed to the Games (3.305m was the Games allocation in 1981-82) be redirected into the Sports Development Programme.
Such a move would certainly be reflected in greater development activity by national sporting associations, as their individual grants would become more realistic and useful.

Little imagination is needed to recognise that the present Budget provision is grossly inadequate when one considers that the amount of $2.885m in the Sports Development Programme must be divided amongst about one hundred applicant national sporting associations.

It is also vital that other areas of the overall Youth, Sport and Recreation provisions be increased. The Australia Games project and the Australian Institute of Sport are two initiatives that must be supported through realistic grant provisions. The potential benefits to Australia from these developments are enormous and they must not be retarded by lack of Government funding.
These projects are at vital stages of their development and it is important that annual allocations also reflect increases due to general inflationary trends.

We recognise that current economic conditions make the provision of additional funds difficult. In this instance, however, such a situation does not apply because Australian sport is seeking more a redirection of grants already established in the sports area, than any substantial increase in the overall allocations to Youth, Sport and Recreation.

We seek your support of the proposal and ask that you be persuasive on behalf of the Australian sporting community whenever the opportunity presents itself. An indication of such an intention will be very greatly appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
I. C. HILL Executive Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly endorse that group's request because its members' recreation, involving shotguns, does not involve the use of living beings as targets. I think it speaks for itself and I will leave the matter at that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the major matter that I want to raise. I think it is fitting that Senator Peter Baume should be at the table. There has been considerable confusion among conservation groups. If on the one hand certain parts of Australia have had a bountiful season with an increase in the kangaroo population are there moves afoot in relation to the culling figures? When were the last figures established? Senator Peter Baume will well recall some months ago giving me an interim report which I think was based on an impending meeting of the various State Ministers for wildlife and conservation under the chairmanship of the Commonwealth Minister for Home Affairs and Environment who, in turn, is responsible for the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Since that date a number of conservation groups-the Kangaroo Protection Co-operative Ltd, the Australian Wildlife Protection Council and, most prominent of all, the Australian Conservation Foundation-have expressed a little apprehension because they believe that the ultimate decision of the various State Ministers in conjunction with the Commonwealth Government, is linked with the attitude of the United States of America as to the importation of kangaroo meat and kangaroo products. I think it has some relationship to some countries in Western Europe. I wonder whether the Minister could, in a very short time, get me information as to if and when the conference of State Ministers took place. Were any revisions made of the existing culling quotas? What is the position in relation to the United States and West Germany regarding the importation of kangaroo meat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mulvihill, describing himself as an environmental Diogenes-I rather like the title-has asked three questions. I refer to Senate Question on Notice No. 2119 concerning the Black Mountain Tower restaurant. This is again a matter involving Telecom Australia. We have checked with departmental representatives who are here today. It is not a matter over which the Department of Communications has the operative control or upon which it can give the answer. It is not a matter over which the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has control. We will try to have the answer to that question produced for Senator Mulvihill as quickly as we can. In relation to the Australian Clay Target Association matter, I take it that it will be adequate for us to examine the letter which Senator Mulvihill has had incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the question of the culling figures for kangaroos, some information has just been placed in front of me. I understand that in accordance with the established procedures the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service seeks advice from State and Territory wildlife authorities on the proposed annual quotas for the harvesting of kangaroos and wallabies and on the number which may be exported. The commercial utilisation of kangaroos is regarded by State authorities as a management tool for controlling the numbers of kangaroos on private lands. Those State wildlife authorities which permit commercial harvesting of kangaroos and wallabies submit commercial quotas for the consideration and approval of the Minister. Upon receipt of ministerial approval the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service advises what was formerly the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs accordingly in order that export permits may be granted and exports monitored. That is the procedure. The relevant authorities in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia and Victoria have submitted proposed harvesting quotas for the year 1982. The quotas are set out in a table which I have in front of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps it can be incorporated in Hansard.

—It might be appropriate if we took a few moments to prepare the table in a form suitable for incorporation and if I came back and sought leave of the Committee at that stage to incorporate the table as Senator Mulvihill has requested.

—I wish to raise a further matter. I think the Department of Home Affairs and Environment is responsible for sports grants and also for the Australian Sports Foundation. Senator Peter Baume will remember that last year I raised the question of whether the whole concept of the Sports Foundation gave true recognition to the need of field games. A campaign about this matter was spearheaded by an Australian athlete that both Senator Peter Baume and I admire, Gael Mulhall. Last year we received some information to the effect that facilities were being provided in Canberra. I wonder whether that matter has been followed through and whether there are adequate arrangements for field game exponents, particularly the discus throwers .

—I recall the questions that were asked last year by Senator Mulvihill. I recall that at that time we were able to advise that pro tem arrangements had been made for the field game activities to take place on an alternative site. There was some question about the suitability of the main arena for these kinds of activities. I do not know whether there has been any alteration to that situation. I represent the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh). We can seek extra information as to whether more permanent arrangements have been reached and about the capacity for field athletes to have an appropriate place to practice and develop their crafts. Again I offer to come back to Senator Mulvihill.

—Perhaps I can add a postscript to that. I am visualising-I think the Minister will agree with me-the area in question being utilised as a final area for our athletes at the Commonwealth Games. I know that in some of the eastern European countries the concept that we are trying to emulate is used as a final warm up area before the athletes compete in the European championships, not to speak of the Olympic Games. I wondered-again I had in mind Gael Mulhall and the field games people-whether the athletes will be able to utilise Canberra or whether they will do their training locally before they go to Brisbane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I do not have the information sought on the last matter. Again, we will try to follow it up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in the Committee of the Whole a matter that I raised during the hearings of two Estimates committees. It was to do with the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-Time Training Scheme, the non-payment of tax for employers who took on apprentices under the supposedly non-taxable amount of money-I think it was about $1,500-offered. As I have said, I raised this matter with two departments. A reply has been given in one of the reports to the Senate and from the other department I received a personal reply from Mr W. J. O'Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation. I will not quote all of that letter because the name of the person involved is embodied in it and would need to remain confidential. I will read just two or three lines of the Commissioner's letter. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that the matter you raised is at present under consideration by the Government but I am not, of course, in a position to say what action, if any, might be taken regarding it.

I now ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) whether that action is in train and whether it is envisaged that the Income Tax Assessment Act will be amended in the near future so that employers who take on apprentices under the CRAFT scheme will, as has been very widely advertised by one of the other government departments, receive tax free the amount of money offered.

This problem has arisen because of the ambiguity of the Act. TALK.START.PARA: —I have just turned up page 18 of the written replies to Estimates Committee C. I take it that that is the page to which Senator McLaren was referring. I note that the Government indicated, in the response which is given there, that the matter that he has raised has been judged to be of sufficient importance that it is presently before the Government for decision. At the time that the report was written it was still in that situation, and to the best of my knowledge and that of my advisors it is still before the Government for a decision. Until the Government has taken a policy decision we are not really in a position to give Senator McLaren the definitive answer he requires. It will require the Government to take a position, make a judgment, and then it will be able to announce what that judgment is. I undertake to check that that is still the situation. If it should be otherwise, I shall try to advise Senator McLaren as quickly as possible.

—I should like to ask the Minister, further, to ascertain when making these inquiries if the Government decides to amend the Act, whether it can be amended in such a way that the persons concerned-I understand that very few have been caught up in this situation-will be excluded from having to pay the tax they have now been called upon by way of an assessment to pay because of the problem in the present legislation. Will consideration be given to honouring the undertaking in the brochures that were freely circulated in the Commonwealth Employment Service offices, that if employers took on extra apprentices the amount of money that they received for taking them on would be tax-free? Will consideration be given in those few cases so that these people will not be unduly penalised?

—I think it most appropriate that we try to make sure that this part of the Hansard record of today's discussion is placed before the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and any other Minister who would be involved in putting views to the Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a few matters in relation to the Department of Administrative Services. The first concerns the Government Information Unit. I have noticed, through perusing previous Estimates committees reports, that there have been many inquires as to the cost of this particular Unit and the purpose to which it was being put. During the Estimates committee hearings recently we finally asked whether the Department could put together a total costing of the Unit. It has provided that in the additional papers submitted to Estimates Committee C. We find that in 1978-79 the total cost of the Unit was $86,159. In 1979-80 the cost rose to $155,861. In 1980-81 it rose to $168,000. In the last financial year, it rose to $565,850. It is becoming a very expensive Government unit.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the way in which the costs have risen in that area, we see that salaries and overtime over four years have risen by 400 per cent. I am sure that any wage earner would like a 400 per cent rise. Obviously, the reason for it is that there has been increased staffing and increased overtime. Looking at postage and telephone costs, one finds that over four years they have risen by 500 per cent. Over four years, the cost of incidentals has risen by 2,500 per cent. The plant and equipment item makes its first appearance this year at $109, 500.

I well remember the pledge of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975 when he said that the so-called support staff for the Labor Government was far too large and that he would be responsible for reducing such staff and that Ministers would not be entitled to Press secretaries. At the same time, he promised that there would be no jobs for the boys. We are already up to at least 13 jobs for the boys-unless the Government has redefined their sex! The reality of the Government Information Unit is that it is a Liberal Party propaganda machine.

I accept the fact that Press officers working for a government will work in that government's interest, that they will propagate government policies and will from time to time also propagate the interests of the parties that are in government. We have had two major instances, though, in which the Unit has probably gone beyond what could reasonably be regarded as fair. In 1980 there was monitoring of the Derryn Hinch program and trying to sabotage it. As recently as last March we had a representative from the Government Information Unit attending Mr Peacock's Press conference and reporting back to the Government. I think that that even takes it beyond members working for this Unit supporting a government; indeed, they are supporting a faction within the Government. I think that that is a misuse of Government funds.

As I said, I accept the political reality that Press secretaries or a government information unit will work in support of a government. What really annoys me is the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister in allowing this sort of growth following his promise in 1975 that it would never occur. He has gone to a situation in which outlays for the Government Information Unit have risen by 500 per cent to 600 per cent in four years. I should like some explanation from the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), who is at the table, as to why it has grown to such a large extent. I might follow up some of these questions, depending on the answers given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have turned to page 59 of the additional information given to Estimates Committee C. I note that the figures quoted by Senator Robert Ray are, indeed, the figures given there, and these are the figures which the Government has identified as being the costs of the Government Information Unit.
