There is nothing secret about these costs; they are being given out. I recall that on a number of occasions at Question Time Ministers-I think that Senator Sir John Carrick has done so on a number of occasions-have set out the functions of the Unit in relation to quite a number of questions and supplementary questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry to hear discussion about jobs for the boys. During our term in government we have tried to make good appointments to a whole range of jobs. Where these appointments require someone with an experience in public administration we have tried to choose someone who has that experience. Some of the people have been former members of this Parliament and I think that they have generally been acknowledged to be distinguished people in the jobs they do. People should understand that we have looked for quality, and we have not hesitated to appoint a former Deputy Prime Minister of the Labor Government where it appeared that he was an appropriate person to appoint. We are as prepared to appoint Lance Barnard, if he is an appropriate person, as we are to appoint other people. We are looking for people who will do jobs well. I am not sure that I can answer in a global sense the question that Senator Robert Ray asked. I have had no part in the ministerial control of the Government Information Unit. I would have to get briefing on what its functions are. I have had almost no contact with it. However, Senator Ray may have a number of specific questions. I suggest that he put them to me. We shall find the ones that I can answer and those on which I shall have to seek further information for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of jobs for the boys, I have never criticised one Liberal Party appointment. I recognise that former members of parliament may be very well versed in administrative and intellectual skills to serve the Government. I would be the last person to criticise a government for appointing a former member of parliament to a position. The point that we on the Opposition side object to, Senator Baume, is that seven years ago it was made a moralistic issue by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) saying that it was a terrible thing.
—Hypocrisy.

—We never conceded that it was a terrible thing. If the Victorian Labor Government appoints eminent ex-Labor politicians to positions, I will not be objecting. But I hope that a Liberal Prime Minister does not make such a big play about this sort of thing again.

SPEECH.PARA: The specific points I would ask are: How large has the staff increase been for the Government Information Unit? The vote for salaries and overtime has, as I have already pointed out, risen from $48,000 four years ago to $217,000, which at a rough guess is just over a 400 per cent increase. Does the Unit have more staff? If so, why were more staff required? Why has expenditure on postage and telephones gone up by 500 per cent in four years? Virtually no other section has had an expenditure increase to that extent. We normally look at a 20 per cent increase each year and sometimes less. I would like to know what is comprised under the incidentals item, expenditure for which amounted to $5,000 in 1978-79, only $591 the next year, $1,700 the next year and suddenly leaping to $124,600. I would like to know what plant and equipment has been purchased for $109,500. Those are the specific matters that will probably give us an indication of why those items have gone up by so much.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to give an answer to only one of the questions. I suspect they would be detailed questions on which I would have to take advice. We have information about the proposed additional expenditure of $109,500 for plant and equipment. I am advised that is for the purchase of equipment for a text communication network for the Government Information Unit. That covers that particular item. As to the other questions such as the size of the staff, the justification for that staff, the reason for the increase in postage and telephone costs and the details on incidentals, they are matters which I will have to seek information on for the honourable senator. Clearly they do require some careful extraction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with the matter I want to refer to in detail I just want to support my colleague, Senator Robert Ray, and Senator Evans by his interjection, in saying that we on this side of the chamber would not have been complaining about jobs for the boys if it had not been first made an issue during the 1975 election and during the term of office of the Whitlam Government. Prior to the Whitlam Government coming into being in 1972 we had 23 years of Liberal Country Party coalition government when many appointments were made. To my recollection there was no adverse criticism from the Opposition about those appointments being made. Of course during our term of office we had to make some appointments but it was made a political issue and as a matter of fact campaigns were fought on it both in 1974 when we were returned to office and in 1975 when we were defeated. One of the big issues was that the Whitlam Government was abusing its position as the Federal Government by giving plenty of jobs to the boys and also that the Prime Minister was touring at large around the world and wasting taxpayers' money. What we object to, of course, as has been pointed out on many occasions, is the hypocrisy of the persons who made these statements that they would not indulge in this sort of thing although in fact it has escalated enormously in the last six years. That should be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject I want to refer to under the votes for the Department of Administrative Services is one which I spoke about in this chamber on 25 March in the adjournment debate. I spoke about the low interest home loans which were made available to some Ministers of this Government when they were Ministers of a previous government. During my remarks, as recorded on page 1249 of the Senate Hansard for 25 March, I said:
That is the way the Prime Minister has tried to duck out of the issue, to try to explain away why he sanctioned these cheap loans. He did not give them to these two chaps--
The two chaps I was referring to were the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon-
Because they gave them to themselves when they were the then Minister for the Interior. That Department has now been changed; It is now the Department of Administrative Services.
On 14 May Mr Newman, the Minister for Administrative Services, wrote to me in these terms:
Dear Senator McLaren,

From comments made in your speech during the adjournment debate on 25 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1249) it could be understood that my Department is responsible for housing loans in the Australian Capital Territory.
I thought you would wish to be aware that housing loans in the ACT are administered by the Department of the Capital Territory and not by my Department .
Yours sincerely, Kevin Newman

I would just like now to advise Mr Newman that I am well aware of that because it was in 1974 under the reign of the Whitlam Government that these cheap home loans were done away with. People getting loans after that had to pay the ruling rate of interest. But when these loans to which Mr Newman referred were granted in fact the old Department of the Interior was the Department responsible for granting those loans and both Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon were the respective Ministers of that department at the time they granted the loans to themselves. I was not labouring under any misapprehension or saying something I was not aware of because what I was actually saying was that when those loans were granted the department which is now the Department of Administrative Services was known as the Department of the Interior. I am well aware that the Department of the Capital Territory now administers those loans, and I will be having quite a bit to say about that later.

TALK.START.PARA: —They underrated your persistence.

—Yes. I will be having quite a bit to say about that when we are dealing with the additional appropriations for the Department of the Capital Territory. I will be speaking at some length on that. The other matter I wish to refer to under the vote for the Department of Administrative Services concerns hire cars which come under the jurisdiction of this Department. As recorded at page 47 of the written replies to questions asked during Estimates Committee C, as tabled in the Parliament some weeks ago, I ask:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for the number of hire car companies engaged in Canberra and whether any of the companies are reallocating Government bookings to persons who do not have a hire car plate. If so, are the passengers travelling in the vehicles fully covered by insurance?
The reply that is put out in this document lists the names of companies which I will not refer to now because they are already on record, but the final part reads:
Enquiries have revealed that no bookings made through the Department's car pool have been allocated or re-allocated to persons who do not have a 'Hire Car' plate.
This is the queer part of the answer. It goes on to state:
If any bookings were re-allocated to such persons the passengers would be fully covered by insurance.

So I am at a loss to understand that answer in its two parts. First I am told that no bookings made through the Department's car pool have been allocated or re-allocated to persons who do not have a hire car plate and then the answer goes on to state that if any bookings were re-allocated to such persons the passengers would be fully covered by insurance. That is very hard to understand. Perhaps the Minister will be able to give me a fuller explanation. I want to know how a passenger would be covered and would not there be a breach of the law if passengers were in fact carried for a fee if a vehicle was not licensed to carry passengers? It may well be that the Department is not aware that some of these hire car companies, or one in particular, did at one time re-allocate bookings. I have it on good authority that a passenger was seen getting out of one of these cars at the Department of Defence and that it was driven by a person who used to have a hire car licence but no longer had it. Yet he was carrying a passenger who under normal circumstances would have been travelling in a car which would have been booked by the Department of Administrative Services. I will have to follow this up further and get some additional information about these cars. I want to know how such passengers would be covered by insurance in view of the answer which was given, if they were carried in a car which was not licensed to carry passengers and particularly if it involved a government booking given over to one of these persons who is not licensed to carry passengers. I would like to know whether these people would in fact be breaking the law if they were in fact carrying a passenger for a fee. I have some more questions to ask on cars but I will wait until I get answers to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senate Estimates Committee C was given the task of looking at the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. The Committee was surprised to find that in a great majority of cases there had been increases in expenditure in respect of any of the functions that were formerly carried out by the Department of Administrative Services but had been transferred to the private sector on the recommendation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which we were told in a fanfare in 1981 was designed to form part of a government policy of reducing Commonwealth expenditure. When we sought information from the Department of Administrative Services we were suprised to find that no cost-benefit analysis had been involved in the decisions flowing from the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In fact, there was no evidence available to show whether funds had been saved as a result of the drastic alteration to the Department's operations during 1981-82.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequence of this was that the Parliament was asked to allocate additional funds over and above what would normally have been provided for services under the jurisdiction of the Department of Administrative Services. It mattered not whether the changes involved the Commonwealth car fleet, cleaning services, food and public facilities or other services which normally come under the purview of the Department of Administrative Services. It was rather surprising, as well as alarming, to find that evidence placed before the committee suggested that the Government decisions taken in respect of the Review of Commonwealth Functions were made for ideological reasons and not for economic reasons.

The Government has made an announcement in the last few days that the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee is to become a permanent part of the Government 's operations. It is virtually operating now as an overview committee of the Government. All that was said last year by Sir Phillip Lynch about the objectives of that committee-that is, that its aim was to save public funds-has been put aside because the evidence placed before the committee shows that ideological reasons and not economic reasons were behind the decisions. There has been a major transfer to the private sector of functions that were carried out by the Department of Administrative Services. This has been done in such a fashion as to cost the taxpayers more money. This is not a cost cutting exercise . The Senate is being asked to approve this appropriation. We must do so in the knowledge that the taxpayers are paying more for the provision of services than they were paying when the functions were carried out by the Commonwealth. It is costing more money. It does not matter whether the changes have occurred to the Commonwealth car fleet, the catering service, the watchman services, the guard duty operations of the Commonwealth or the cleaning operations. These functions were previously carried out by the Commonwealth employees.

We heard today that the Government is still proceeding with its proposal to sell off Government properties here in Canberra. One property which has been suggested should be sold off is Havelock House. It has been suggested, I think quite properly, that Havelock House could well be used for the activities of the Australian Federal Police in its training programs, rather than the Government having to meet a very heavy capital construction cost in Western Australia, as one of my colleagues from South Australia and other honourable senators suggested-in fact, the Government has suggested-will be the case in Western Australia. That exercise will cost millions of dollars. We have properties here in Canberra which the Government has placed on auctioneers' tables to sell off to the lowest bidder. No evidence was put before the Committee that to transfer the cleaning function of the Department of Administrative Services results in greater efficiency. In fact, I think there is abundant evidence to show that this will not necessarily follow. Those of us who had to talk with the employees who had been sold over the head, as it were, to the private sector heard about the great deal of dislocation and suffering caused by those decisions.

It is quite surprising, therefore, to find that it will not be until the end of the next year, when we deal with the estimates in 1983, that we will be in a position to know whether the Government's objectives have been realised and whether, as is shown clearly in these estimates, the cost factor will place some additional burden on the taxpayers of this country. One could express a great deal of dissatisfaction about the way in which the Department is being administered by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. Let us look , for example, at the dissatisfaction that exists in relation to the Commonwealth car fleet, to which my colleagues have referred. There has been a grave deterioration in the service provided by the Commonwealth cars. The statement that the Government made in respect of the Review of Commonwealth Functions indicated that, in hiring of cars and taxis to supplement the work of the Commonwealth fleet, preference would be given to cars which were made in Australia. I ask honourable senators on both sides of the chamber how many times they have been driven to and from their homes and to Parliament House in cars that are of an imported nature in the last year or so, since the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendations were put into effect.

The Government's professed intention to give preference to cars made in Australia when hiring cars from the private sector has not been put into effect. The Commonwealth fleet has hundreds of cars lying in the Commonwealth depot, not being used. At the same time hire cars from the private sector are used to drive VIPs about. I am talking about VIPs because I have been informed that occasionally even judges have had to use taxis and hire cars. That is a practice which I find difficult to accept, having regard to what some judges have been subjected to in terms of threats against their security and even their lives because of their roles in some jurisdictions. One would have thought that they in particular would have been given complete security by having the service of a Commonwealth car driver on all the occasions they required it, but that is not the case. Similarly, we find that is not the case in respect of members of parliament and other authorised personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be done in the light of the Red Brigade experience overseas.

—That is true. One can look at the economics of having such a large number of cars in the depot which are not being used. One third of the Commonwealth cars in Canberra are lying in the depots even at a time of maximum demand. On average, more than half the cars of the Commonwealth fleet in Canberra are in the depot undriven, unused. Yet cars are being hired from the private sector. The process, which was begun by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, was supposedly designed to make Government more efficient, more economical and more acceptable to the Australian people. The evidence, as produced by the work of the Estimates Committee, shows that that is not the case at all; that in fact a very unsatisfactory state of affairs exists. Whether we examine the provision of cleaning services, food, vehicles, or any of the substantive areas of responsibility of the Department of Administrative Services, the service provided is seen to be unsatisfactory. We are not obliged to refuse to approve the appropriation for the Department but if ever there were a case for refusal to approve an appropriation it is provided by this Department.

SPEECH.PARA: One could perhaps say a little more about the organisations which come within the jurisdiction of the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer in particular to the Australian Federal Police, about which I will have more to say in the course of another debate. Suffice it to say now that the morale of the Australian Federal Police has never been lower than it is at the moment. The ability of that organisation to meet its responsibilities is deplorable. Despite the efforts of the commissioner and the heads of his various divisions-I understand that they met today to consider the work of the organisation-the fact remains that its work is probably at the lowest point in its history in terms of effectiveness, efficiency and its capacity to carry out the functions that the Parliament laid down several years ago when it agreed to the relevant legislation.

Even within the Australian Capital Territory the establishment of the force is down. The effectiveness of the police force in the national capital has been reduced to an alarming degree compared with what it was prior to the amalgamation. Dissatisfaction among members of the force is very high. Little has been done by the Government to try to put into effect the objectives set by the Parliament when it agreed to the legislation merging the Commonwealth Police and the Australian Capital Territory Police. Mr Newman can talk very eloquently about the problems of other police forces and one sees many melodramatic endeavours by some sections of the leadership of the Australian Federal Police to try to indicate that it is an effective organisation. However, I am sure that Mr Newman must know how bad is the morale in the organisation-as indeed it is now in all of the activities covered by the Department of Administrative Services. It is the case with not only the Australian Federal Police but also the Commonwealth driving pool and those sections that are still in the process of being transferred to the private sector. One might have expected, on the basis of the evidence that was supposedly placed before the Parliament following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that a much more efficient and economical process would operate in this Department. The facts show that that is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was expecting an answer from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on the questions that I asked earlier. It does not look as if I will get them at this stage. I will probably get them after dinner, when I will pursue the matter further.
—He has not had a chance.

—He was on the telephone when I rose, so I excuse him. I wish to raise another matter which perhaps the Minister can also look at over the dinner break. I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, on 4 December asking for a copy of the Marks report, which contained many of the recommendations to which my colleague, Senator Gietzelt, has just been referring . The report was the subject of lengthy questioning during the hearings on the Estimates. On 2 February, referring to the Marks report, Mr Newman said:

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to your request for a copy of the Marks report I regret to inform you that I am unable to comply as the report is a confidential document.

I claimed in the Estimates Committee hearings, I have claimed in this place and I claim it again now that that document was compiled at the taxpayers' expense. When we are examining the expenditure in these Bills we ought to be told the cost of that report. Members of the Parliament ought to be able to look at it. During the Estimates hearings we were able to ascertain that Mr Marks recommended that a further consultant be employed. On 19 April, Mr Mills, of the Department of Adminstrative Services, said in answer to a question from me that that would involve a cost of the order of $50,000. From a more detailed reply later the Committee learned that the cost would be between $48,000 and $50,000 to employ another consultant to conduct another inquiry into the Commonwealth car fleet. Where are we going in relation to these matters? I have been reliably informed that these consultants have never consulted the people who operate the cars, who have to manipulate them and who have to arrange the programs. They never get into the cars at six o'clock in the morning and go out with the drivers, or get them in at 10 o'clock, or midnight, to see the adverse conditions under which drivers and transport operators have to work. Their work is all done from behind the desk-in theory not practice-yet we are expending taxpayers' money on it.

We know that the Government proposes to spend between $48,000 and $50,000 of taxpayers' money on the new consultant, whoever he may be. We may have been told his name, although I think it was with some hesitancy on the part of the Government. I believe it was said that he may not wish to have his name or his fee, divulged, but we do not know what the Marks report cost or what its recommendations were. It may well be that the Senate will have to use the procedures available to it to see that the report is made available. We have to go through the whole of the trauma associated with Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. In that case an interdepartmental report was not made available to the Parliament. A Senate Standing Committee spent a considerable amount of time delving into the recommendations in that report. We may well have to do the same in respect of the Marks report. It appears that the longer this Government remains in office the greater is the number of inquiries carried out at the taxpayers' expense and then locked away in the secrecy cabinet so that no one can see what has been recommended or whether the Government is carrying out the recommendations of the consultants.

That is another gripe of mine, and I repeat it now. When we are examining appropriation Bills we ought to be told what consultants have cost. That applies particularly to the employment of Mr Marks who, I understand, is now Chairman of Commissioners of the Australian National Railways Commission. One of the recommendations made by a firm of consultants at a cost to the taxpayers of $409 ,000, was to drop the word 'Railways' from the title 'Australian National Railways'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the charge for that, Senator?

—It was $409,000. That is on the public record. That is what the Government paid consultants just to get a new logo, to change the colours of ANR and to drop the word 'Railways'. Now we are dealing with the Marks inquiry but we cannot find out what Mr Marks recommended to the Government, or how much the inquiry cost the taxpayer. We are asking here and now-I hope that the Minister will have second thoughts over dinner and be able to come up with an answer-what was the cost of that inquiry. I hope also that the Minister will be able to table the Marks report in this Parliament so that my colleague Senator Gietzelt, who is the shadow spokesman for Administrative Services, can have a good look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I had posed quite a few questions relating to the Department of Administrative Services. I wind up by referring to another matter which I also raised during the hearings of the Estimates committees and which relates to orders that are given to Commonwealth drivers. At page 132 of Senate Estimates Hansard of 19 April I asked the question whether car drivers who exceeded the speed limit upon an order from a member of parliament or a Minister and who were apprehended by the police were liable to pay the fine or whether it was the responsibility of the Government. The answer which is provided in the document containing the answers to questions which were not answered during the Estimates hearings is:

SPEECH.PARA: All Commonwealth drivers are required to obey the relevant State or Territory motor traffic rules. If a driver disobeys the rules he is responsible for any action that may be taken against him.

That puts the driver in a very awkward situation. Who is to be the boss? Probably the department which employs the driver tells him that he has to obey the rules of the road. He may be driving a Minister or a member of parliament who is running late for an appointment or to catch an aircraft. I have been told of a case where a Minister insisted that the driver exceed the speed limit so that he could be on time for his appointment. The driver was apprehended by the police, subsequently fined and had a demerit point put on his licence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish we had that system in this place.

—That may be. This is a place of free speech and where these matters have to be raised. I raised it at the Estimates committee hearings and I am now referring to the answer given to me after those hearings. I am putting a case in support of drivers who are directed by Ministers to break the law. If Senator Rae agrees with what the Government does, I do not. I do not think it right that a driver who is ordered by a Minister to exceed a speed limit should then incur a fine and have a demerit point placed on his licence. I support the drivers in their view that that should not happen. If the honourable senator supports the other view, he can be held responsible for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the Department of Administrative Services should take some action to protect drivers who are ordered by Ministers, members or even departmental heads to break the law by exceeding the speed limit. If they are apprehended, the onus of responsibility should be on the person who directs that driver to break the law. I have heard of another case some years ago when a judge ordered a driver to exceed the speed limit in order to be on time to appear in court in Sydney. When the driver was apprehended, the judge immediately put his hand into his pocket-it was an on-the-spot fine-and paid the driver's fine because he felt responsible. The judge did so out of his desire to see that the driver would not be penalised as a result of action requested by the judge.

From the answer that I am given, it appears that the Government or the Department of Administrative Services has to do something. It can issue an instruction to a driver that he very definitely must not obey an order from a Minister, a member or a departmental head to break the law. If that driver is reported by the person who asks him to break the law and he refused to do it, it is the person who asked who should be responsible. There should be no penalty against the driver. The driver should not be taken from his car and put into the car depot to do menial work. He should not have to do that because he failed to obey an order from a Minister or a member that would result in him breaking the law. I ask the Department of Administrative Services to take note of that. It is a fact; I have been told about it by drivers. It is a matter that has to be remedied as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few brief remarks on the same subject covered by Senators Gietzelt and McLaren, that is, the Commonwealth car fleet. During the hearings of the Estimates committees I posed a question on this subject-I think it was to Mr Mills-by asking whether there was anything in the Marks report or any other consultant's report that justified in terms of economics the decision to reduce the size of the Commonwealth car fleet. The reply from Mr Mills was: 'The answer to that would be yes'. The reason why I asked that question was that evidence had come out, in regard to the cleaning services to which Senator Gietzelt has already alluded, that the decision was not made basically with economic criteria in mind. It was almost an ideological decision. There was no evidence that the reduction in cleaning and watching staff proved more economical than having government employees doing that job. Apparently, in terms of transport, the Government will claim that it is cheaper to use outside transport. I think we in this Parliament are entitled to ask for some evidence of that. I realise that the public servant concerned was not in a position to release the Marks report or to allude to its contents because the Government regards it, apparently, as a confidential document. But I think the Parliament is entitled to see the costings of private transport compared with government transport. Without that sort of information we cannot make an informed decision.

SPEECH.PARA: At that Estimates Committee hearing I also asked the question: 'How many cars are provided for a Minister in his home State?' I was informed that there was one. I also asked, and I have not received a reply: 'How many cars are allocated to the Speaker, Mr Snedden, in Victoria?' There was no answer provided to that question in the additional information. I would like to know whether the Minister has that information available now some couple of weeks after the additional information has become available.

Finally, on the question of Commonwealth cars, we are not arguing that they should be retained from a parliamentarian's point of view because the Marks report recommends that parliamentarians receive Commonwealth transport in any event. But other areas will be cut back. I think this is serious. Every driver I have talked to is considering his future. I do not think the drivers have been properly informed about the exact state of play at the moment. Many who have served for more than 20 years are looking for jobs at the moment. I think this is creating a great degree of ill-ease amongst those government employees.

In summary I would like to know whether the Marks report will ever be made available to Parliament for perusal. Secondly, I would like to know whether the Speaker, Mr Snedden, is allocated one or two cars in his home State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond very briefly to certain matters raised by Senator McLaren. I believe that the time has come in this chamber when Senator McLaren must be brought to order in relation to the defamatory breaches of privilege which he has engaged in over a period of several years in relation to the consultants who were engaged by Australian National and the management of Australian National with regard to the corporate plan work which was done and to which he has made reference almost every time that I can remember during any discussion of the Estimates. Senator McLaren has maligned those people by saying that all that was obtained for a sum in excess of $400,000 was a new name, a new logo and a change of colours. I have pointed out in the past that that is not the fact. I have pointed out in the past that, in fact, it was the work which is undertaken by such consultants on behalf of a large cross-section of the major companies and statutory authorities of Australia. The whole development of a corporate management plan was involved. The whole development of an analysis of the operation was undertaken. The development of a system for the management of the company, including its financial affairs, its structural management, its public presentation, its public relations and all the rest, was involved. I believe that the repeated allegations--
—Is this a point of order?
—No, it is not a point of order. I believe that the repeated assertions--

—Senator Rae, at the moment we are discussing the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. If your remarks come within the purview of that Department I am prepared to hear you. If not, I suggest that they might relate to the Department of Transport.

—Maybe they should be so directed, Mr Chairman, but I am responding to the speech made by Senator McLaren when he was speaking to the Estimates for the Department of Administrative Services and to the Marks report and he was using, as a throw-away line, a further allegation. If it is necessary I shall seek leave to continue my remarks later because I believe that the continued assertion of something which is demonstrably untrue is unworthy of the honourable senator and unworthy of being permitted by this chamber to be continued time and again-the first time, certainly, but to repeat it time and again and to use the cover of privilege to repeat what would be actionable defamation outside this chamber is not a permissible approach.
—It would not be actionable and you know it.
—Senator McLaren says it would not be actionable. Would he like to repeat it outside? I will leave it at that, Mr Chairman. Unless Senator McLaren is prepared to accept-

—Order! Senator Peter Rae, I ask you to restrict your remarks at this stage to the Department of Administrative Services. If you wish to comment later on estimates relating to the Department of Transport in regard to the matters you are raising, I invite you to do so at that stage.
—I wish only to respond to what was permitted to be said by another honourable senator in addressing these estimates.
—I was not in the chair at the time Senator McLaren made those remarks. I now suggest that your remarks are not pertinent to the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services.
—But they are pertinent to a response which ought to be permitted in this chamber.

—You might like to respond to them, Senator Peter Rae, when the estimates for the Department of Transport are being discussed. If you can relate your remarks to the Department of Administrative Services, I invite you to do so now.

—The original remarks which caused my concern were not related to the Department of Administrative Services. Under your ruling, which I observe , I shall await a further opportunity to continue my remarks.

—I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Robert Ray in that it seems to me that it is vital that the Marks report on transport be made public. The entire staff of the car pool of this Parliament is in a state of suspense and great indecision as to its future. The Marks report, as I understand it, addressed itself entirely to the car pool. It did not take into account the much broader and much more important aspects of transport generally for the Public Service. The Services-the Royal Australian Army and the Royal Australian Navy-can organise their own transport, and there is considerable evidence of waste in this area. The comparatively small number of people employed in the car pool are being attacked, it seems, because of the Marks report which has not been made public. I believe it is urgent that this report be made public and that there be consideration of wastage insofar as the whole transport area of the Public Service is concerned, and particularly that of the Services. An investigation into the whole area in long overdue. It seems to me to be grossly unfair that the investigation has so far been directed at the comparatively small number of employees in the car pool who, in my experience as a senator, operate with remarkable efficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised by several honourable senators in relation to this aspect of the Estimates. I think the aspect that seems to have the greatest interest is the Marks report and whether it should be made public. The Marks report was commissioned by the Government to deal generally with transport and storage responsibilities of the Department of Administrative Services. It was a report dealing with a number of matters, one of which was the car pool, in which honourable senators seem to be particularly interested, no doubt because of their close involvement with the services of that pool. I want to emphasise that the Marks report was not commissioned to deal with the car pool but to deal with transport services and storage facilities generally provided by the Department. The report covers a much wider range of activities than the those of the car pool. The report was commissioned on the basis that it would deal frankly with various matters. Because of that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) decided that the report should not be made public. It is a report which, as I have said, was commissioned for the purpose of consideration on a confidential basis. It was not prepared on the basis that it would be made public. The Minister has decided that it will not be made public. That is the stance that the Government maintains.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the expressions of view in the course of this Committee debate tonight will be considered, but I think it ought to be known that that was the basis on which the report was commissioned and the reason the Government has taken its position. The subsequent inquiry into the activities of the car pool has beeen undertaken as a result of the Marks report. It is a separate and discrete inquiry into the car pool. Although some broad decisions have been made in relation to the pool, which have been made public and to which honourable senators have referred, the fact is that that is a separate inquiry and one which has not yet been completed. Therefore, in relation to the problems with which honourable senators are concerned-they being natural concerns on behalf of those who may be affected by the report-nothing really can be done to alleviate any concerns until that report is made.

I think Senator McLaren asked at the Estimates committee hearings about the consultancy fees for the consultant who was to be engaged in the preparation of that report. The answer to that question is shown on page 46 of the additional information which has been provided. Nothing further can be said or provided in relation to that report because it has not been completed. Senator McLaren also commented on some answers that have been received in relation to questions he asked at the Estimates committee hearings. He asked about the number of hire car companies engaged in Canberra and whether any of these companies have been reallocating government bookings to persons who do not have hire car plates. He went on to ask whether, if that was so, the passengers travelling in the vehicles not covered by the hire car plates are covered by insurance. The answer given appears on page 47 of the written replies to questions asked during the Estimates hearings.

I would have thought that that was a very adequate answer to Senator McLaren's question. If anything it really went further than the question. For some mysterious reason that seems to have troubled Senator McLaren. That is a problem which I think he will have to resolve in his own mind. I cannot help him any further. It is a perfectly clear answer as far as I am concerned. It sets out who are the hire car companies in Canberra, about which he asked. It states that there has not been any reallocation of bookings to people who do not have hire car plates. It goes on and provides further information. If that situation did occur, although it has not occurred, passengers in those vehicles would be covered by insurance.

That seems to me to be a perfectly clear answer and to be perfectly correct from a legal point of view. I do not know what Senator McLaren is complaining about. I do not think there is anything further that I can add to the debate that has taken place. Senator McLaren says that he had a number of questions that he still wants to ask. If he likes to pursue those questions, specific answers will have to be obtained in relation to them at a later date. A full attempt has been made to answer the questions that have been asked during the Estimates committees. Those answers have been provided in an additional booklet that also has been tabled in the Senate. At this stage I regret that I can provide no further information to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow up the reply given by the Attorney -General (Senator Durack). Two points arise out of it. Will the report by the consultants ever be released on the basis that we have paid upwards of $50,000 for it? Secondly, if the Marks report is not going to be released, could some document showing the comparative costs of the Commonwealth car pool versus private transport be prepared and released? That may get around some of the problems that the Attorney-General is facing regarding some of the other aspects that are contained in the report.

—I refer to the answer just given to me by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I posed a question to him. How would passengers be covered by insurance if they were transported in cars where the job had been reallocated by a hire car company to a car which is not licensed to carry passengers? My understanding of the law is that third party insurance would not cover a person paying to be transported in a car if that car was not licensed to carry passengers. I again ask Senator Durack: What method would be used to insure the passengers travelling in cars when these bookings may have been re-allocated from a hire car company, which found itself not having enough cars to do the job at the time for which it accepted the booking, to a person who carried the passengers in a car which was not licensed to carry passengers? What I want to know is: What method has the Government used to ensure that such passengers, whoever they may be, are covered by insurance if there is an accident?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the questions Senator Robert Ray asked will have to be considered by the Minister. Obviously the question of releasing a report that has not yet been received is hypothetical. Whether it should be released will certainly be considered and that will have to be judged at the time. The suggestion by Senator Robert Ray that some paper be prepared setting out the information that he seeks regarding the comparative costs is also a matter which I will have to refer to the Minister and ask him to give consideration to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid that I cannot take the matter raised by Senator McLaren any further . The situation that he envisages has not occurred and certainly should not occur. Without giving any specific opinion in relation to the rules relating to third party insurance, the general principle under third party insurance is that people are covered in the situations that are envisaged. It would appear that the information that has been provided on the face of it is correct. In the light of Senator McLaren's pressing the issue I will refer it to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) for the answer that he has given that he will endeavour to get some clarification on how those people would be covered. It was my suggestion that in dealing with Group C we take the department's estimates line by line. I want to correct one matter concerning the Hansard record of the hearings of Estimates Committee C on 19 April 1982. At page 89 questions I asked about the fees paid to consultants are recorded. It is recorded that Mr Stuparich, one of the departmental officers, gave certain answers. It appears as though he was asking the questions when in fact the record should read that I was the person asking the questions. This is the section in which I said that the matter of consultants' fees-the amount paid or even the name of the consultancy firm engaged-should not be a matter of secrecy. I would like to have that matter corrected when it appears in the bound volume of the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee's hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a couple of matters concerning the Australian Electoral Office, which is covered in the Department of Administrative Services estimates. At a hearing of Estimates Committee C Senator Gietzelt asked of a departmental officer a question concerning the habitation review. In the additional information supplied by the Electoral Office-it is quite detailed information-we were supplied with an accurate rundown of the habitation reviews to be conducted by 30 June this year. There are some fairly wild disparities in those figures. We were informed that the Electoral Office is short of money; that it is not being funded to the extent that it can carry out its duties properly. One of the areas cut back on in order to save money has been the habitation reviews. People would realise that any habitation review needs quite a deal of manpower because virtually every house in Australia has its door knocked on to establish who should be on the role and who should not be .

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of areas I have difficulty with in regard to the information supplied; for example, why has New South Wales been so heavily reviewed and some other States not reviewed at all or only very little? I do not think there is an electorate in New South Wales where more than 50 per cent of the people have not been reviewed. However, in Queensland there has been absolutely no review at all . It is noticeable that the Queensland State Electoral Office, concerned with the State electoral roll, is carrying out a major review at the moment, which includes some excellent television advertisements, full page advertisements et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first time ever.

—As Senator Jones said, it is the first time ever; nevertheless, that Office has found the money to do it properly. In Victoria we find that the average coverage is about 30 per cent. In Tasmania, the Northern Territory and Queensland there has been no coverage at all. If we are to have an independent electoral office that is supposed to do its job efficiently and well , I do not think that the lack of funds is enough justification for not having the electoral rolls up to date. I realise that the Australian Electoral Office is operating under one of the most archaic electoral Acts of any country. I think the Government has promised to do something about this by Christmas 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise another matter concerning the Electoral Office. In September I asked whether it would be possible in every electorate to count the ballot out if there was an absolute majority for a candidate; in other words, to get a two party preferred vote in every electorate. My question asked in September was misunderstood and the costing came back as $200,000-odd. I qualified that question recently and I have now been provided with the information that it would cost approximately $20,000 across Australia. I urge the Government, in considering reviewing the Commonwealth Electoral Act, to look at that suggestion . I do not think $20,000 is too much to spend to establish the final two-party preferred vote in each House of Representatives elections. That would dispel the sorts of thoughts which were prevalent in 1954, 1961 and 1969; namely, that the Australian Labor Party was robbed in having got more than 50 per cent of the preferred vote but not having been elected to government. That would establish once and for all what the final preferred vote is throughout Australia.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Committee is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the votes contained in Group D be now passed without requests.
Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity while we are discussing the Estimates for the Department of Defence to raise the subject of the Lithgow Small Arms Factory. Along with other senators and members of the House of Representatives about two weeks ago I met here with a delegation from the factory. The reason the delegation came here is that the factory had been told that 40 to 60 jobs were due to be lost at the end of May. Now it has been informed by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) that 60 jobs will, in fact, be lost through attrition over the next year rather than retrenchments. It has also been told also that no guarantees can be given on this front beyond May of next year. I do not believe that this Government can claim that Australia has no need for small armaments. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 16 March 1982 gave a fascinating insight into what is happening in Singapore at the moment. This country is becoming the region's foremost producer of armaments. In fact, the article states that Australia buys large quantities of ammunition from Singapore to overcome shortfalls from its own ordnance factories.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Lithgow people have good reason to worry about the future of the small arms factory there. In fact, history has shown us the callousness in which jobs are lost through Defence Department decisions. I refer, of course, to 1958 when 250 jobs were lost at the factory when the Army's 303 rifle was replaced by the FN rifle. The writing is on the wall at the moment. If the Army wishes to replace the FN rifle-I believe at the moment that the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is seriously looking at an Australian replacement for the FN rifle-then I think we have to look at the fact that this Government might not give out the contract to local industry. It is most likely to import rifles from Singapore which, although they will certainly be cheaper, might not be of as high a quality as those which are produced by the Lithgow Small Arms Factory at the moment. Of course, there is a real danger that if Australia begins increasingly to rely on overseas armament manufacturers our local defence capability will be destroyed. This will be the crucial point in times of war. I believe that this Government owes the people of Lithgow reassurance that their factory will continue to operate at full strength and that future small armament contracts will remain with local Australian industry.

I place on record tonight the fact that Mr David Simmonds, who was the Australian Labor Party candidate for the seat of Calare at the last election, was approached over this very issue. He raised the matter with Mr Ross Free, the member for Macquarie, who then approached Senator Mulvihill who is the chairman of the Labor Party's manpower committee. We were able at very short notice to put together a meeting of people in our party who were concerned about this matter. We are determined to do everything we can to make sure that the Lithgow Small Arms Factory continues to remain viable and employ the same number of people as it employs at the moment.

There is another matter that I wish to deal with in the consideration of the proposed expenditure for the Department of Defence and that is the methods of payment used by the Department. In my belief, the way the Department is making payments at the moment needs to be carefully reviewed. It did not surprise me at all to see a piece in the Daily Mirror in Sydney of 20 April 1982 which read:

The owner of a Sydney whitegoods company is reeling in disbelief at a letter he received from the Defence Department after he provided them with $20,000 worth of equipment. They say they can't pay until 1983.

Over the last two years I have made endless representations on behalf of a small local firm in the Manly-Warringah district in Sydney where I live on this very subject of late payments. One rather desperate letter that was sent to me from the company made the point that from 28 invoices sent to the Department of Defence only seven were paid on time-I have all the authentication of this-with the remainder taking up to 59 days to be paid. By normal standards, I think anybody would agree, payment should be made within 30 days. I was assured by the then Minister that a better and faster system for paying accounts was to be instituted. Obviously there is still something drastically wrong with the Department of Defence system of payments, if this newspaper article is correct. From the personal experience I had I tend to agree that the article is correct. Most firms, particularly small firms, cannot afford to give credit during the present unhealthy economic climate and probably themselves have large bills to pay. I hope that this is something on which we can get an answer from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) tonight.

The last issue that I wish to raise as far as the Department of Defence is concerned relates to the officials who came to answer our questions during the Estimates committee hearings. The situation was not satisfactory. In fact, the report of Committee D states that the number of undertakings by the Department of Defence to supply in writing answers which could not be given at the time of the hearing were more than those from the other two Departments-Foreign Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-combined. The Committee strongly believes that at Estimates hearings departments should be represented by officers who are sufficiently senior to answer confidently and correctly, with the facts, most of the questions put to them.

For example, I asked what I considered to be a very basic and uncontroversial question. I inquired whether the Department had a policy of installing solar energy systems where possible in order to cut down on fuel costs. Clearly, that question was not designed to put the Department on the spot. I do not think that it required a long, complicated or carefully researched answer. But the officer who rose to answer my question knew nothing about such proposals and a written reply was promised. The reply that we finally received revealed that the Department indeed does use solar energy units in some situations and expects their more widespread use in future years.

I think this is an example of the lack of senior well-informed departmental witnesses that the Committee was faced with. It contrasted greatly with the situation in which we found ourselves when we spoke to representatives of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In fact, both these departments were represented by their permanent heads, Mr Henderson and Mr Menadue, which was very much appreciated by the Committee members. We hope that in future the Department of Defence will be able at least to provide the same level of representation as we received from the other two departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to supplement the representations of my New South Wales colleague Senator Sibraa on two counts. It is fortunate that Senate Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who represented the Minister for Defence at the Committee hearing to which Senator Sibraa referred, is in the chamber tonight again representing the Minister for Defence. Firstly, in regard to the termination or cessation of certain operations at the Lithgow Small Arms Factory, I believe that the Government should be aware of a problem encountered in the Vietnam war. I do not suppose that honourable senators on this side of the chamber would endorse the principles involved in that war. I remember that when I first came to this Senate in 1968 many countries in Europe were rather lukewarm in their attitudes to the issues in Vietnam. Australia needed some procurements from Sweden. The Swedish Government was rather cold in relation in that war and it deliberately held up or did not proceed with a certain contract. Do not get me wrong; it was not a major one. Senator Sibraa was pointing out what can happen if we become too dependent. He quoted an article to support his assertions. At the moment Australia may be on good terms with the Prime Minister of Singapore, Mr Lee, but if at any time he had a difference with us he would be the first person to apply some form of armament sanctions on Australia. I think that, quite apart from the aspect of decentralisation, that is something to be kept in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I also endorse what Senator Sibraa said about slow responses from the Department of Defence in comparison with the dialogue and answers that we received later from Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I think this is epitomised by a case I raised that was documented by Mr Wyner, secretary to the New South Wales branch of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia. I sought a simple explanation about the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act and a payment to a retired painter and docker named Bennett. It is quite some weeks since the Estimates committees met and it is beyond my comprehension that I have not had an answer by now. So I leave those matters with the Minister to transmit to the new Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair), although some of them, I know, will follow Mr Killen to his new portfolio. I assume, mindful of the ruling which you gave earlier, Mr Chairman, that I can now proceed to two other maters.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the group, Senator.

—Thank you. When we dealt with immigration, I asked Mr Menadue about whether Australia had made any complaints about discrimination, or perhaps harassment, by the countries of the European Economic Community towards Australians. This was more or less exemplified by one or two Australians who had sought to take their chances in British and European soccer. He said that there had been no complaints from Soccer Federation officials, but as I interpreted that, I wondered what our Foreign Affairs Department, as the logical spokesman- not the Immigration Department-had done. Unfortunately, I did not ask the question then, but all of my fears were realised, and I shall have passed to the Minister a copy of the National Times of 25 April which contains an article by a journalist, Ken Healy, headed 'Socceroo's Roundabout Route to Canberra', concerning a boy of Greek parentage and the problems that he experienced in both Greece and Britain when he encountered EEC limitations on his activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that it might be argued in those countries that the Professional Footballers Association could be deemed equivalent of a trade union . But I think that that is an oversimplification of it. The point that I take is that the meek do not inherit the earth. Consequently, I should like to know at the outset whether the Foreign Affairs Department has any form of dialogue with EEC countries when we feel that we are being discriminated against. I know that National Country Party members of the Cabinet have chastised the EEC countries at times about certain trade policy, but this is a matter concerning the free travel of individuals. I know that the Sydney and Melbourne Press and a host of people in the soccer field, mainly boys of post-war migrant stock, wonder why our Government is so passive and why we do not talk about this matter to those European countries.

I say this with some feeling because, as one of those who were trade union fledglings in the 1948-53 era, when I was a member of the Sydney Labour Council I voted for Marshall Aid for Europe. While the bulk of Marshall Aid obviously emanated from the United States, Australia made a contribution. Today, when we get some of the fat cat European Common Market countries applying discrimination to Australians and New Zealanders, I believe that we should remind them of our response to them when they were rebuilding in post-war Europe. Probably fate will give me an opportunity in September-October at the Council of Europe to make those remarks in person. But what I want to find out is whether our Foreign Affairs people ever speak up bravely and make suggestions to those countries.

After all, we are always the good guys. We have never countenanced guest workers here, and rightly so. But some of the European countries bring people in , let them do all the dirty work, and then, when those countries get economic problems, they pack such workers out across their borders. Whatever may be said at times about some facets of our immigration policy with which we might not agree, we can look Europe in the face and say that at least we have standards and principles. I appeal to the Minister to get me a clear cut answer. Must we always remain passive in this regard?

The other matter to which I want to refer is related to immigration. Some weeks ago I asked Senator Durack, as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, about the progress of indications to the New South Wales Teachers Federation in regard to the funding and staffing of adult migrant education. The answer I received was that the New South Wales Government and the Teachers Federation were remiss in that a copy of a statement by Mr Justice Dey of 28 August 1981 had not arrived. I have in my possession here a copy of a letter sent to Mr Macphee dated 30 April, under the signature of Jennie George, General Secretary. It is reinforced by several telephone conversations that I have had with the Federation's organiser, Alderman Peter Woods, a close associate of mine who handles this section of the Teachers Federation operation, which refuted that and pointed out that way back in February the Federation had clarified this point. Be that as it may, on 30 April it again responded with the information. I think that in the light of that I am entitled to ask how Senator Durack was given a bum steer in relation to that answer to me. In view of the fact that the Department has apparently now got the real score on this matter, what sort of a response am I able to get?

Another matter relates to a score card I got on people who had transgressed our criminal code and were facing deportation. I am interested in developments in relation to Brett Collins and Greg Stone. I admit that the Department has given me a lengthy and comprehensive list but I am curious about the position in regard to Stone and Brett Collins. I will not hold up the Committee by giving my reasons but I think they will be known to a number of people. I think the Minister will appreciate that since we had the Estimates committee hearings things have happened. I refer to a recent issue of the Australian Financial Review in which certain remarks are attributed to the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee). I know him well enough from his involvement in his other portfolios to know that he is not a man with a hatred of trade unions. However, I noticed in the middle of this article that someone had raised the question about pommy shop stewards, a term applied to people who have been much maligned. I suppose it beats using somebody's particular name. The article stated that Mr Macphee had said that when he left the Immigration portfolio he left a policy which would not allow too many of those characters to enter Australia. I think that is a rather sweeping statement . I know what the family reunion scheme is. I know what job skills are. I would like an assurance that because somebody happened to be active on the work shop floor in Britain it would not mean he was not wanted here. After all, we are not ashamed of the Tolpuddle Martyrs saga and we are not ashamed of the Eureka Stockade. I could think of a few other groups of people who have also been sent out here and who have clashed with authority. But that is not the Ian Macphee I know. It is probably a journalistic error. I would just like that situation to be clarified.

I just jump back again to the Defence Ministry. I have hammered this point repeatedly. As the Royal Navy has released papers on certain aspects of campaigns in World War II, I wonder whether we are perfectly satisfied that the details have been released about the full circumstances of the sinking of HMAS Sydney. I refer to a book by the British author Montgomery. Several former members of the German Navy have disputed some reference in the book. I think that is a matter on which I should get some information because recently the Royal Navy released papers about the unfortunate British admiral who did not fire on the remnants of the Vichy fleet as it was passing Gibraltar and probably the papers that were released removed the particular stigma on him. Perhaps it is not impossible to ask whether we can get something of that nature as far as that situation is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised relating to Estimates Committee D. Firstly I refer to the comments of Senator Sibraa on the Lithgow Small Arms Factory. I have no information here tonight that would enable me to deal with the matter that was referred to by Senator Sibraa but I will seek an early answer from the Defence Support ministry on the matters that he has raised.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the payment of accounts is concerned, I am informed that there is no general difficulty with regard to the payment processes and as far as the Department is aware the system is functioning normally. I do understand that around about August-September 1981 there was some difficulty with the computer. That may be around the time that was referred to by Senator Sibraa as being of some difficulty. But all departments are urged not to have late payments. The usual practices and procedures are such that late payments should be avoided. If there are particular difficulties for any reason I am sure that the responsible Minister would like to hear about them and endeavour to overcome the delays because we do understand that anyone, whether he be in a small or large business , who is a supplier to the Government is entitled to receive early payment and settlement of the accounts that are due for payment.

If there are particular instances where information may be given that would facilitate payment-I know that Senator Sibraa has said that he has had to attend to this himself for constituents-that is one way to overcome the problem. We would certainly want to hear of any general difficulty that is being experienced .

The matter concerning the officials who attended the Committee hearing has been raised. I noted that in the Estimates Committee report reference was made to this matter. Perhaps there are differences in the way in which departments are able to present themselves. I think it would be accepted that the Department of Defence is a very large department. It is very specialised and is segregated in its duties. An enormous number of people would need to be in attendance at any particular time to deal with all of the requests. It is interesting to note that the committees had different views about the number of people who ought to attend and the way in which Senate Estimates committees could be assisted by officials.

The Department of Finance, in its guidelines for the preparation of explanatory notes for the Estimates committees, which were issued in January of this year to the departments, did advise the departments that they should ensure that sufficient advisers were available at committee hearings in order to answer as many questions as possible, thereby minimising the need to provide supplementary information at a later stage. It does require a lot of departmental work if the officers are unable to deal with detailed questions. I think it would be agreed that in the great majority of instances the Estimates committees can be provided with answers to many of the questions even though they may be of a detailed nature.

The Department of Finance has drawn attention to the fact that the functions of some departments by their nature-for example, the Department of Defence-may attract a wide range of questions, very different types of questions and a line of questioning which may result in a question being asked which is remote from the matter originally raised. I think that in that sense Estimates committees are of great value. This may result in a written response being required. I am sure it is agreed that where any of the departments have offered to provide written responses these are dealt with as completely as possible to assist the committee concerned.

The Committee did make some further observations in support of its comments with regard to the level of the officers and the range of the officers who attended. Perhaps it could be noted at this stage that two other committees- Committee A and Committee H-were concerned that too many officers are required to attend Estimates committees. In an attempt to reduce the officers attending it has been suggested that if notice were given to departments of the committee' s interests appropriately briefed advisers could attend. This suggestion appears to have the endorsement of committees A, D and H. So we do have different views of committees. I accept that the committees wish to ensure that officers are present who are able to deal with their questions. The secretary or the head of the department is not always the person who is able to deal with every detailed question of a specialised nature. Those of us who have been present at an Estimates committee hearing concerning the Department of Defence would recognise that a very wide range of officers, civilian and military, do attend and that the information that is given is given freely. Where a question has to be taken on notice and information has to be supplied, every effort is made to do this.

Senator Sibraa referred to the matter of solar installation. In this instance it was necessary for the Department of Defence to refer the matter to the then Department of Housing and Construction, and I think the Department of Administrative Services, to get an answer. If further information is required on that same subject I will see that the new Minister for Defence receives notice of the matter raised by Senator Sibraa on this occasion.

Senator Mulvihill referred to a number of matters, including a Royal Australian Navy book. I believe the matter which he raised concerns a letter which is under consideration for reply by the Minister. I will see whether a reply can be facilitated. He also expressed the hope that the Department of Foreign Affairs makes it clear to the European Economic Community that on any occasion we feel discrimination is shown by it against Australians, we should state our objection very strongly. I can assume only that the Department of Foreign Affairs would do so in individual cases, but perhaps I should see that Senator Mulvihill is fully briefed before he goes to the Council of Europe. If we are able to facilitate the passing of any information to him or cite particular instances in the course of briefing him we shall do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might finish up in the Bastille.

— The honourable senator would never know where he might finish up but as long as he comes back safely to work for the migrants of Australia they will be very happy. The honourable senator has incorporated in Hansard the letter form the New South Wales Teachers Federation and that will be drawn to the Minister's attention again.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some information concerning certain immigration matters that the honourable senator has raised. For instance, he asked what had been the reaction of the New Zealand Government concerning the deportation of Glen Stone and Brett Collins. I am advised that the New Zealand Minister for Immigration has decided that Mr Stone is not to be readmitted to New Zealand. Our Minister is currently reconsidering the question of Mr Stone's deportation in the light of the recommendation by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that the deportation order against him be revoked if he cannot be deported to New Zealand.

With regard to Mr Collins, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal affirmed the deportation order. Mr Collins appealed successfully to the Federal Court on a question of law and the matter was remitted to the AAT for re-hearing on 10 October 1981. I understand that the Minister is now considering Mr Collins's position and I will endeavour to provide early advice to the honourable senator about that appeal.

The honourable senator also referred to the staffing of the Adult Migration Education Service in New South Wales. The report of the working party, which included representation by the New South Wales Teachers Federation, has been passed to working party members for their consideration. The report, with the views of the members, will be considered by the Minister when it has been received. We are not aware that Judge Dey's decision has been received, but the matter will be followed up and I will see that the honourable senator is advised . Also, I will endeavour to obtain information concerning any other matters that he has raised.

As far as the use of the term 'pommie shop steward' is concerned, I will ask the Minister whether that was an accurate report of any comment that he made. No doubt he will have advice to give us on that subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of remarks about the estimates for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs before Senator Mulvihill raises other issues. One matter on which I spoke at length in the Senate after the Estimates committees hearings of last year concerned the long and frustrating delays experienced by British people who wish to visit, or apply to migrate to Australia. Mr Menadue, the departmental head, agreed that the delays were not acceptable and said that consideration was being given to improving the situation. I can understand that an intending migrant would face some delay while an application was being processed, but to have to wait three or four months before even the first interview is arranged, is appalling. I particularly believe that there is no excuse for such excessive delays when it is clear that the migrant has a skill that is desperately required in Australia or it is imperative that a family member be reunited with his of her family.

SPEECH.PARA: An article in the Australian Financial Review of 10 February 1982 describes the present situation at Australia House in detail. That article states:
BHP's general manager of personnel, Mr Ron Wallace, said while the company had received . . . co-operation from DIEA,
The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-

We cannot help feeling that there are not enough staff in the department to handle the volume of migration being carried out. The resultant delays make things difficult for both employers and prospective employees.

Last year BHP launched a recruitment drive and placed two advertisments in the British national press which drew 17,000 inquires. By June last year the company had selected 400 potential employees. However, when this article was written- that is on 10 February 1982-only 180 had arrived and the prospects for getting more people out did not seem bright. The staff shortage extends also to the visa section. In fact, an article in the Canberra Times of 5 February 1982 claims that applicants for visas have to wait up to four weeks because of drastic staff reduction. Australia House is getting a very bad name for being inefficient, slow and unco-operative. I would not be surprised if a number of potential visitors are discouraged from travelling to Australia because of the delays and difficulties experienced in obtaining a visa. The Government must show some flexibility towards staff ceilings in the Department, particularly with respect to our officers in the United Kingdom. In any of the remarks that I have made, I do not wish it to be interpreted that the people who are working in Australia House have been inefficient. We receive repeated complaints-I know that a number of members and senators are receiving them-because the staff ceiling situation is impossible with the number of applications being made at present for migration to Australia and Australian visas. If the whole section of our High Commission in London is to operate efficiently, what is needed is a complete review and overhaul of the visa application and migrant inquiry section.

I would again like to point out the Committee's appreciation of the fact that Mr Menadue, the permanent head of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, was present at our Estimates Committee hearings. I was particularly pleased because it gave me an opportunity to ask him his opinion about the present situation in our Embassy in Beirut. He had only recently returned from that country. The situation is that the embassy is located in west Beirut, which makes it almost impossible for christian Lebanese living in east Beirut to get to the embassy. The short trip is just too dangerous an undertaking for most of the christians to consider. They are then faced with the alternative of travelling to Damascus. The journey is uncomfortable, long and, again, hazardous .
