Furthermore, when they reach Damascus they believe that their applications are prejudiced because local staff in the embassy in Damascus do not treat christian Lebanese applicants as fairly as they should. The point that they are making is that they are discriminated against. I visited our Embassy in Damascus. I talked to the Australian Immigration people and found them to be very co-operative. I talked to the locally employed staff and their explanation of the situation was certainly acceptable to me. However, an increasing number of christians in both Lebanon and Australia are complaining of what they believe is prejudice shown against them by the locally employed staff at our embassy in Damascus. I made this point to Mr Menadue. He admitted that he had received a number of complaints about the situation. This Government must do something to improve the position of the christian Lebanese who are effectively being denied the right to apply to migrate to Australia that is available to other people around the world .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of Estimates Committee C I will speak briefly to the report relating to the Departments of Defence, Foreign Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is my intention not to go through the report from A to Z but just to consider one or two of the recommendations or comments that have been made. Page 2 of the report refers to the seniority and expertise of departmental witnesses. I note that other members of the Committee have spoken about this and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has responded. The only point I wish to make in regard to this matter is that there is no criticism of the number of departmental witnesses who attend. I reiterate what was expressed by a committee in October 1976; namely, that the departmental people who come before the Estimates committees should be of a breadth of knowledge and experience not necessarily available to officers at lower levels. During the committee hearings one or two points were made that it was somewhat surprising that questions asked could not be answered at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time I want to commend the departments and the departmental staff who have participated in the Estimates committees for their expertise. I am talking now about the preparation of documents that have been brought before the Estimates committees that no doubt have made their whole proceedings and hearings much more efficient. I believe that the criticisms that have been made in regard to the giving of evidence are of a nature that can be overcome with liaison between the departments and the committees.

It is not my intention to take up the time of the Committee but there is a point that, as Chairman of Estimates Committee D, I must bring forward. I refer to the evidence relating to overseas property which was mentioned on page 6 of the report. Firstly, I want to say that it is not the right or the intention of the Committee to come to a decision. But it believes that the administrative arrangements in relation to overseas property should be considered. Before I refer to the points that have been raised in the report I move:
That the Committee, having considered the report of Estimates Committee D, recommends that the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations:
A review of administrative arrangements in relation to the purchase, construction and maintenance of overseas property.

The Committee has not taken a decision but in the taking of evidence a situation arose which it believes should be further investigated. We believe that a committee of the Senate is the proper organisation to review it. In referring to overseas property, the Committee said:

Overseas property, while occupied in the main by the Department of Foreign Affairs, is maintained by the Department of Administrative Services. While evidence was given that the two departments maintained close liaison, the Head of the Department of Foreign Affairs pointed out that on occasions there were certain practical difficulties.
It was stated in the evidence:

It is the Minister for Foreign Affairs who is responsible for the wellbeing at posts. The wellbeing of individuals at posts has very much to do with the state of upkeep of their apartments, whether there is enough money for regular maintenance, whether, for example, there is enough money for maintenance in Moscow to keep the heaters going and in Jakarta to keep the refrigerators going. Yet that is the ministerial responsibility of somebody else, and that can be a problem.
That evidence appears at page 157 of Hansard. The Committee considered the situation and stated:

Additional problems may result when accommodation overseas is designed to standards suitable for Australia but not necessarily suitable for the particular conditions encountered overseas (e.g. see Hansard, p. 157). The Department of Foreign Affairs, with personnel on the spot, may be better situated to provide an input of local knowledge, and to employ local architects and tradesmen where necessary.
. . . The Committee recommends that such a review be undertaken by the Finance and Government Operations Committee.

The Committee understands that there have been, for want of another expression, two departmental inquiries into the aspect of who should be responsible for the wellbeing of buildings and capital installations belonging to the Australian Government overseas, whether it be the Department of Foreign Affairs or the Department of Administrative Services. Certainly, there is sufficient evidence to indicate that the matter should be looked at very thoroughly once again. Australian ambassadors apparently do not have the responsibility of maintaining the wellbeing of staff in Australian dwellings. I have noted that the Australian Embassy in Cairo is in a poor state of repair. The value of an Australian asset is being allowed to dissipate-

TALK.START.PARA: —So is Parliament House.

—Yes, perhaps so, but all I am saying is that Australian investments overseas in property should be properly looked after. The committee members and I wonder whether the organisation is able to manage an efficient operation. One could go on at length, but I have made the recommendation that this matter should be considered. Whilst the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is a hard-worked committee and two departmental committees have been looking at it, the Committee members and I believe that it should review the matter. We are not making decisions; we are merely recommending that the matter be reviewed in the interest of Australian assets overseas and the Department of Foreign Affairs staff who man these places .

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I refer to the matters relating to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Once again we commend that Department for the way in which it has presented evidence and make brief reference to the new migrant selection scheme. The Committee intends to maintain a watching brief on preparations for the new migrant selection scheme and to continue to review it to see that it is kept in very good condition. We realise that the number of migrants will increase this year. I think there will be an increase of some 10 per cent to 13 per cent which means that we will see some 125,000 migrants coming to Australia. It is the intention of this Committee to continue to oversee the operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the recommendation from Senate Estimates Committee D. The Department of Finance makes the comment on this recommendation that the one hundred and seventy-second report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts presented in November 1978 concerned the financing and administration of property owned or leased overseas by the Commonwealth Government. Recommendation one of that report was that the function of administering overseas property should be under the control of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting the Government's response on 18 September 1980, the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr McLeay, pointed out that such proposals are matters for the Prime Minister but that administrative arrangements are reviewed from time to time and the Committee's views would be taken into account. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wrote to the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, on the matter on 6 November 1980 advising him that he had concluded that it would be preferable not to alter the present arrangements at that stage. The Prime Minister took into account the numerous changes in portfolio responsibility for the function over the years and measures for improved co-ordination between the Department of Administrative Services and departments with overseas operations. Those measures include the secondment of officers from relevant departments to the Overseas Property Office, strengthening the oversight of property matters by senior staff in relevant departments and the delegation of authority to heads of missions.

That is the comment from the Department of Finance which related to the discussion in the Senate Estimates Committee hearing. I have noted the comments made this evening by Senator Kilgariff. I am sure that Senator Peter Rae, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, also would wish to make some comments on this recommendation. But I simply point out the comments referring to that earlier report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. As I have noted, there have been other reviews of this from time to time. It seems that it is one of those things that people will keep reviewing and talking about. Perhaps it is timely that some other investigations of the matter be undertaken. However, I will leave the matter with those comments and I will be interested to hear Senator Peter Rae's comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier in relation to another motion for a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the Committee is certainly not seeking further references . However, until we get some form of reorganisation of the Senate committee structure the position is that the Estimates committees can only achieve follow up from a permanent or standing committee by a reference through the Senate of a matter which concerns such a committee to the appropriate standing committee. In this sort of case the Finance and Government Operations Committee has been regarded as the appropriate committee. I therefore suggest that it is an appropriate matter for the Senate to approve on the basis that the Estimates Committee wished to have the matter pursued.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that, however, I point to the fact that not only has there been the report in 1978 by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts but also there has been another inquiry by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. There has been some hot contention and difference of opinion between the Department of Foreign Affairs and other sections of government on what is the appropriate method of managing overseas properties. The extent to which it would be appropriate to reopen the whole inquiry or to find out what matters have changed since 1978 would obviously have to be taken into account by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations when it considers-if it receives this reference-what is the proper way to go about dealing with the reference. I suggest to honourable senators that it is appropriate that the Senate accept the motion arising from the Estimates Committee and refer the matter. Then it will be up to the Finance and Government Operations Committee to determine how it goes about the matter.
Motion (Senator Kilgariff's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to formalise my earlier speech by asking leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of a communication sent by the general Secretary of the New South Wales Teachers Federation to the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in relation to migrant education, staffing and funding. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has seen it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
30 April 1982 The Hon. Ian Macphee,
Minister for Immigration,
and Ethnic Affairs,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Mr Macphee,

Federation is most disturbed that there has been no resolution of the important problem relating to the funding and staffing of Adult Migrant Education that was considered by the working party set up last year at the instigation of yourself, the New South Wales Minister for Education and this Federation.

Federation is disturbed to hear that this matter will not be considered because your Department alleges that certain information was not placed before it. A copy of Mr Justice Dey's statement of 28 August 1981 was forwarded as requested some months ago. You now state that an announcement will not be made until this statement is received.

An Officer of this Federation, Peter Woods, phoned your Department in February of this year enquiring as to when the Government would be making a response and was told that the report was to be presented to you in order that it could be dealt with in the week beginning 9 March 1982. Your Department did not indicate at that time that Mr Justice Dey's statement had not been received. Indeed this Federation would see it as somewhat irrelevant to the matters under consideration, whilst at the same time acknowledging that it is considerably supportive of the contention of this Federation that funding and staffing of the Adult Migrant Education Programme has been significantly inadequate.

Accordingly, a further copy of Mr Justice Dey's statement is attached and it would be hoped that your Government will now expeditiously deal with the matters in dispute and promptly rectify the obvious deficiencies within this most important area of public concern.
Yours sincerely,
JENNIE GEORGE General Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —There are other matters to which I want to refer. With the advent of Mr Hodges as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs there is a sort of limbo, as it were, in relation to matters on which the Committee on the Determination of Refugee Status has probably made positive evaluations. I have in mind several Bolivians, one who had the backing of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, another who had the backing of the Australian Railways Union and a third, a Chilean, who had backing from the bus employees union. I do not have to relate to honourable senators the turbulence that exists in Latin America, with the exception, probably, of Peru. I am hoping that the new Minister will give special attention to some of these cases because people were interviewed almost eight or nine months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I will wind up about Uruguayans. I have received several letters from the Central Office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The matter stemmed largely from Senator Primmer. I think Senator Chipp also raised the matter of Uruguay. The United Nations stated in one letter that 80 Uruguayans were in a camp in Brazil. We were prepared to take a sizeable number. I subsequently received a letter which I do not have with me. I am not altogether sure whether the Minister or Mr Menadue signed it. We rightly felt that we were not impressed with the first couple who presented themselves. I received another letter which said that our humanitarian program would take people on board but it did not finish the original idea. If there were, say, 80 people and we rejected several, are we to take any of the residue? All this agitation was also supported by my Victorian colleague, Senator Primmer, at the request of the Uruguayan community in Melbourne. I understand that the Uniting Church in Sydney , through the representations of some Uruguayans, was also interested in the matter. Perhaps that matter can be clarified in relation to just what our commitment is.

Finally, mindful of what the Chairman of Estimates Committee D did with the problem, we have-to adopt the words of the title of Charles Dickens's book-great expectations for many in relation to the family reunion program. To be brutally frank, because of the number who will apply how many will have to be compressed in the first year? It will be a very difficult ministerial exercise. I read in the Canberra Times that Cabinet ultimately-it was similar to a question I asked about the Public Service Board-would augment the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs by another 25 employees. Could we get a break-up of how many people will be allocated to Sydney and Melbourne? I am sure the Minister is aware of the regional problems notably at Parramatta in New South Wales. What is the position at the moment-there has always been a blame him or blame them attitude-about getting full co-operation from the Australian Federal Police and State police on the vetting of citizenship applications. This is an important factor in the time span. Could we get some information on that? Maybe the Minister will say that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) should supply some of the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of brief issues relating to the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs. Late last year I moved in the Senate, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, as a matter of public importance the need for the Australian Government to supply food aid to Poland. At that stage martial law had not been imposed. Nevertheless the Australian Government still refused to grant such aid despite the clear urgency of the situation. Furthermore, just prior to the imposition of martial law the Polish Government asked Australia to extend trade credits to enable it to buy food-stuffs. The Government's subsequent decision to suspend consideration of this request until martial law has ended shows little concern for the wellbeing of the average Polish citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government has been in an excellent position to assist the Polish people during this trying period but has, I believe, not given the complete co-operation required. Nobody in Australia supports the imposition of martial law but it is obvious that the Polish people are suffering enough without this country taking such a tough, uncompromising line towards them. Poland needs Australian support at this time whether it be in the form of food aid or an extension of trade credits. It seems inconsistent to me that our Government, which according to a Foreign Affairs officer at the estimates hearings continues to support the idea of private humanitarian assistance to Poland and pays $1m to the Help Poland Live appeal-I do not oppose that decision ; in fact I agree with it-at the same time still refuses to back down on food aid and trade credit issues to Poland.

As I mentioned earlier in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs estimates I visited Lebanon earlier this year and during the Estimates committee hearing I took up the question of the value of the United Nations interim force in Lebanon. It is clear to me that this force has come in for a great deal of criticism from a number of countries. I strongly support the criticism that has been made by a number of countries about the United Nations interim force. What the Lebanese people desperately need at the present time is a proper United Nations peacekeeping force throughout the whole country within the internationally recognised borders, not just on her southern border. At the moment I believe that the interim force is a waste of time, effort and money. For that reason I gave notice of motion earlier this week which stated:
That the Senate:

(1) urgently requests the Secretary-General of the United Nations to initiate immediate action by the United Nations Security Council to bring about a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Lebanon, and
(2) is of the opinion that such settlement should embrace-
(a) strict respect by all members of the United Nations for the territorial integrity of Lebanon within its internationally recognised boundaries;
(b) extending the responsibilities of the United Nations Interim Force to apply to the internationally recognised boundaries of Lebanon;
(c) the transfer of responsibilities currently exercised by the Arab League peacekeeping forces to the United Nations Peacekeeping Forces, and the subsequent withdrawal of the Arab League Forces;
(d) disarming of factional and communal militias, and the PLO
(e) concurrent steps towards a settlement of the Palestinian question which will provide Palestinians with a national homeland.

I believe it is about time that the Australian Government, which contributes every year to the United Nations interim force in Lebanon, raised this issue in the United Nations. There is one further issue concerning the Department of Foreign Affairs that I would like to comment on. During the Estimates Committee hearings I asked whether all our Foreign Affairs posts overseas received Radio Australia news summaries. Unfortunately it appears that some posts do not have the communications equipment to pick up the Australian news summaries. Not surprisingly, these posts feel very out of touch and not up to the date with what is going on in Australia. I was particuarly pleased to hear from the permanent head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Henderson, that the objective is to rectify this situation so that all posts receive Radio Australia news regularly. I hope that the available finance is provided as quickly as possible in order to fix this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier Senator Sibraa raised matters with regard to delays in processing the applications of British people and others to come to Australia. He noted what was said by the Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs at the time of the Estimates Committee hearing. I am not able to say very much more than was said at that time. I think it is accepted there are delays in some instances and that sometimes those who have sought early application because of skills related to employment opportunities expect that these things may be able to be conducted more quickly than they are able to be. I think it was said a little later by another speaker that if we were able to facilitate all applicants coming as quickly as they would like we would probably have difficulties staying within the figures in our immigration program laid down for this year. I have noted what was said by Senator Sibraa. I thank him for the spirit in which he made the comments because it is not a matter of criticising those who are working very hard and effectively to process as quickly as is possible and to facilitate the applications. Other difficulties arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sibraa mentioned the position in Lebanon. I am not able to say a great deal about what he raised as a very real difficulty of some people in applying for migration from that part of the world. I know he is aware of this and I know the Committee was given information with regard to the processing arrangements. I can only add to what I think is known about the way in which the arrangements proceed. At present we have under review the situation applying at the Australian Embassy in Beirut. At this stage I can say no more than that. But I accept that there are very many difficulties and uncertainties in that part of the world. In the latter comments of Senator Sibraa I noted what he said about the interim force. He drew attention to his notice of motion. Of course, that notice of motion is known to us. It will have the attention of the Minister concerned.

Senator Mulvihill again raised a number of matters. Firstly, he mentioned those matters relating to the Committee on the Determination of Refugee Status and a number of countries such as Bolivia, Uruguay and others. He was concerned that matters he had raised earlier may not now be considered as urgent by the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges). I can assure him that the matters he raised are under consideration. He will have the same response from the new Minister as a matter of continuing Government policy as he would have had there been no change. Senator Mulvihill raised matters of co-operation between police forces. I am advised that the time taken for the completion of penal checks by the Australian Federal Police has been significantly reduced and the average turn round period is currently three weeks. There are no particular difficulties that I am aware of with the current level of State and Federal police co-operation in these matters. Senator Mulvihill raised a question at the Senate Estimates hearing on which I can now supply him with information. He asked whether we were catching up on the backlogs or whether the delays were getting worse. The response to that question is that we are reducing the citizenship backlog overall and the on-hand caseload in the Sydney office fell from 15,760 to 10,285 in the period June 1981 to March 1982. In Melbourne office the on-hand case load was 8,837 in June 1981. It rose to 12,780 in December and has now fallen to 11,196. On an Australia-wide basis the on-hand case load was 41,411 in June 1981 rising to 44,679 in December 1981. It now stands at 40,800. So there has been some reduction in the citizenship backlog.
A question was raised with regard to the additional staff about which an announcement has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Cabinet approved 25 to be employed.

— Yes, Senator Mulvihill. The distribution of that 25 is that there will be 14 in New South Wales, including three in Parramatta; Victoria will have six; Queensland, two; and there is one each in South Australia, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. In addition to that 14, central office has provided a task force of four for up to one month and the Public Service Board has agreed also to 15 temporary intra- monthly positions for May and June. The staffing position situation for new policy implementation now satisfies the union demands. We hope that the case load position will move smoothly from this point on. I think those are the matters on which I am able to supply information. Where other matters have been raised for which information is sought I will see that as early as possible replies are given to the honourable senators concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senate Estimates Committee E reported in May 1982. It drew attention to only one item. This item was virtually a repeat of a matter that was raised in our previous considerations in a report in October 1981. I say at the outset that there has been, from the experience that I have had on the Estimates committees over six years-originally under the chairmanship of Sir Reginald Wright-a vast improvement in the amount of information that each of these committees has had available to them from the departments. It has been my observation that the departmental officers and the senior officers within those departments are anxious to provide the sort of information that honourable senators and the Senate Estimates committees require . I regard the latest details that have been supplied to our Committee as being the most detailed and the most informative that we have received yet. I also pay credit to the Committee secretariat which looked through these figures and provided the Committee with a great deal of information.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular item on which I wish to address the Senate at the moment deals with the Department of Housing and Construction, as it then was called. I quote from the report of Senate Estimates Committee E in October 1981 which states:

Of the total of $1,135.6m allocated to the Department, $467.26m is for work carried out on a contractual basis for other Government Departments and Authorities. Because the Department of Housing and Construction is only acting as the contractor, it is not possible for its officers to be questioned on the purpose, background or need of the items involved. As no justification can be sought from the Department of Housing and Construction, the Committee feels it is desirable that each initiating Department should be questioned on the respective amounts. This could be facilitated by individual Departments including an explanation of such expenditure as an appendix to their Explanatory Notes. Only a broad statement of this expenditure need be included in the Department of Housing and Construction's Explanatory Notes.

Senator McLaren and honourable senators of both sides of the chamber have expressed displeasure on previous occasions when they have had to go from department to department, from Estimates committee to Estimates committee to find the department or the committee in which a particular item that attracts their interest was located. I have been particularly frustrated in asking questions on capital expenditure and capital works to find that the relevant items are all listed under the Department of Housing and Construction and are not listed under the client department.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not exist any more; there is no Department of Housing and Construction.

—Senator McLaren is quite right, but I assume that the responsibilities of the former Department of Housing and Construction that are relevant to my comments will be taken over by the new Department of Transport and Construction. I am pleased to say that in our latest report we make the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been informed by the Department of Housing and Construction that it has written to the Department of Finance concerning the adoption of certain procedures to facilitate examination by Estimates Committees of the particulars of new works proposals of individual Departments, as recommended by the Committee in its Report to the Senate of 13 October 1981.

Subsequent to that report being produced I had a visit from senior officers of the former Department and we discussed the way in which the recommendation should be carried out. I am very pleased to say, as Chairman of the Committee, that the solution that was arrived at by that Department has my complete approval. The offer that was made by the former Department of Housing and Construction, which would of course, be subject to the approval of the Department of Finance and client departments, is that any new works to be undertaken by a client department would be listed under the relevant department' s expenditures. Honourable senators who have an interest in that matter could then ask questions of the relevant department as to why a particular building should be built and they could go into the details that they think necessary. We did not regard it as essential that once a building had been commenced any reference be made in subsequent reports but considered that such references could remain in the old Department of Housing and Construction reports. Any subsequent alterations to the costs and estimates would most likely be the responsibility of the client department. I thank the Department for its co- operation and I thank the Government for its ready co-operation in meeting the wishes of Estimates Committee E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the supplementary estimates for the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. We are spending a considerable sum of money-$25m-in that area. I am concerned-I have expressed that concern before, but I hope that in this context we can persuade the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to take the matter further-with the so-called 'unemployables' of our society. I refer to those people whom I have heard referred to in this chamber as people who have no will to work and who as a result are presumably doomed to be some sort of human flotsam and jetsam in this generation. As I have suggested previously and as I suggest again now, that is something that we cannot allow to happen. I think we are failing in our duties as members of parliament if we do allow it to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I am well aware that there are many problems in the community in coping with the difficulties of these young people. I have spoken with very many of them in drop-in centres and elsewhere and I have found that almost uniformly they are young people who did not do well at school and who now regret that fact. It is the lack of work experience and, indeed, skills in education that are keeping them out of work. I am convinced that the majority of them, if they were offered a work situation which they found acceptable, in which they felt confident and in which they could acquire skills-preferably they should work with their own peer group and have some choice of occupation-would be quite prepared to work hard. If that work element could also have an element of national service in the true sense so that it would be demonstrably something of value to the community and the young people engaged in it would feel that it was so, I am not so cynical about our young people as to believe that it would not appeal to them, as it has appealed to every generation of young people if it has been properly put to them in that way.

I would think that such work would need to be voluntary. I do not believe that it would be good if it were done on a compulsory basis. My reason for saying that, largely, is that if a scheme is voluntary, it has to produce results. If it is compulsory, it can impose all sorts of things on people and not have to justify itself as a success. I think that that is one of the best reasons for its being voluntary. It should offer a variety of work and concentrate strongly on the acquisition of skills. There should be a very strong training element within it.

I am encouraged in that view, which I am well aware is deeply debated in the community, almost universally, among people who are thoughtful on this issue, to find that it is also echoed quite strongly by two of the three people who have written the excellent document 'Challenge to Australia', which all honourable senators, I think, must have seen. In that document, Sir Barton Pope, Sir Macfarlane Burnet and Sir Mark Oliphant-I hope that they will forgive me for referring to them as three of the grey eminences of our society-have laid down ' Challenges in planning for the next One Hundred Years', 'Australia's Needs in the Immediate Future', and 'Looking at Today and Tomorrow'-the titles of their three contributions. Sir Barton Pope says:

We must purge from our society the present uncertainty and despair of our youth . . . National service intake could be increased and, as in other countries, training extended for part time strategic road contruction, logistics, water boring, and use of heavy equipment in the outback, all urgently required for defence from within. Upon release such youth would be better equipped and orientated to a life away from the urban areas. So trained, their services would be sought by the mining and mechanised rural industries where Australia's future activities should lie. This is the recruiting ground for our leaders of the future. Governments must accept some responsibility for the character of our youth.
That last sentence is perhaps the most important part of what I have quoted.
I turn to Sir Mark Oliphant's view. He said:

A large and growing part of Australia's G.N.P. is spent on unemployment benefits and on pensions for people still able and willing to work. This at a time when so much remains to be done in this underdeveloped country. Roads, railways, airfields, pipelines for gas and water; electrical grid systems; greater exploration for minerals, oil, gas, and coal, underground water; are some obvious needs that can be satisfied without importing anything or incurring any external debt. To pay people to be idle when these tasks, many urgent, remain undone, seems to me profoundly uneconomic. It confirms the view of the distinguished American diplomat, writer and teacher, George Kennan, that man has not yet learned how to govern.
Those are hard words but challenging ones. They should be taken to heart, considering their origin.

There is a great need for community consensus on this subject. That consensus, when it comes, must take the eminently respectable and reasonable view of the trade union movement into account. Such a scheme must not create a sort of subservient class of workers, it should not interfere with the conditions and salaries that unionists have. That should be its first prerequisite, because the viewpoint of the trade union movement in that respect is absolutely sound, and I could not agree with it more. Indeed, if there is any such consensus or an attempt at it, perhaps it would be good to ask the trade union movement first what it thought about that sort of thing, and perhaps suggest some situation in which the trade union movement took a major stake, if not all the stake, in the organisation and running of such a national enterprise, which would achieve some of the things which those two eminent men that I have mentioned have suggested.

These elements should be regarded as vitally important. Whatever the enterprise is it should have a strong training element; it should not do work which would otherwise be done by unionists, it should be voluntary, and it should be demonstrably in the national interest so that the young people engaged in it feel some sense of satisfaction, prestige and achievement in the longer term.

I am raising this matter now during the consideration of the Estimates of the former Department of Employment and Youth Affairs in the hope that the Minister will take it to the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) and ask one question: Has the Government thought about whether a scheme such as this might not be brought about? I am sure that the Government has thought about it. I could not believe that it would not do so. Has it, however, just assumed that such a scheme would not be possible because of the automatic opposition of the trade union movement to it? If so, that would be tragic because I believe there are many thousands of young people who are literally rotting, in a psychological sense, who are trapped in a situation which they cannot control and which they cannot get themselves out of. Only the community can get them out of that situation.

So, I ask the Minister for Finance-and I would like her response on this question, please-whether indeed the Government has considered this, whether it has assumed that it would not work because the trade union movement would automatically be opposed to it and whether it will not now take up this matter in a serious fashion by consultation with the Labor Party and with the trade union movement to see whether something can be done to break this wretched situation which has trapped so many of our young people as victims of a problem not of their choosing and not their fault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I ought to rise just for one moment to reply to some of the remarks made by Senator Mason. Whilst agreeing with his general concern that those who are unable to find work in our society should be aided by society in order to recover some of their self-esteem and be prepared to contribute to society should economic recovery present itself under the next federal administration by a Labor Government, nevertheless I think there were two aspects of his remarks which may need to be queried. One was his endorsement of the idea that a program ought to be undertaken whereby our young people were taken out of their city urban environment into the outback and taught how to sink water bores. To be quite frank, what we ought to be doing instead of proposing this fantasy world concept which is applicable to some sort of Benedictine or Chinese Maoist theory of preparing people for life by making them work with their hands--
—They were not my words.

—You were endorsing them, I believe, Senator Mason. What we need to do is prepare our young people for the realities of Australian urban life, for instance, the existence which they find in the western suburbs of Sydney or wherever it might be. To think that some time spent in the outback is going to prepare them for their adult life within Australian society is, I think, not very helpful to them. It is about as helpful as many of the Community Youth Support Scheme projects were in which we found people making candles or doing leather work in the belief that somehow this was meant to prepare them for a contribution to their family's welfare in later years. Senator Mason seemed to be endorsing an idea put forward by some knight by the name of Sir Barton Pope that the Government should be responsible for the character of our citizens. I find in that suggestion a very disturbing thought indeed because I would expect that to be a remark from those who endorse totalitarian governments and their total formation of the character of their citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to create Australians who have moral and ethical standards which embrace integrity, perseverance, courage or any of those things which we say make a good character I believe those characteristics, those standards which make up a character which we would applaud, ought to be gained by presenting to our young people models of those individuals who in history, whether from religious traditions or non-religious humanism have achieved those sorts of impacts on human history which are so remarkable. Such persons should be presented as heroic models for our young people. One thinks of Martin Luther King in the United States of America, a great man from a contemporary industrialised Western democracy who showed how non-violent social change can be achieved against the forces of prejudice and so on. One thinks of Gandhi. One thinks of Mother Theresa in Calcutta. I think it is far better to think of a program alerting our young people and inviting them to mould their character on and to adopt as their character base the character of these individuals who are so important in human history rather than thinking that governments can mould character. Once one thinks of governments having the responsibility to mould character, one is in the realm for the justification of all those laws against victimless crimes, for example, which I am sure Senator Mason would think are unnecessary on our statute books.

TALK.START.PARA: —But do they stay unemployed? That is the real point. They cannot mould themselves if they stay unemployed.

—If the honourable senator is talking about character in terms of employment and unemployment he is inviting an argument about the necessity of work in order to prove one's worth as a citizen. Then one enters the question of character and the protestant work ethic and whether there can be a fulfilling human life without the need to contribute to society by way of paid employment. In that respect I believe that many honourable senators and many Australians are now moving to a belief that there is much to be said for the view that there are many realms of human life which do not fall into the realm of paid employment which are valuable and can be undertaken only by those with the character of courage and self-sacrifice which is not required in many paid occupations. So to equate character with the question of employment or unemployment seems to me to be unfortunate. I rose only to make those remarks. Perhaps they are not strictly pertinent to any estimate which is in my mind at the moment. I simply put those remarks in contradistinction to some emphases which were perhaps unintended in Senator Mason's contribution.

—I raised a question with the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs regarding the courier service. I wanted to know why the courier service was replaced. Did it work out cheaper to replace the service? What was the case? I was advised by a Mr MacDonald that I should have made inquiries on this question through the Department of Administrative Services. Unfortunately I was not here at the time the Department of Administrative Services vote was dealt with. I want to know why the courier service was replaced. If, as Mr MacDonald has stated, the contract was let by the Department of Administrative Services, is the Department telling me that it has no say in who gets the contract although it has to pay for it? The courier service was taken off the Department and given to private freight contractors. Was it cheaper or more expensive to do this? I ask the Minister to provide me with the answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. This Department is mentioned on page 23 of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82. There has been some comment and concern expressed about our unemployed youth. I can only say that it is one of the greatest tragedies of our time that such a large number of young people are unemployed and are placed in difficulty when seeking employment today. In my experience there is only one immediate solution to this problem and that is permanent part time employment. School to work transition programs are putting young people in artifical situations. If unemployed people are given a responsibility, albeit on a part time basis, they respond very quickly. They are placed in a real work situation. They have to accept the discipline of appearing at specific times during the week. Very quickly they become part of the work environment. I have seen young people who have opted out of society completely. Some have never had a permanent job in their life. However, once they were placed in a permanent part time environment in industry they very quickly changed their attitude. Instead of opting out of society they decided that it was not such a bad idea to be involved in a real work situation and thus they decided to seek full time employment.

SPEECH.PARA: I have discussed this matter with the former Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr MacPhee) but in reply have received only comment along the lines that the matter would be considered. I do wish to take the opportunity to emphasise again in the Senate that if we accepted the principle of providing permanent part time work and threw down to employers the challenge to make at least one position available on a rostered basis we could very quickly, and without significant additional cost, employ at least on a part time basis, all of the unemployed in the community. That would solve a very real social problem, one that is rapidly developing into a situation in which a large percentage of the young people in the community are opting out of society completely and becoming frustrated and disruptive.

Such trends, if allowed to develop, will reap a very bitter harvest for our country in the years to come. We can solve the problem of youth unemployment immediately; we cannot leave it any longer. It is not one that we can think about and solve tomorrow. It must be solved today. I repeat, to use unemployment as an economic weapon, particularly against the youth of our society, is a crime and an urgent change of direction in Government policy must take place. The problem of youth unemployment must be solved now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised by recent speakers, most of whom have been concerned with the question of youth unemployment and the most sensible approaches that might be adopted in remedying it. In a sense, I am very pleased that there have been multiple contributions because the variety of the approaches taken by Senator Mason, Senator Tate and Senator Siddons help to illustrate why it is not simply a matter of saying: 'We would like a bit of good will in this matter.' There are serious questions as to how one should tackle the problem and they are seen as serious, in most countries that we would regard as equivalent to ours, right around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the present Government's approach, as would be well known to the Committee, there has tended to be an emphasis on training and work experience programs. In the last Budget there was a change in emphasis, with a considerable real growth in expenditure in this regard, but a decision was made that the Community Youth Support Scheme would no longer be funded. Some of the reasons were reflected in the comments which Senator Tate, in I believe a quite non-partisan way, made in the debate tonight. It is history now that the good points of CYSS became a matter of intense public interest and debate and the Government restored the program but changed the guildelines to try to ensure that more value was obtained from the projects than had been the case before.

The simple point that I wish to make in response to the contributions of honourable senators is that it is very easy for us to agree that there is a significant problem, both economic and social, in this field. It is very easy to agree that the Government has a responsibility to do things in this area. I hope it is common ground that in the current budgetary period the Government has shown that it is prepared to make an additional effort in a Budget in which it was trying to hold the line. There was certainly an increased allocation in this area.

We are now faced with suggestions that further and different approaches might be taken. I would not wish to treat those suggestions with disrespect, but I think that it would be disrespectful simply to acknowledge either agreement or disagreement at this stage. I can only say to honourable senators that the question continues to be on the agenda for Government consideration and that I will ensure that the points raised will be taken into account in the course of that consideration. I can understand that Senator Siddons, who says that he has spoken to the former Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and merely been told that it is under consideration, might think that that is not a very adequate answer. I can only say as one of the Ministers concerned in the deliberations in this area-of course, consideration by other Ministers such as the Minister for Education is relevant in approaching the broad questions which arise, for instance the proper courses to be made available to youth-that certainly the matter is currently on the agenda for joint consideration. Of course, we would like to improve our performance in that area.

I would confess to some modest scepticism about the idea that any wholesale solution can be found by working in the bush. That appeals to me in a personal sense and it would undoubtedly suit some of Australia's youth but I think there is a lot of force in the views put forward by Senator Tate that for a great number of Australia's youth that is not really likely to be part of their long term reality. For that reason I think one has to be cautious in embracing any single approach which might be thought to provide a universal solution. Surely what we have learned from both overseas experience and our own is that there is no single solution. In fact there needs to be a continuous and multifaceted approach to the very real problem of ensuring that all Australian youth find a place in Australian society. To balance the debate a little, it is proper that the Senate should show its concern for the perhaps one in five young people who might be having difficulty fitting into society. It is worth remembering that there is a very significant large group which is not suffering difficulty. One must remember that the system does pick up a substantial number of children in an adequate way. That is not to say in any sense that we are not responsible for or should not be concerned about the others.

I note also Senator Siddons's suggestion about permanent part time employment. Without having the statistics with me, it is a fact that in Australia recently there has been very considerable growth in part time employment. That is not unusual and is not peculiar to this country. I merely say to honourable senators that matters that they have raised will become part of an ongoing consideration which will include consideration in the Budget context.

Senator Elstob raised a matter of some particularity and I am not sure that I can necessarily give him all the answers that he would wish. My advice is that the contract for courier services for the Commonwealth Employment Service was let to Australia Post by the Department of Administrative Services in the normal course. The Department of Administrative Services acts as the Commonwealth's agent for the letting of such contracts and such contracts are let on the basis of competitive tender. I understand Senator Elstob was concerned at the lack of contact between the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the actual contractor. I can only say that these difficulties arise, I suppose of necessity , if we preserve a system in which contractors are not chosen because we like the colour of their eyes or for whatever reason, rather that contracts are put to tender to ensure that there is an opportunity for people to compete and that there is a fair allocation of those contracts. I imagine that Senator Elstob would be on his feet complaining bitterly if for some reason Australia Post was not able to compete for that contract. It is probably inherent in the system that we follow-which is meant to be fair to the community, to ensure that we get best value for money and that those who are interested in doing the work get a chance to compete for it-that some of the difficulties arise that Senator Elstob is concerned about. I suggest that, if he wants to follow up the matter with more particularity, he do so with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee). I think it is unlikely that we can deal with it further in this debate.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the votes contained in Group F be now passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, as Deputy Chairman and a member of the Committee of which I am Chairman, I know that you would want me to pass thanks to those staff who helped us during our deliberations with Estimates Committee F. I would like also to thank the departments involved, which presented to us their Estimates in a form which was such that they required very little additional explanation or questioning, although it seems that honourable senators always find a way of looking for things that are not in the Estimates no matter how well they are presented to them. Occasionally new members on committees have not heard the explanations given in previous years. I want to thank not only the Committee staff and the departments but also mention the co- operation of the committee members, namely, Senators Coates, Georges, Jones, MacGibbon and Withers. Although Senator Withers was away for some of the time for some reason, he was able to help us both before and after the hearings with some formal matters that needed to be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise to the officers of the Department of Transport for not being present while the Department's estimates were being examined. I take a particular interest in that Department. I had a fairly bad case of flu that day. I suppose it is bad for a chemist to admit to having the flu; I could not have had enough vitamin C. But for once I let my better judgment prevail and I went home early. I am grateful to Senator MacGibbon for so ably chairing the meeting during my absence. I thank Senator MacGibbon. Everybody commented that he chaired the meeting very ably. Of course, this is an area in which he has a profound knowledge and interest.

I had intended to apologise to the Department of Transport for not taking up an invitation. I do not know whether this was done. Due to pressure of work, I have not had a chance to examine the Department's training areas. I, and several other members of the Committee, do intend to do so as soon as possible. The Department invited me to undertake the inspection because I seem to criticise continually the amount of money that is spent on training some of its pilots as examiners of airmen. The Department sends some officers overseas for training and it costs this country a considerable amount of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have gone there to learn to fly.
—You would not have knocked that fence down in Geelong.
—I thought I would get some comment from Senator McLaren. I have not hit a fence for many years, but I will try, particularly in Senator McLaren' s area.
—You keep out of our area; we don't want you.

—I will keep out of Senator McLaren's area as much as I can. That invitation by the Department has not been ignored. We wish to see it. I suppose when we do accept the invitation we will see in the Estimates an item: ' Hiring of simulators for Senators Townley, Coates, MacGibbon, et cetera' that will amount to several thousand dollars. The departmental officers will then say : 'That is one of the reasons why the Department of Transport estimates go up; senators use the simulators'. When we solve that problem we might consider going on that inspection.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that I thought would be explained tonight was the reason for the big difference in the wages for the Department of Transport. I do not know whether the Minister has some statement that he is expecting to make. Will a statement be made within the next few minutes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, when you are ready.

—We are ready. Perhaps it might be a good time to make it in order to stop me going any further. I did find it a little difficult to get the real basis for the error with which the statement will deal. I know that departments do not like making errors. There must be a good reason for it. I would like to hear how it will be handled. The Committee did comment, in its report, on the difference of some $7m in the estimates for wages. I will be pleased to hear the answer to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Senate Estimates committees are working very well. There is some talk around the corridors that the Committees have become redundant. I do not believe that for a minute. I believe that Estimates committees do a valuable job. Due to the pressure on Estimates committees over the last few years, the estimates are presented to them in a way that reduces the number of questions that have to be asked. I think it would be a mistake if Estimates committees and standing committees, for argument's sake, were combined. I think it is very valuable to have Estimates committees separate from standing committees. I think that is something which the Senate may look at in the near future; it is something which I believe it should look at very closely.

Another point is that now we have a department responsible for aviation, distinct from the Department of Transport. I hope that, as the aviation sector of transport is of more interest to me than the other area, we will be able to retain that area in Estimates Committee F, which I am lucky enough to chair at this stage. Aviation, of course, is very important to many areas of Australia, particularly to Tasmania because of that bit of water separating us from the mainland. I hope that in the reorganisation, due to the new ministries, that area will remain with this Committee. Finally, I thank the Committee members and the staff for the work they did and also Senator Messner for his help and tolerance when we were trying to extract information that perhaps he thought we should not have. I thank everybody involved and look forward to a reply about the $7m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on one point in the estimates relating to the Department of the Capital Territory. I must say at the outset that one always has a feeling of unease when dealing with the Department of the Capital Territory in that there is very little monetary restraint in what it does; no one seems to appreciate the value of money. There is a general belief that the world owes it a living. I think that is well illustrated by an item of expenditure of $848,400 for the provision of child services. Basically this was the cost of looking after 50 or 60 children for a year. All the members of Estimates Committee F were astonished to discover that this was going on. This amount works out at a cost of between $14,000 to $16,000 a year to look after one child. All the parents on the Committee were astonished . In my case, it would cost between $56,000 or $64,000 a year to look after my four children if such a rate of expenditure applied within my family.

SPEECH.PARA: The disturbing thing is not so much the huge sum of money involved but the attitude of the Department. There is simply no restraint-no upper limit-on what it costs to look after children in these organisations. These are not private organisations; they are charitable organisations such as Dr Barnardo's home, the Marymead children's centre and the Outreach Inc. Home. The Department asks: ' What did it cost you last year to look after the children?' They give their total cost for the year, which the Department divides by the number of children. It divides that by the number of weeks or months in the year and pays the organisation on a pro rata basis. It then comes back for more money in the supplementary estimates. That is an intolerable way of looking after public funds because it works out at a rate of $14,000 to $16,000 a year, at the upper limit, to look after a child.

The officer answering the questions made the situation even worse because there is no correlation, apparently, between the institutions. One institution charges in excess of or around $250 a week for each child and as you, Mr Temporary Chairman, said, you can keep someone in a hotel for that. Another institution charges $147 a week for each child. That is a very big difference. It costs about $103 to provide exactly the same service. But the story gets even worse because the officer admitted that the Department pays foster parents $30 a week to provide exactly the same service. There is a big difference between $30 and $ 250, and no one is concerned about it. I leave the matter at that, Mr Temporary Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hate to repeat what the previous honourable senator spoke about but this was one of the points I was so aware of when it was raised. I think Senator Georges may have asked questions originally and those questions, together with the couple of questions I asked, brought the information to light. The information that came to light, as Senator MacGibbon said, was that children were being looked after at a cost of $250 a week-up to $ 14,000 or $16,000 a year. The point I want to make, without labouring the points already made by Senator MacGibbon, is that it seems very unreal that this Government should expect parents to bring up children on the amount of child endowment it pays and yet one of its departments is now paying $250 a head for children who are its responsibility in a particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: We must also consider that some working fathers or mothers would be taking home less than $250 a week and keeping a family of two or three. Either the Government's estimate of the amount of child endowment it should pay is very wrong or there has been some sort of neglect or overpayment in the area of child care administered by the Department. I am not sure of the procedures but it seems to me to be such an error that it is nearly unreal that we should approve this sort of estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't.
—I am not sure of the procedure to stop the estimate being approved.
—You can't block Supply.
—We cannot block Supply.
—You can, we can't.

—Yes, that is right. The Estimates Committee asked questions in relation to a particular item and received certain answers. Not only did the answers amaze Opposition honourable senators but also they amazed Government honourable senators. It is absolutely out of this world to expect us as senators responsible for the expenditure of money in the Australian Capital Territory to accept the amount of money that the Department says it is required to pay to keep one child in the A.C.T. I hope I am not being critical of the officers who appeared at the Estimates Committee hearing or of the institutions which look after the children. I am not sure, but I believe that the Government should look at those people who have been handling the care of children and see what sort of officers have been negotiating a deal in relation to that expenditure. That amount of money should not be being paid for one child. I think that somewhere along the line the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) should take a very close look at what is happening in the A.C.T. in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the estimates of the Department of Transport which are contained in Group F and a problem that exists in Port Augusta where attempts have been made over a long period to incorporate the local aerodrome in the local ownership plan. I raised this matter during the Estimates Committee debate on the subject. I pointed out that because of the growing interest in the northern Spencer Gulf area and the increased demands being placed upon the aerodrome, which is in a very mediocre state, I have asked the present Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) to regard this as a matter of importance and to include the aerodrome in the local ownership plan. I am glad to say that at last the Government, through the Minister, has recognised that this matter is important and has approved in principle the inclusion of the aerodrome in the plan.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first instance, the original plan for the aerodrome was seen to be a little too sophisticated for the current demands. Apparently at the moment consultations are continuing with respect to the detail of the plan to ensure that what is ultimately put forward to the Department and the Minister for his consideration meets the current requirement. I have a letter to which I refer. It substantiates my concern. It is from the Port Augusta hospital and is written to the Minister for Transport. A copy of the letter was given to me and to other members of parliament. I will read it for the benefit of the Committee to highlight the importance of this airstrip to the northern Spencer Gulf area. The Chief Executive Officer of the hospital, Mr Robins, wrote:

On the night of 12th April 1982, a male patient with gunshot wounds to the head was admitted to this hospital in a critical condition. Following assessment and stabilisation, an aerial retrieval team from Adelaide was called to evacuate the patient.

Earlier that day, another retrieval team enroute to Adelaide had landed at Port Augusta, where upon, the pilot of the aircraft expressed great concern about the poor condition of the runways. When making arrangements for a retrieval team, hospital staff were advised that retrieval team pilots had refused to land at night on the Port Augusta aerodrome because of its extremely hazardous nature. As a result the aircraft landed in Whyalla--
which is about 50 miles away-
the retrieval team then travelled by road ambulance to Port Augusta and returned , with the patient to Whyalla for the return flight to Adelaide.

As you will appreciate, it is essential that such critically ill patients be evacuated in the minimum time possible with the least movement and added distress; these factors can contribute significantly to fatalities in circumstances such as this.

Unfortunately, this is not an isolated incident. Over the weekend in question, three (3) aircraft carrying ill patients were diverted from Port Augusta to Adelaide and Whyalla because of the condition of the Port Augusta aerodrome. Pilots of emergency aircraft have, over the past years, repeatedly criticised the safety standards of the runways. As the major receiving hospital in the area , critically ill patients are evacuated through this hospital, which, with growing frequency and concern, is experiencing difficulty and reluctance by authorities to commit emergency retrieval teams and aircraft to land in Port Augusta.

The Board of Management of the hospital finds this situation abhorrent. It compromises the care and expertise provided to stabilise and maintain patients until retrieval teams arrive. It unnecessarily places at risk, the lives of patients as a result of excessive delays and movement. The emergency service provided by this hospital is placed in jeopardy, raising serious questions about its capacity to respond to emergency situations. The demise of the hospital's emergency service capability is intolerable and disastrous for this, the remote Northern and Western Communities served by Port Augusta Hospital.
The letter concludes by demonstrating the urgency of the matter as far as the Port Augusta hospital is concerned.

It is also a base for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. I understand that at the present time consultations are continuing which, I hope, will result in a program being established and a plan being drawn up that will meet the requirements of the current demand. The Minister for Transport has given me the undertaking that he will give it priority. I understand that it is then a question for the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to determine whether it should have a high priority--

TALK.START.PARA: —What undertaking has the Minister for Transport given to Mr Wallis?

—In the Budget context. Incidentally a person telephoned me tonight and asked me who Senator McLaren was because every time he turns the wireless on he hears Senator McLaren. It is most refreshing for people to listen to someone else for a change. In answer to my friendly colleague from the Australian Labor Party, I mention that I was one of the persons who initiated the work that was carried out on the strip that is in existence at the moment at Port Augusta. I think I have had a lot longer interest in that subject than the person to which Senator McLaren referred. I commend the matter to the Government for urgent attention and, I hope, high priority in the context of the next Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After dinner Senator Peter Rae came into the chamber and accused my colleague Senator McLaren of South Australia of constantly repeating certain defamatory statements in relation to a consultancy firm which had devised a new corporate image for Australian National Railways. It was suggested by the Chairman that the matter be taken up during consideration of the estimates of the Department of Transport. That is what I now intend to do because a statement by Senator Peter Rae, who is a senior senator in this place and a lawyer, that another senator had engaged in such repetition and had made defamatory statements is of some importance. As to the element in his charge that Senator McLaren had engaged in tedious repetition I hardly think--
—Not tedious.

—I do not think that any repetition in itself should be any great cause for concern because if an honourable senator has a matter that is constantly of concern to him and which he believes ought to be of concern to the Australian people then he has a duty-is quite entitled in any case-to raise it constantly for the attention of the Senate. When one thinks of Senator Peter Rae 's obsession with Trans Australia Airlines, which is constantly reiterated in this place-it is of a destructive kind in my view-and his constructive constant concern with the so-called quasi-autonomous national government organisations or qangos, one can see there is nothing in the charge of constant repetition.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the charge that Senator McLaren has made defamatory statements in relation to the consulting firm I say that if an honourable senator looks at the commercial operations of any organisation and the way in which it operates in society and wants to comment on those operations in the Senate chamber he will highlight or give special attention to certain aspects of that operation. I thought at first that Senator McLaren may have unduly or unfairly highlighted that aspect of the consultant firm's task, undertaken for Australian National Railways, relating to the mere change of name; that perhaps he had left out, as Senator Peter Rae indicated, many other constructive proposals and tasks undertaken by that firm on behalf of Australian National Railways. In fact Senator McLaren asked, on 25 February 1981:

Was a firm of corporate image consultant experts engaged by Australian National Railways to recommend the new name of 'Australian National'; if so (a) what is the name of the firm; and (b) what was the fee paid for the services rendered.

The Minister, Senator Messner, replied yes. In other words a corporate image consultant expert had been engaged. The Government there admitted that this was indeed the consultant's task-to change the corporate image not only in respect of potential clients of Australian National Railways but also vis a vis the public as a whole. A corporate image consultant was engaged and indeed that was its primary and, I think, sole task.

The Minister's answer continued and indicated that there had been three stages to the particular campaign undertaken to change the image of Australian National Railways; that it included, amongst other things, the new name of Australian National. In the question asked by Senator McLaren and in the answer supplied is the indication that the task undertaken by the consultancy firm was indeed a narrow one, that of changing the corporate image of Australian National Railways at a cost of some $400,000. That was the cause of the concern that Senator McLaren raised in his question. It is very clear that if a lawyer of Senator Peter Rae's standing comes into this chamber and accuses another senator of making a defamatory statement he must have some evidence that defamation has occurred. In relation to a trading corporation he has to show, of course, that some real injury was suffered by the corporation in relation to existing or potential clients. No evidence of such injury has been brought forward in the chamber by Senator Peter Rae. In that regard I say that he has not sustained his charge that Senator McLaren has defamed the consultancy firm. As I said, the charge of constant repetition is of no moment. In regard to the serious charge, I wanted briefly to put those remarks on the record by way of rebuttal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Tate has misunderstood what I said. He brought in again his references to Australian National, the change of name and the cost which, he said, was over $400,000 in respect of a consultancy which did no more than advise in relation to dropping the word ' Railways' from the name and giving a new colour image.

That was the point that I was making. That was the point about repetition. That is the point about when we lose the privilege of this place.
