TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend General Business Notice of Motion No. 53 standing in my name relating to the Senate House Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to insert the word 'complete' before the word 'report' so as to make absolutely clear that the Committee is seeking the full report and not just a part of the report. I therefore move, pursuant to notice:

SPEECH.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the President transmit to the Senate House Committee, as an in camera document, a copy of the complete report by Urwick International Pty Ltd relating to the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff.

Honourable senators will recall that, as a result of the October 1981 Report of Estimates Committee A, the Senate directed its House Committee to inquire into and report upon the organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department. The Senate empowered the Committee to call for persons, papers and records and, in accordance with normal practice, advertisements were placed to notify interested organisations and individuals of the inquiry and to invite submissions.

The Committee received a number of submissions in addition to requests from some honourable senators and honourable members to discuss with the Committee their views concerning the Joint House Department. Certain of the submissions directed the Committee's attention to the review by management consultants of the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff which, according to evidence given by the Speaker to House of Representatives Estimates Committee A on 28 August 1980, recommended the amalgamation of those three departments. The Senate House Committee was also informed that there was considerable disquiet among certain of the parliamentary staff that such an amalgamation might be agreed to, and we were urged to exercise the powers given to the Committee by the Senate to call for a copy of the management consultants' report.

The Committee considered the position it should adopt on this question. The management review was ordered by the Presiding Officers in 1979 and was undertaken by Urwick International Pty Ltd. The cost to the Parliament was $75, 000, which was funded through the expenditure appropriated to the Joint House Department. The Committee determined that, as part of the reference by the Senate directed its inquiry into the organisation and functions of the Joint House Department, a thorough examination would have to embrace any proposals for new functions or the taking over of existing functions from other Parliamentary departments. Accordingly, the Committee wrote to the President on 25 February 1982 and advised him that it was of the opinion that it would be of considerable benefit to its deliberations if a copy of the report were made available. The Committee's letter also offered to classify the report as an in camera document should the President be concerned to limit access to it. The President replied to the Committee on 1 March 1982 stating that he felt obliged to discuss the matter with the Speaker as the report we sought 'was submitted to the Presiding Officers as the officers jointly responsible for the three Joint Departments'.

The Committee subsequently commenced its program of public hearings and found the validity of its opinion-that the report would benefit our deliberations- confirmed by the evidence given at the hearings. On 22 April 1982, the President , in his response to a further request for the report, stated:

. . . on 1 March I wrote to the Speaker informing him of my response to your initial request and indicating that I was of the view that approval should be given to the release of the report to the Committee on an agreed basis of confidence.
Subsequently, I had discussions on the matter with Mr Speaker but agreement between us could not be reached.
In the circumstances you may consider it appropriate that the Committee now take the matter up directly with Mr Speaker.

The Committee, whilst fully aware of its power to continue to deal directly with the President in the matter, nonetheless decided that it would write to the Speaker. The Committee's letter, which was dated 29 April 1982, requested the Speaker to consider agreeing to the President releasing his copy of the report pointing out that to do so would greatly assist in expediting the Committee's consideration of the reference. We also emphasised that the Committee's request was still for the report to be classified as an in camera document. The Speaker replied to the Committee on 3 May 1982 stating that he regarded the report as confidential to the Presiding Officers and that the-
. . . enquiry into the organisation, operation and functions of the Joint House Department by the House Committee of the Senate is wrong.
He further stated:

Such inquiry is in direct conflict with the authority and responsibility which the Presiding Officers have for the operation of the Joint House Department, in particular the statutory powers of the Public Service Act.

The Speaker concluded his letter by declining to comply with the Committee's request. Yesterday the Committee replied to the Speaker informing him that whilst we were aware of the powers conferred upon the Presiding Officers by section 9 of the Public Service Act, we did not agree with his claim that the inquiry was in direct conflict with his statutory authority. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard an extract from section 9 of the Public Service Act .
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
1. Statutory powers in relation to the Parliamentary departments are conferred on the Presiding Officers by section 9 of the Public Service Act. The appropriate sections are-
Section 9-
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act-

(c) all appointments or promotions of officers of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Joint House Department shall be made by the Governor-General on the joint recommendation of the President and of the Speaker;

(2) Subject to this section, unless inconsistent with the context, any action or approval required by this Act, the regulations or any determinations in force under section 82D to be taken or given by the Board may, so far as officers of the Parliament are concerned, be taken or given by the President or the Speaker, or the President and the Speaker, as the case may be, in substitution for the Board, and any action required or authorized by this Act, the regulations, or any determinations in force under section 82D to be taken by a Permanent Head or Chief Officer shall or may be taken-
(e) in relation to officers of the Joint House Department-by the Secretary to the Joint House Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. We pointed out that Ministers have the same statutory responsibilities for the administration of their departments, yet parliamentary committee investigations are not opposed on those grounds. Parliament has, of course, accepted that information involving public interest or national security may be withheld from parliamentary committees but these are not at issue in this instance. The Committee also stated its opinion that the statutory responsibility referred to does not override the responsibility that each Presiding Officer has to respond to the wishes of their respective Houses. This position is embraced in the concept that a Presiding Officer is the servant of his chamber, not the master.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Committee pointed out that it is the duty of each House to take such steps as it thinks necessary to inform itself on matters coming before it, and for this reason, the Senate House Committee was charged by the Senate to undertake the inquiry into the Joint House Department. PROCTEXT.PARA: The Senate House Committee has now considered your letter dated 3 May 1982, in response to its request that you agree to the President making available to the Committee his copy of the Report of the Management Consultants which dealt with the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting staff.

The Committee is aware that section 9 of the Public Service Act confers certain powers upon the Presiding Officers, separately or jointly as the case may be, in relation to the administration of the Parliamentary departments.

The Committee does not agree with your claim that the Senate House Committee's inquiry is in direct conflict with your statutory authority. Ministers have the same statutory responsibilities for the administration of their Departments, yet Parliamentary committee investigations are not opposed on those grounds. Parliament has accepted that information involving public interest or national security may be withheld from Parliamentary committees, but these are not at issue in this instance.

In addition, the Committee is of the opinion that the statutory responsibility referred to above does not override the responsibility that each Presiding Officer has to respond to the wishes of their respective Houses. This position is embraced in the concept that a Presiding Officer is the servant of his Chamber, not the master.

It is the duty of each House to take such steps as it thinks necessary to inform itself on matters coming before it. It is for this reason that the Senate House Committee was charged by the Senate to undertake an inquiry into the Joint House Department.

It is a matter of regret to the Committee that you have chosen not to concur in the release of the document on an in camera basis. The Committee, therefore, has determined that it has no further option but to call on the Senate to direct the President to release his copy of the report to the Committee.
As Chairman of the Committee, I will be giving a notice of motion in those terms in the Senate later today.
The Rt. Hon. Sir Billy Snedden,
Speaker of the House of Representatives,

He never said that this expenditure was used for anything other than what I asked him about and that concerned changing the name of the Australian National Railways and recommending a new name. To my question asking whether this had been done I was given the answer: 'Yes'. Who am I to believe? Am I to believe Senator Messner, who answered in this place on behalf of Mr Hunt, or am I to believe Senator Rae who came in here in all his glory at 8 o'clock tonight and told us that this firm, through the money which was paid to it did many other jobs? I would have thought that had the firm done all of these other jobs Senator Messner would have told me that in his answer. I am not a mind reader. Of course, I could not know whether that money, or part of it, had been spent on doing other jobs for which the firm was engaged. I was not concerned about that. I repeat again--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not again. You have said it five times already.

—I have to do this so that Senator Rae will understand. He has misrep- resented me tonight. He has accused me of defaming people. He said that I would be subject to libel action if I made this statement outside this chamber . I have made the statement outside this chamber. The firm has not yet come along and said that I have defamed it, because it cannot. I have never defamed the firm. All I have done is criticise the Government. I will continue to do so while it is prepared to waste money through some of its instrumentalities just to drop one word from a title and devise a new logo so people do not know with whom they are trading-whether it be a railway company, a shipping company, a health company, a cosmetic company or whatever other company one might like to consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three matters have emerged so far in this debate which deserve some attention. Firstly , Senator Jessop raised the question of Port Augusta Airport. I think that there is a great deal of concern locally about this matter. Concern has been expressed in many forums, including this chamber during Question Time. It has been expressed to the present Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) and the former Department of Transport about the status of this set of negotiations. There is a need for the Government to consider the proposal which Senator Jessop advocated in terms of Budget priorities. No doubt that will be taken into account in the next few months.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter which was raised by Senator MacGibbon and commented upon by Senator Jones related to the Department of the Capital Territory and the cost of funding the care of children in various institutions in the Australian Capital Territory . Those institutions are run by church groups and/or welfare agencies within the Capital Territory. I think the general thrust of the argument was that the cost of caring for people in those circumstances is quite considerable. Figures such as $14,000 a year were mentioned. I should point out that first of all it is important to recognise that the children who are being cared for in these circumstances come from broken homes or are parentless and perhaps are in a state which we would call very disturbed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And some would be quite uncontrollable.

—Quite. It would be expected that the cost of looking after them in the institutions set up in the Territory for that purpose would be considerably more than that of looking after them in one's own home. I believe that we should acknowledge that. It is important also to acknowledge-and this did not emerge from questioning in the Estimates Committee-that the cost of looking after children in these circumstances in the Territory is not significantly different from the cost of looking after children in State institutions in the various States. In fact, the costs are reasonably comparable . So, on the whole, one cannot be satisfied entirely that the costs are not somewhat higher than might otherwise be expected, but the Department is well aware of the high cost, a fact which emerged during the discussion in the Estimates Committee. Taking into account the kind of care that is offered in the various institutions and the need for an overall balance in financial priorities , the Government is currently undertaking a review of the situation and no doubt will have more to say on the matter in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point, which was raised by Senator Townley as Chairman of the Committee, related to the question of salary and the Committee's concern in relation to identification of an underprovision for salaries in the estimates of the Department of Transport before the Appropriation Bill was actually finalised . Honourable senators will appreciate that the Department of Finance does examine the reasonableness of salary and other departmental estimates, frequently detecting inadequacies in those estimates.

That the examination of the Department of Transport's salary estimates was not as effective this year is partly explained by the move away from uniform to individual award increases. As these individual awards involve penalty rates, shift allowances and varying dates of effect for over 100 occupational categories and almost 500 separate designations within the Department of Transport, the broad review techniques, together with the advice provided by the Department of Transport on which the Department of Finance relied, did not reveal the underprovisions.

Other factors included the timing of some determinations, which made it impracticable for departments to take into account the preparation of the draft Bill. The Department of Transport also indicated in its evidence to the Committee additional reasons which led to the underprovision. The Department of Transport and Construction and the Department of Aviation are to examine carefully their own procedures with a view to reducing errors of this kind so that adequate provision may be advised in sufficient time for their inclusion in the Bill. The Department of Finance is reviewing its own processes in the light of that as well.

There remains the question, raised by the Committee, of whether and how the Government can validly fund the underprovision. The funding, which relates to salary and like payments, is urgent and the underprovision was not foreseen until after the last day on which it was practicable to include the provision of the Bill. I suggest that these circumstances allow, in terms of the legislation and the statement to the Senate of the Minister for Finance on the Advance to the Minister for Finance in May last year, the funding of the underprovision validly from the Advance. I suggest that there might also be scope for funding some of the underprovision under section 5 of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 , which relates to the funding of award increases, and under section 37 of the Audit Act 1901, which relates to transferring provisions within a subdivision of an appropriation Act. These matters will be examined by the Government over the next few weeks and the course adopted will be reported to Parliament in the normal manner.

The Committee noted that the then Acting Minister for Transport had written to the Minister for Finance on 19 April 1982 seeking advice on the means for funding the underprovision. The Minister for Finance indicated that she did not believe that seeking an amendment to the Appropriation Bill was practicable, especially in view of the other avenues that were open to the Government. The Minister for Finance also noted in her reply that officers of the departments of Transport and Finance would need to consider a number of matters related to the underprovision. One other point might be made in relation to the reference by Senator McLaren to the $400,000 cost of rationalising and designing a new corporate image for Australian National Railways. It is true that the question answered the specific point raised by Senator McLaren but of course it did not give further information as to the broader expenditure which was incorporated in that $400,000 worth of costs. I make that point now.
Consideration interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Brett Anthony Collins: Proposed Deportation

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Brett Anthony Collins: Proposed Deportation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 11 p.m., in conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise the case of Brett Anthony Collins, a deportation matter which did receive some attention earlier today from Senator Mulvihill and also, in reply, from the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I believe that the importance and urgency of this matter and some of the principles aroused by it justify the attention of the Senate in a little more detail even, I acknowledge, at this very late hour. The Government, or more accurately the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges), proposes to deport Collins and that order will take effect on Friday of this week unless it is countermanded or some further legal proceedings intervene. I want to add my voice to what is a growing chorus demanding that that decision be revoked. I believe it is a case of quite considerable importance not only to the individual concerned and to his family. It also throws into sharp relief the principles and basis upon which the decision to deport is exercised-an area of administrative practice which, of course, has also been thrown into sharp relief in recent times by the equally insensitive behaviour of the Minister's predecessor in the context of Pochi and Barbaro.

SPEECH.PARA: The story in respect of Collins, briefly, is as follows. He came to Australia from New Zealand in 1968. In 1971 he was convicted of armed robbery and assault and sentenced to 17 years gaol. Nobody could possibly doubt that the offences for which he was convicted were very serious. Nobody could possibly have believed at that stage of Mr Collins's career as a future Australian citizen that he had very much going for him. However, ten years later, on 11 June 1980, he was released with parole until 1989. On 4 July 1980 the then Minister, Mr Macphee, ordered that he be deported. In November-December 1980 he appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal constituted by Mr Justice McGregor. In January 1981 there was a decision upholding the deportation order. In mid-1981 the Federal Court of Australia quashed the decision of Mr Justice McGregor. In December 1981 there was a rehearing before Mr Justice Davies and on 30 April 1982, just a few weeks ago, a judgment was given by Mr Justice Davies that the deportation order be upheld. So we had a period of 21 months elapsing between the making of the original order and the final AAT decision. I suggest to the Senate that that is a very important period, that 21 months, because it enabled Mr Collins to demonstrate publicly his concerns and his abilities, and also qualities that can be said, and certainly have been said by many people, to be of courage and persistence which he had already arguably begun to display while he was in prison.

Let me mention briefly some of those activities of Mr Collins in that 21-month period. In the first place, he assumed a very significant role in the administration of Glebe House, a halfway house for prisoners in Sydney established not very long ago. He assumed the responsibility for the administration of that establishment about six months after his release. In that position he has been accountable to several funding bodies, namely the Department of Corrective Services in New South Wales, the Department of Youth and Community Services and the Drug and Alcohol Authority. He has been administering a budget of some $80,000. Glebe House has been a conspicuous and immense success in that it has significantly lowered the rate of recidivism, certainly when compared with other halfway houses, and it has an excellent reputation with those, including magistrates, who are concerned with the administration of justice in New South Wales. Secondly, Mr Collins has been very active and visible as a spokesman and leading figure in the Prisoners Action Group. He certainly has been involved in some activities which have caused irritation to the government establishment. Certainly he has been a thorn in the side of those who have wanted to ignore the issues of prison reform. For example , I refer to his involvement in the recent case in New South Wales against certain prison officers. Thirdly, he has been involved in an organisation known as the Prisoners Legal Service which operates as an advisory committee to the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales. It was set up in 1981 to monitor the legal services provided by the Legal Services Commission to prisoners in New South Wales. In this respect, in relation to his activities, I seek leave to incorporate a one-and-a-half page letter to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs from Ms Susan Armstrong, the Assistant Ombudsman in New South Wales, which deals particularly with the prison reform activities of Mr Collins.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows:
SA:DS 13 May 1982
Dear Mr Hodges
Re: Brett Collins-Deportation Order
I am writing to ask you to review your decision to deport Brett Collins, which I understand is likely to have effect at the end of this week.

I am not a personal friend of Mr Collins, and I do not agree with all his views on prisons or prison reform. However, my job as Assistant Ombudsman in N.S.W.- which is the position which has prime responsibility for dealing with complaints from prisoners and complaints against police-has brought me into contact with his work on behalf of the Prisoners Action Group and Glebe House, and I believe that he is performing a most valuable role in the community.

The issues on which Mr Collins acts as spokesman and activist are issues of fundamental importance, which need to be the subject of public discussion and on which the voice of prisoners must be heard. I believe that the emergence of the Prisoners Action Group-and in particular Mr Collins-as a spokesman for prisoners has contributed significantly to their greater willingness to seek the changes they desire through established political and legal channels rather than through acts of senseless violence or destruction-as, for example, occurred in the burning of Bathurst Gaol.
I believe that Mr Collins has played a role of some importance in fostering the use of orthodox and legal avenues of approach among the prison population.

There is no doubt that Mr Collins is, and is recognised as, the key figure in the prison reform movement. It may be unfair, but his deportation would certainly be viewed by prisoners as a deliberate means of depriving them of their chief spokesman and there can be little doubt that the level of frustration and anger among inmates would rise accordingly.

I have no doubt that, if he is permitted to remain in this country, Mr Collins will be able to make a most valuable contribution to the Australian society. He is clearly strongly committed to work in an area where people of intelligence and energy who wish to work within the established political and legal systems are rare and greatly needed. His work at Glebe House-which performs a most useful function and to which this office has referred prisoners on their release -has been particularly valuable and I have no reason to suppose it will not continue. I understand that he has recently completed an Arts degree, and wishes to undertake studies in law, and my knowledge of his abilities would lead me to believe he could make a most useful contribution in this.
It appears to me that Mr Collins is, in fact, an exceptionally striking instance of successful rehabilitation.

When the deportation order was first made on his release from gaol in mid 1980, I could not have quarrelled with the Minister's view that, in accordance with normal policy, the likelihood of his reoffending made deportation appropriate. However, two years have now passed and to my knowledge no suggestion that he has been, or is likely to be, involved in illegal activity has ever been made, and he has clearly demonstrated his willingness to work through existing legal and political mechanisms. I understand that the extent of his 'unlawful' activities to be his involvement with organised civil demonstrations, an activity which he shares with a very large number of most respectable citizens-including, at a recent Sydney demonstration, eight bishops. I have never heard it alleged that Mr Collins has been involved in violence at demonstrations. The extent of Mr Collins commitment to his political activities would make it, in my view, most unlikely that he would jeopardise his position through any such illegal action.

In short, I believe that Mr Collins is playing a most valuable role within the Australian community, and that this is widely recognised even by people who may disagree with some or all of his views. People of his ability, intelligence and commitment are needed in this country if the democratic political system is to function fairly and effectively, and I would urge most sincerely that you reconsider the decision to deport him.
Yours faithfully
Susan Armstrong Assistant Ombudsman
I wish to quote one passage from that letter to indicate to the Senate its importance. It states:

. . . I believe that the emergence of the Prisoners Action Group-and in particular Mr Collins-as a spokesman for prisoners has contributed significantly to their greater willingness to seek the changes they desire through established political and legal channels rather than through acts of senseless violence or destruction-as, for example, occurred in the burning of Bathurst Gaol.
I believe that Mr Collins has played a role of some importance in fostering the use of orthodox and legal avenues of approach among the prison population.

In addition to those activities, Mr Collins has been involved in university studies. In 1980 he completed a Bachelor of Arts degree at the University of New South Wales, a degree which he commenced while in prison. He is now enrolled, I understand, as a law student in the post-graduate diploma of criminology course at the University of Sydney Law School. In relation to his family and personal background, Mr Collins has remarried following a divorce which occurred during his imprisonment. The evidence given to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and not, I understand, in any way subject to dispute, is that he and his wife are, indeed, very happily married. His wife testified to the effect that the period of their relationship since his release has been an extremely important, creative, constructive and satisfying period in her life. He has re-established contacts with his son by a first marriage. It is acknowledged by everyone concerned in this case, including Mr Justice Davies, that his wife and son would suffer seriously if he were deported.

An impressive feature of this case is the array of glowing testimonials which have been given publicly or privately on Mr Collins's behalf by a number of highly credible people. I have already incorporated the testimonial from Susan Armstrong, the Assistant Ombudsman of New South Wales. I simply mention that others who testified to Mr Collins's considerable personal qualities and who have opposed the decision to deport him include Mr John Baston, senior lecturer in law at the University of New South Wales and a barrister, Mr David Brown, lecturer in law at the University of New South Wales and also a practising barrister and solicitor, Mr Rod Madgwick, barrister and National President of the Australian Society of Labor Lawyers; the South Australian Prisoners Action Committee and Lenn Lehmann, the well known convenor of that committee; and various other people such as barrister and senior journalists who have spoken favourably in one way or another of Mr Collins at the various hearings in which he has been involved.

The crucial aspect of this decision to deport, is, of course, the adverse decision that was brought down by Mr Justice Davies on the rehearing of this matter in April 1982. It is that decision which, I believe, deserves some scrutiny by the Senate-not that it is appropriate at this hour to give it very close scrutiny-and more particularly, the weaknesses in that decision deserve very close scrutiny by the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hodges. While I take the view that Mr Justice Davies is a competent and usually sensitive judge, on this occasion, from a reading of the 55-page decision put down in this case, I believe that it is quite unsatisfactory in a number of respects. These are matters which should be very closely borne in mind by Mr Hodges in reviewing, as I hope he is, this case. The basic elements in the judgment are these: The judge reviews very carefully the whole background of Mr Collins, his activities in the period during his release, the family networks and support systems he has developed and so on and in relation to all those things basically, on balance, comes down favourably to Mr Collins. One extract from the decision in this respect on page 55 is as follows:

. . . I accept that many of his activities-particularly his work as administrator of Glebe House, as an assistant to the Legal Services Commission, as a counsellor to prisoners and former prisoners and as an intelligent person with an extensive experience of the prison system who can advise on problems affecting prisoners-serve a very useful function and are of considerable benefit to the community.

But having acknowledged that and having made all the other points I referred to briefly in passing, the judge then goes on to find that on balance he believes that the retention of Mr Collins as a member of the Australian community will involve some risk to the Australian community, that there is a danger of recidivism in Mr Collins's case. That may be so but it is not a danger that emerges very clearly at all from my reading of this case. I believe that a number of other aspects of the judgment warrant more concern even than that, that on balance the judge may have got things wrong. I believe in particular that a quite undue weight was given to Mr Collins's political beliefs, and more especially his participation in political demonstrations. I believe that it is clear that an unfavourable view was taken by the judge of his involvement in the prison reform movement and that while his work in Glebe House is described, as I said, as laudable, on page 23 of the judgment the judge puts it in this way:
but it is not the same thing as the adoption of an ordinary occupation.

Further, and even more disconcertingly, there is a clear suggestion that that it is immature or unsound for someone in his mid-thirties to be 'actively involved in demonstrations for a variety of causes'. That is on page 21 of the judgment. God help many of us in the labour movement-indeed many of us on both sides of politics-who at one stage or another in our adult lives, not least in our thirties, have been actively involved in demonstrations for causes in which we believe! There is further a clear suggestion that a passionate commitment to a cause is in itself a dangerous quality or at least a demonstration of unreliability of a kind which can apparently give credence to the claim that a person is a risk to the Australian community. I think these sorts of remarks are disturbing becasue they suggest that considerations quite irrelevant to the purpose for which the power to deport convicted persons under section 13 of the migration Act exists.

To move quickly-I will not take the time of the Senate much longer-to the issue which is central, clearly, to the exercise of ministerial discretion, that is the question of the likelihood of recividism, I believe again the judge's remarks are simply not satisfactory. Senator Durack may nod his head in sleep over there and look vaguely amused by the concern I am expressing for this case at this late hour--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested only in speculating as to what in your view is a short time.
—I appreciate that the liberty of the subject is not of immediate and momentous concern to Senator Durack.
—We are hanging on your every word.

—I am glad that Senator Crichton-Browne is in the chamber listening. With his reputation in these matters it is a sign of a welcome change of heart and mind that he is taking seriously and listening earnestly to what I am saying. There is a suggestion in Mr Justice Davies's decision that the possibility of the commission of summary offences at demonstrations is relevant when manifestly it is no more relevant to Collins than to anyone else engaged in legitimate political activities. The further point which I make demonstrates some clear antipathy on the part of the judge to the political activities as such of this gentleman. In relation to demonstrations, Mr Justice Davies drew the inference that Collins-I quote from page 21 of the judgment:

SPEECH.PARA: has not entirely cast off the traits which I think led to the crimes for which he was convicted.

In this part of the judgment, on page 22, a strange test is advanced relating to his 'inability to control his thoughts'. There is the suggestion that 'his mind concentrates unduly upon the present to the exclusion of other matters which he ought to take into consideration'. This appears to be amateur psychology at its worst which would be ludicrous were it not so important to the future of this individual and those who have come to depend, in a family sense, on his presence in Australia and those in the more unfortunate sections of our community who have come to depend on the very active spokesman-like role which he has played in the community at large.

Finally in respect of the likelihood of recidivism by Mr Collins, the judge seems to be taking into account on page 22 the fact that his criminal activities commenced at a fairly early age. On page three he says that the juvenile convictions and the facts surrounding them are 'facts which tend to increase the risk of recidivism'. Again in respect to that one finds it very difficult to believe that that can possibly be a serious consideration. Even after all of this and the extraordinary array of propositions which seem to bear upon the judge's final decisions, all of which I have suggested in one way or another are less than satisfactory, the judge, on page 22, states:
Probably, Mr Collins will not again commit a major crime.

There is a clear acknowledgement that the probability, not the possibility, is that there will be no recidivism. Yet, inexplicably, that remark is immediately followed by the statement by the judge that he 'cannot conclude that there is no significant risk of recidivism'. That is the situation that arises from this judgment. The key to it all is perhaps, finally, in the summing up on pages 54 and 55 when the judge, having acknowledged that there is an inability if Mr Collins were in New Zealand to pursue his interest in prisoners' rights, states:
On the whole, however, it seems to me that his continuing association with prisoners and demonstrations--
I repeat that he said:

. . . his continuing association with prisoners and demonstrations is more likely to lead to volatile situations in which he may commit a major crime than would be the case should he devote his energies to pursuing a less emotional interest.

All this is said in the face, as I have indicated, of a very considerable body of evidence from a number of people that he would not re-offend and in the face of the judge's conclusion that the probability is that Collins will not commit another major offence. I think I have said enough-no doubt for Senator Durack more than enough-to indicate to the Senate that this case deserves, notwithstanding the adverse judicial finding, some very serious reconsideration by the Minister and some very urgent reconsideration, because the order is scheduled to take effect in 48 hours' time, of just whether there has been a proper basis for the deportation order. Surely the relevant criteria that should be applied by the Minister are the real likelihood of recidivism, the contributions to the community which the person has made, the family ties and the social networks that the person has created and the dislocation to them that will result if the person has to leave the community.

It seems to me, as I said in the context of the Pochi and Barbaro matters, that a deportation should be made by the Minister only when the strongest possible probative evidence is available to him of involvement and likely continuing involvement by that person in an activity which is totally incompatible with that person's continued membership of the Australian community. I find it impossible to believe on the very large amount of material which I have scrutinised in relation to this case that that criterion or, indeed, any of the others I have mentioned could possibly be satisfied. I urge the Minister to revoke the order and to do so on the basis that the judicial decision was manifestly insensitive to the basic principles which should be applied in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised by Senator Evans is one for decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges). I will draw his attention to the submissions that have been made by Senator Evans in regard to this matter which is before him. I presume that Senator Evans will take steps also to convey his views to the Minister, if he has not already done so. Nevertheless, as Senator Evans has made submissions in the form of a speech in the adjournment debate I will take steps to ensure that they are brought to the Minister's attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs and Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 11 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Australian statutory authorities have provision for employee elected representatives or trade union nominated representatives on their boards.
(2) What is the legislative basis of this representation and when was it established.
(3) Who are the current employee or trade union representatives and who have held the positions previously.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised that there are no Commonwealth statutory authorities which have statutory provision for employee elected representatives on their boards.

There are several authorities which have statutory requirements providing for direct nominees of trade union organisations to be appointed. In addition, the Government has appointed a number of members of trade unions to other statutory positions.
Those authorities which are required to include direct trade union nominees are :
National Labour Consultative Council (established by Act No. 65 of 1977 and amended by Act No. 61 of 1981) includes seven members nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (s. 6 of Act);
Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee (established by Act No. 123 of 1977) includes one member nominated by the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia;

Federal Co-ordinating Committee (established pursuant to section 86 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 and Statutory Rule No. 235 of 1977) includes four members nominated by the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia;
Port Co-ordinating Committees (established pursuant to section 87 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 and Statutory Rule No. 236 of 1977) and operating in 41 ports in Australia.

In addition the Trade Union Training Authority (established by Act No. 50 of 1975, amended by Act No. 92 of 1978 and Act No. 176 of 1981) includes on the Australian Council for Trade Union Training seven members appointed by the Minister for Industrial Relations after consultation with the Australian council of Trade Unions (ACTU). These appointments are made from a list of at least twice the number of nominees as there are vacancies, submitted by the ACTU (this arrangement also applies to the selection of the representative of the Confederation of Australian Industry). Four of the members appointed this way are also appointed to the Executive Board of the Trade Union Training Authority.
(3) Members of trade unions who have been directly nominated by trade union organisations and appointed to statutory authorities are:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Commission on Human Rights Sub-Commission on the Prevention of Discrimination and the Protection of Minorities seek and receive information from the Australian Government on the treatment of Aborigines, particularly in Western Australia and Queensland.
(2) Did the Sub-Commission, on 10 September 1981, invite the Government to consider ratifying International Labour Organization Convention No. 107- Indigenous and Tribal Populations, 1957.
(3) On what dates and on what aspects have other United Nations bodies (a) sought, and (b) received information from the Government on the treatment of Aborigines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, through the Sub-Commission's Special Rapporteur on Indigenous Populations, Mr Jose R. Martinez Cobo, who was appointed in 1971 and visited Australia in 1973. Material on inter alia the treatment of Aboriginals in Western Australia and Queensland was provided during his visit to Australia in 1973. Further information was conveyed to Mr Martinez Cobo in March 1975 and in May 1980. Mr Martinez Cobo is expected to submit his final report to the Sub- Commission's 1982 Annual Session.

Australia also provided written information to the Sub-Commission on the situation of Aboriginals in Queensland, Western Australia and elsewhere in Australia in response to a statement made by a representative of the Minority Rights Group to the Working Group of the Sub-Commission on Slavery and Slavery- like practices on 15 August 1979. On 3 September 1980 the Australian observer to the Sub-Commission also provided information on Aboriginals in Queensland and Western Australia in response to a statement made by a representative of the National Aboriginal Conference speaking under the auspices of the World Council of Indigenous Peoples which had raised a number of issues relating to Aboriginal policy in Australia.
(2) Yes, in paragraph III.1 of Sub-Commission Resolution 8 (XXXIII).

(3) In accordance with its obligations under the International Convention for the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, Australia has provided three regular periodic reports to the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. These reports were submitted in July 1975, August 1979 and July 1981. All three reports have included material on the situation of Aboriginals in Australia. Australia has also been represented at the sessions of the Committee where its reports have been discussed, and has responded to questions raised by Committee members in relation to the Reports. These sessions were held on 6 and 12 April 1977, 6 August 1979 and 4 and 5 March 1982.

Pursuant to United Nations Economic and Social Council Resolutions 728F and 1503 the United Nations Human Rights Commission and Sub-Commission have developed special confidential procedures relating to communications concerning human rights and the provision of human rights information. Australia has co- operated fully with these bodies in their enquiries relating inter alia to Aboriginal issues.

In the course of Australia's multilateral diplomacy within the UN framework, the question of Aboriginals has been raised in a variety of contexts over the years. Australian representatives have, of course, provided relevant information as required. It is not possible to provide a comprehensive list of such instances, extending as they do over a wide range of UN bodies and over a period of over thirty years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs:

(b) the French Embassy in Tokyo has denied any knowledge of the Hidakas' involvement in terrorist activities in France.

(2) Were the Minister and his Department given false information concerning alleged activities of Professor and Mrs Hidaka, who are highly respected citizens in their country, and is the refusal by the Australian Government to grant them visas continuing to cause widespread concern among Japanese scholars; if so, will the Minister order a review of the unfortunate decision to deny visas to the Hidakas and thereby restore this country's credibility in Japan over what could be construed there as a gross bureaucratic insult.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is aware of the article published in the Australian newspaper of 16 December 1981 which attributes certain statements regarding Professor Hidaka to a Japanese police official. The Minister understands, however, that the police official involved has denied making any statement to the effect that Professor and Mrs Hidaka had no links with the Japanese Red Army.

(a) Yes. The honourable senator's attention is however drawn to the official transcript of the proceedings of the Japanese Diet on 1 March 1982 in which it was made clear by the Government's spokesmen that Professor Hidaka's passport was issued pursuant to an invitation from a number of Australian universities and that in the circumstances some of the provisions of the Japanese passport law were not pertinent to the decision to issue the passport.
(b) In a letter received from Professor Hidaka in July 1981 he acknowledged that he and his wife had been informed by the French authorities in 1975 that they would not be allowed back into France.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Commission on Human Rights Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and the Protection of Minorities on 10 September 1980 invite Australia to consider ratifying International Labour Organisation Convention No. 107-Indigenous and Tribal Populations, 1957. If so, what response did the Australian Government make and when.
(2) Which international conferences since 1970 have discussed:
(a) the conclusion;
(b) the ratification; and
(c) the implementation of conventions concerning indigenous populations.
(3) Which of these conferences has Australia attended and how did Australia vote at the conferences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, pursuant to paragraph III (I) of Sub-Commission resolution 8 (XXXIII). The Government has been examining the provisions of the convention and has not as yet responded formally to the Sub-Commission's request. The Government however continues to have doubts about the convention and considers that it reflects a number of outmoded concepts. For example, the convention's emphasis on 'integration' does not accord with the Government's current policy of recognising the fundamental right of aboriginals to retain their identity and traditional lifestyle if desired. On this point, we understand that the ILO is looking at the possible need to redefine the objectives of ILO Convention No. 107, replacing the present emphasis on integration by the principle of respect for the indigenous population's identity and wishes. This would be consistent with the Australian Government position in respect of this convention.

(2) The question of an international legal regime to protect indigenous populations has been raised on a number of occasions in multilateral fora over recent years. The most significant development has been the adoption by the 38th Session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March 1982 of a proposal of the UN Sub-Commission on the Prevention of Discrimination and the Protection of Minorities to set up a working group to examine the rights of indigenous peoples and to draft a set of standards to protect those rights. This United Nations' initiative followed several international non-Government organisation conferences relating to indigenous peoples. The most notable of these was the Third General Assembly of the World Council for Indigenous Peoples (WCIP) held in Canberra from 27 April to 2 May 1981 which agreed on a charter of rights for indigenous peoples. It is not possible to provide a comprehensive list of all conferences since 1970 dealing with the question of conventions concerning indigenous peoples, many of which were conducted under non-Government auspices.

(3) Australia is not a member of the Sub-Commission but sent an observer to the 34th Session of the Sub-Commission during which the proposal was originally formulated. As a member of the UN Commission on Human Rights, Australia was in a position to give its full support to this initiative at the Commission's recently concluded 38th Session. As regards non-Government organisation conferences, no provision was made for official Government representation at the Third General Assembly of the World Council for Indigenous Peoples although Australian officials observed the proceedings and assisted with arrangements. A delegation from the National Aboriginal Conference attended the conference and supported the charter proposed.

The Government's position in support of measures to protect the rights of indigenous peoples, demonstrated specifically by our support for the Commission on Human Rights initiative to set up the working group, remains unequivocal. The Government recognises the special vulnerability of indigenous peoples to violations of fundamental human rights and wishes to see effective international standards developed which deal with the particular needs and aspirations of indigenous peoples in every part of the world. The Government regards close consultation with representatives of indigenous peoples themselves as crucial to the drafting of such standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs and Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applications for re-appointment have been made by former officers of the Commonwealth Public service since 30 June 1981.

(2) Has it been necessary to establish any Re-appointment Review Committees to consider such applications; and if so, (a) who are the members of the Committee( s); and (b) how many applications have been dealt with.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister in Federal Affairs and Public Service Matter has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Former officers of the Australian Public Service (APS) who are eligible for re-appointment fall into three categories:
those persons who have resigned from the APS;
those persons who have been retired from the APS; and
some persons covered by the officers' mobility provisions in Part IV of the Public Service Act.
Statistics are not available on applications for re-appointment by staff in any of these categories.

The third category requires clarification. The Public Service Amendment Act 1978 came into operation on 15 March 1981. This Act repealed and replaced the Officers' Rights Declaration Act with the new officers' mobility scheme now contained in Part IV of the Public Service Act. This scheme provides a two-tier arrangement. The first tier covers Australian Public Service officers who are selected for employment with Commonwealth authorities or certain non- Commonwealth authorities for up to 3 years. The second tier covers those officers who, at the end of the 3 year period, decide to remain with authorities . The second tier also includes:
those persons covered by the Officers' Rights Declaration Act for 3 or more years who elect to join the mobility provisions;
those persons whose absence from the Service on leave without pay exceeds 3 years, and who are employed by either the Postal or Telecommunications Commissions; and

those persons compulsorily transferred to the Postal Commission, the Telecommunications Commission, the CSIRO, the National Gallery, the Australia Council, the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service and from the Australian Legal Aid Office.

Although a person covered by the second tier ceases to be an officer of the Service, he retains certain rights. These rights include transfer and promotion to Public Service positions and a person who is successful in gaining a transfer or promotion, and subsequently takes up duty in the position, is deemed to have been reappointed. A person in the second tier may also apply for re-appointment in certain circumstances. Such an application is dealt with by a Re-appointments Review Committee.

(2) It has been necessary to establish only one Re-appointments Review Committee to consider one case to date. The three members of the Committee were the Chairman of one of the Promotions Appeal Committees, a member nominated by the Public Service Board and a member nominated by the relevant staff association. The one application submitted to the Committee was brought to finality by other administrative action agreed to by the person concerned, resulting in his re-appointment at the classification level he held when he left the Service for employment in a statutory authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice on 11 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has final consideration been given to incorporating some of the functions of the Broadcasting Information Office (BIO), into the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) as detailed on page 22 of the Department of Communications Annual Report 1980-81; if so, (a) what functions are to be incorporated into ABT; and ( b) what were the originally envisaged functions of the BIO.
(2) Have any extra positions been provided to the ABT to undertake the former BIO functions.
(3) Have any extra funds been allocated to the ABT this year to provide for such activities or is it intended to provide such funds at any time.
(4) Is Mr Ian Fairweather still on staff of the ABT; or if he has intentions to leave, will his position be filled.

(5) Are positions currently with the ABT in Melbourne to be transferred to Sydney; if so and occupants of the above positions resign rather than move with the position will the positions be refilled in Sydney.
(6) Has the ABT stated what, if any, of the originally proposed functions it will carry out.
(7) By whom will the answer to this question have been prepared.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has recently completed a staff review and a re-organisation proposal will be forwarded to the Public Service Board within the next few weeks. The Tribunal has taken into account the Government direction that the proposed functions of the Broadcasting Information Office ( suitably modified and reduced) be retained within the Tribunal. The Tribunal proposes to create an Information Division. The Division will embrace liaison with the public and with the broadcasting system (apart from specific regulatory matters), the research activities of the Tribunal and the communications of Tribunal information, as effectively as possible, to the industry and the public . There will also be State representation.

Whilst the Tribunal will embrace most of the proposed functions envisaged for the BIO the Tribunal will not embrace them to the extent originally proposed in the Self Regulation Report. As the BIO was not established its functions were never formally determined.
(2) The Information Division will be incorporated within the Tribunal's staffing ceiling.
(3) No. The Tribunal has been undertaking the functions envisaged for the BIO and funds have been appropriated on that basis.

(4) Mr Fairweather was an officer of the Department of Communications and was never an officer of the Tribunal. Mr Fairweather ceased duty with the Department in 24 March 1982. His position will not be filled within the Department.
(7) Answers to questions are the responsibility of the Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is any signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty able to accumulate nuclear material and enrich that material to weapons grade under accepted international safeguard procedures and then abrogate that Treaty at any time.
(2) Has the Vietnamese Government revived the experimental nuclear reactor supplied to the previous Government of South Vietnam by the United States of America.

(3) Has the government of Iran revived an experimental nuclear reactor in Teheran that the United States of America supplied to the pre-revolutionary government of the former Shah, who had planned a major nuclear program for that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) obliges each non-nuclear weapon State Party to the Treaty not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices and not to seek or receive any assistance in the manufacture of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. The Treaty also imposes the obligation on each non-nuclear weapon State Party to the Treaty to accept International Atomic Energy Agency ( IAEA) safeguards for the exclusive purpose of verification of the fulfilment of its obligations assumed under the Treaty with a view to preventing diversion of nuclear energy from peaceful uses to nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices.

Article X of the NPT provides that any State Party has the right to withdraw from the Treaty if it decides that extraordinary events related to the subject matter of the Treaty have jeopardised its supreme interests. Such a Party would have to give three months notice to all other States Parties and the United Nations Security Council which notice must include a statement of the extraordinary events it regards as having jeopardised its supreme interests.

The NPT is the principal international instrument aimed at preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. It is a persuasive symbol of a broad-based international consensus and an important deterrent to proliferation. The strength of this consensus is demonstrated by the fact that 113 States have already adhered to the NPT. Abrogation of the Treaty by any State Party would have serious political and economic consequences. Such a State would forfeit its access to supplies of nuclear material and expertise. No State party has ever withdrawn from the Treaty except the Socialist Republic of Vietnam which in 1979 advised the three depositary governments for the treaty that it did not consider its self bound by the treaties and agreements signed by the former Saigon administration.

(2) No. However, in June 1981 the Board of Governors of the IAEA approved a nuclear safeguards agreement between the IAEA and Vietnam covering the Dalat reactor in connection with the supply of nuclear fuel for it from the USSR. This suggests that Vietnam proposes to recommence operating of the reactor.
(3) The Teheran reactor was shut down following the outbreak of hostilities with Iraq in 1980. As far as can be ascertained, it has not been reactivated.
Amended Answer replacing an answer which appeared in Hansard of 6 May 1982:

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Human Rights Commission: Aboriginal Foster Children

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard page 982) Senator Giles asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In a report in the West Australian of 19 September 1981, Mr Robert Riley, Chairman of the Aboriginal Child Care Agency, expressed serious concern at the number of Aboriginal children lost from the Aboriginal society through activities of the State Community Welfare Department. Mr Riley said that according to 'Children in Limbo'-a report recently published-66 per cent of children in long term care in Western Australia in community welfare institutions and placed with white foster parents were Aboriginals. The Aboriginal community was only 2.3 per cent of the State's total population. Mr Riley said that the Minister for Community welfare, Mr Hassell, had indicated that foster parents might soon be able to adopt children who had been in their care for two years. Mr Riley said:

'This means that a lot more Aboriginal children will be lost from the state's Aboriginal community. Under the old assimilation policy children were forcibly taken from Aboriginal communities and put in missions. This proposal to ease adoption regulations is exactly the same, only more thorough.'

Is the loss of cultural identity a matter which is within the charter of the Human Rights Commission? Can the Attorney-General indicate when the Human Rights Commission will be established and able to deal with such cases?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The scope of the powers and function of the Human Rights Commission are laid down in the Human Rights Commission Act. Broadly, the Commission is required to investigate complaints that Commonwealth law or practices infringe human rights and it is empowered to review legislation to conduct research and educational programs. The Honourable Senator's concern would appear to relate to matters of State, not Commonwealth, responsibility. The Human Rights Commission was established on 10 December 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April Senator Tate (Hansard, page 1347) asked me a question without notice concerning representations received by myself or the Government on steaming coal exports duties. I undertook to check on such representations and, having done that, I provide the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Coal Association met with Cabinet in pre-Budget discussions on Wednesday 10 March 1982 and presented a submission which covered the whole question of Coal Export Duties. The Government has undertaken to consider this submission in the Budget context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1655) Senator Robertson asked me, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware that, following a visit by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy to France, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory is now in France holding discussions with the French atomic energy officials about the sale of Northern Territory uranium? In view of the fact that France is not a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, will the Minister clarify whether the Australian Government would condone contracts to sell uranium to France if these were negotiated?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Chief Minister visited Paris from 26-29 April for discussions with French government organisations in the power generation field, including nuclear energy. The Government understands that there was some discussion about sales of Australian uranium to France.

Australia's nuclear safeguards policy as announced by the Prime Minister on 24 May 1977 does not require existing nuclear weapon states such as France to be parties to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in order to be eligible to purchase Australian uranium. However Australia's policy does require an assurance from such states that nuclear material supplied by Australia for peaceful purposes will not be diverted to military or explosive purposes and that it will be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.

Under the Australia/France and Australia/EURATOM nuclear safeguards agreements France has provided Australia with legally binding assurances to this effect. The entry into force of these agreements has opened the way for deliveries of Australian uranium to France under new contracts.

Similar agreements with the same assurances have been concluded in accordance with the Government's nuclear safeguards policy with the United Kingdom and the United States which are also nuclear weapon states.
